author: Houtworm
review: Overcooked 2 is an amazingly chaotic management game for up to 4 players, chop the ingredients and cook them as fast as possible for a nice tip, There are a ton of recipes and surprising kitchens.The story is set in The Onion Kingdom, The Onion King read from an old book and he summoned these undead loafs of bread called the Unbread, They are hungry and will consume the entire Kingdom if they are not fed in time. You play as one of the many available chefs and it is your job to feed the Unbread to save the world. The story plays out trough some dialogue from the king after certain stages, The story is nothing special, but it is a funny universe and it should give you a laugh or 2.The Onion king his dog and all playable characters are extremely likable, They don't say much but they all look very funny, If you are a shark a mouse or something way crazier, It will have a friendly face. The enemies are a little disturbing but also quite funny, Undead loafs of Bread, It probably won't give you or your children nightmares.The game is mostly focused on multiplayer, Every single gamemode can be played with up to 4 players, Online, Local but also a mix of the 2. You also can play it solo, But you will control 2 chefs and have to switch between them to manage the kitchen. it is still the same game, A very chaotic experience, Coordinating with yourself is harder than it sounds.There is the Story mode, which brings you to an overworld where you can launch levels, You start in 1-1 and before you can start 2-1 you have to visit the castle and talk to the Onion King. There are 6 worlds in the main campaign, and every world has 6 levels. There is a ton of DLC, some free and some paid which bring a bunch of new worlds, levels, chefs and recipes to the table. Only the host needs the DLCs, You can play along if you just own the game and are in a multiplayer game.In the main Story you can also switch gamemodes, From Story which is the default, Practice which disables timers and Survival in which served meals add time to the timer. Next to the main Story mode there is Arcade mode, Which is just a random level from the main Story or one of the DLCs, It is a nice thing if you completed every single level with 4 stars. Then there is a Versus mode, In which 2 kitchens have to fight it out, It is always 2 versus 2, But you can play 1 vs 1 too by controlling 2 chefs.The gameplay is extremely hectic, Raw ingredients need to be chopped, Cooked, Baked, Blended, Steamed. Grilled, and mostly they need multiple steps to prepare, Then you need to combine all the prepared ingredients on a plate and deliver it as fast as possible. There are more recipes than I can count, It starts easy, But things get complex pretty fast. Good teamwork is essential for getting all the stars.Next to the obvious cooking you also have to wash the plates, make sure nothing burns, deliver the orders on time and make sure you don't mess up the ingredients. If you mess up a recipe you can throw it away, If it burns you have to grab the fire extinguisher and put out the fire before it spreads.The levels are even crazier, There are kitchens with a road running trough it, People dancing in a Conga line, trough it, or even kitchens on a few floating rafts in the middle of a river. There are kitchens which have moving parts, switch positions, have portals, buttons and even cannons to reach out of reach platforms.The graphics are adorable, It is simple but charming, Things you can interact will stay the same and are marked clearly. The decor is ever changing, You go to all kinds of restaurants, Indoor, Outdoor, On a river or high in the sky. The Soundtrack is very cosy and uplifting, But it gets tenser inside the levels as they progress, especially the last 30 seconds. It is a very nice fit, and each theme has its own soundtrack. Together it creates a very nice atmosphere that is fun and suitable for all ages.The game runs fine, There are just 2 things that bother me, First the game Crashes on controller connect, Which is especially awful for a multiplayer game. And secondly the Steam Cloud save is not working. Other than that the game runs very well I get a very nice 200-300 fps. Not a single problem next to the 2 forementioned things. The worst thing is that these are a long standing problems. And there doesn't seem to be any interest in actually fixing it.After you complete the story and all the DLC with 3 stars you can fight it out in Versus mode where you have to compete together with someone or solo against another kitchen. There is also Arcade mode, This will just pick a random level from the Story and DLC. There is no random generation, A lot of DLC, but even after completing everything the game remains a lot of fun, The human factor is just so unpredictable and it causes some very chaotic and funny situations.The game is fun but frustrating, Crazy and Chaotic. Blame your friends for burning the burgers, not preparing the mushrooms and throwing sushi on the road. It is a great game and certainly worth your money, Just be sure to backup your save files.

author: ready2b
review: Given how much I enjoyed , there is no way I would miss out on playing . Just like the original, 2 is a chaotic party game where you and up to 3 friends work together to serve top-of-the-line dishes while coping with and overcoming terrible kitchen designs, bizarre situations and natural disasters. In sum, frantically fun.  Both Overcooked! games are great but I recall enjoying the first game more. The new features introduced in 2 were welcome but sometimes flawed and unnecessary. Somehow the fewer gimmicks and simpler levels (for the most part) in 1 made for a more fun experience. Regardless, I enjoyed Overcooked! 2 as a whole; it is still the chaotically fun co-op experience that I‚Äôve come to expect and love from the Overcooked! Series. Looking forward to 3!

author: Hyfrith
review: An incredibly fun and frantic couch co-op experience. We simply connected a couple of old wired Xbox 360 controllers to my PC to play this game together in our house and it was a blast! It will test the strength of your relationships, haha.But why can't I recommend this any more? The developers released a compilation version of this game called All You Can eat which was Overcooked 1 and 2 in one bundle plus some extra features. Trouble is, they are continuing to release free content updates for that version of the game but aren't adding those updates to the base Overcooked 2 game!! So anyone who already owns 1 and 2 separately has to pay all over again for All You Can Eat if they want to receive further content updates.This is a despicable business tactic and shows real contempt for long time supporters and fans of this otherwise excellent franchise.

author: AngriffsBaum
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: everRampager
review: As a returning player: 6/10, for those new to the series: 9/10. Review will be from the first perspective.Being quite familiar with the first game, my partner and I were super excited for more cooking chaos but ultimately we didn't feel the game is worth the money. The first three/four worlds we 3-starred everything on our first try just from familiarity with the game, the throwing mechanic has a lot of potential and the Kevin levels were a lot of fun but in the end it feels like we only got about 12 levels of actual difficulty.Overcooked 2 was the time to add in a level editor, not switches on the world map (what are those even for, anyway?). Make the game replayable, maybe a new game+ that you can select at the start if you're familiar with OC already/unlocked at the end of story that changes up the base game. OC2 isn't a sequel, it's just the definitive version of OC1.

author: Feena
review: What a cute fun game to play with your family and friends! Overcooked returned with many new features and the most highlighted one is online multiplayer! Yes, you can play now with your online friends, unlike the first game which only supports local co-op/PVP. We are back to Onion Kingdom and must help to defend it from the hoards of The Unbread. (undead) The story is fun and cute, and the stages are more challenging than before, you also keep unlocking new recipes that require you and your friends to team up or yell and shout during the whole stage. I had so much fun playing it with my friend and sister.The artwork is fun, you'll have so many chefs to choose from and unlock the more you advance into the game. The map is huge, each chapter has multiple stages and each stage has a unique challenge, besides the DLC's which adds even more contents. There are also Kevin's the dog, stages where you have to cook and serve dog food! those are really hard to make!The soundtracks are nice, fitting the gameplay, nothing too loud. I played this game using a controller, not sure if it can work as smoothly with a keyboard. The trophies are a bit challenging and need some grinding, but what makes this fun is when you play it with your friends, you wouldn't feel that you are grinding for anything.  You can team up with total of four players together.Pros:+Beautiful visuals and locations design.+Fun Soundtracks.+Unique gameplay+Multiple Chefs.+Bonus stages.+Huge map and many stages to play.+New Game+ unlocks an additional star to earn and difficulty. +Seasonal free content + paid DLCs.+Local and online multiplayer.+Many recipes (You unlock more as you advance into the game).+Steam achievements.Cons:-When you fall down into the sea, the game freezes for everyone for a couple of seconds until the player respawn. After finishing the main game, you'll unlock a new challenge and that will require you to get a fourth star in each stage! The developers still bringing new content and adding more recipes. With the new Holiday free update, you get to feed angry hoards and defend your kitchen at the same time!  I highly recommend it for people who enjoys multiplayer challenging games.

author: homskillet
review: I feel bad leaving a bad review as I'm sure the developers put a lot of effort into it and I appreciate what the game is trying to offer. However as a big fan of the first one I can't help but point out some huge problems with the second one that have kept me from enjoying it.Overcooked is at its best when you are figuring out how to solve the level efficiently given the layout of the level in front of you. You make a plan, divide tasks, and refine your execution until your team is a well oiled machine. Then you move on to the next level and do it again.It's at its worst when the levels are built to slow you down or irritate you. Not particularly challenging, just clunky. You end up standing around a lot. You often have to wait for platforms to reappear or to get to you. There's nothing you can do to speed it up. I'm cool with dynamic levels that force you to adapt, but not when you end up just standing around waiting for the level shifts to occur. The first game's levels felt like they were asking the question "can you find an efficient way to get things done here?" This time around the levels are asking "can you find a way to get anything done here at all?" I think they knew the levels were clunky and made the scoring system very forgiving to compensate, because we got 3 stars on almost every level the first time through. I know they're releasing a NG+ so maybe the difficulty will change, but going back and replaying levels is not that appealing of a proposition due to the level design I described above. I am hoping future patches fix this game. The foundation is solid, some new levels and appropriate difficulty would solve everything.If you are considering this game and haven't played the first one, I suggest buying that one instead. It is far less polished, but the design is on point.

author: Corvo
review: Happiness, contentment, glee, felicity, bliss, enjoyment.You will find none of this here.Only pain, misery, suffering and misanthropy. And you will still love every second of it, while you laugh and want to murder your friends at the same time. Highly recommended for co-op, just be ready to get new friends afterwards since they don't belong in the necessary hive-mind to accomplish the tasks.On a more serious note, the game is quite fun and have plenty of levels with interesting variations and gimmicks. There's never a dull moment and the pacing is good. It seems to be more balanced to 2 and 4 people than 3, and dropping objects is a herculean ordeal and the game would be two times better if they made it easier. But besides those issues, Overcooked 2 is a fun game and worth buying.

review: It's one of those games where you have to play with at least one other person as you will be yelling/crying to "throw the dang meat" or to "get out of the way" to get to the rice that is about to burn. author: Paul
review: It's probably the best widely available local coop game out there, and on top of that it's regularly upated. Supporting split controllers and keyboards doesn't even require a lot of preparation for a bigger company of four. Though there can be so much going on that it's better to start from beginning of campaign, since even for a casual game difficulty can spike before you really notice, but in score requirements for progression are lowered compared to Ovecooked 1. Beyond that, it's mostly about how player company can start cooperating (which is wonderful for the genre), and all that cooking chaos is a colorful background.

author: CaptNCarcinogen
review: I 3 starred every mission within around 6 hours of game time, and honestly, it would have been faster if every second mission I didn't have to alt+F4 because the game failed to load missions and froze on the loading screen. Also, the last mission of the game was pretty lackluster and probably one of the easiest missions in the game to 3 star. I did most of the game, earning a score on most missions of approximately 2x the required amount for 3 stars and only a few missions required a 2nd try to get full star rating. When playing multiplayer, there were several lag spikes, to the point my friends froze in place for about 30 seconds, multiple times. On the note of multiplayer, only the host earns achievements, chefs, and any sort of progress. I wish the unbread made more of an appearance rather than the odd points on the world map and the beginning cutscene. It is a good, fun game, but not worth the full asking price. Quite disappointing especially coming from the first game expecting it to be better, like a sequel should be.

author: aruvin
review: is a massive improvement over overcooked 1 and still delivers the culinary co-op madness.  (ovc 2 in short) is developed by Ghost Town Games Ltd. and Team17 Digital Ltd. It is published by Team17 Digital Ltd. The PC version was released on Aug 8, 2018 and it is also available on PlayStation 4, Switch & Xbox One. As of this writing, Metacritic  shows:I am not going to address the obvious question: Does the sequel of the beloved 2016's overcooked live up to the expectation? Instead, i'll be asking you: Are you  of those people who is  by all the comments you read on reddit/metacritic/steam reviews/forums/etc and is on the fence whether to purchase overcooked 1 or 2 because of all the  feedbacks? I totally understand what you are going through and I can only say, it's not the product's fault. its the people. They are causing all this  over one of the  couch co-op/co-op product in the history of gaming/current market (Well, at least as of this writing in the year 2020).Once again, the onion kingdom needs saving. This time around, onion king accidently summons a horde of unbread. *gasp* So thats where players come in. The objective is to serve the food while overcoming different challenges/obstacles presented in each level. That's easier said than done.Play up to 4 players via local or internet multiplayer. The campaign offer players 6 worlds@regions to explore with a total of 36 levels and 8 Kevin levels that needs to be unlocked. Aside from the campaign mode, Versus mode is still available and there's an Arcade mode now. Once you complete the entire campaign, you will unlocked 4 star mode. Play with your food chefs!If that's not enough to satisfy your culinary experience, there are currently 5 DLC's available for purchase and a new free DLC coming up in July 2020. Controls: WASD keyboard and controller. Keyboard key binding is not available.Audio: The background music sets the mood and tempo for the game. Different background music will be played in different world/region (similar like ovc 1) Every player action has feedback sound; dash, chop, throw ingredients, fire, falls, etc. everything. +1 to the teamVisuals: The overall concept is still similar with ovc 1: simple, colorful, clean and plain looking (does not have details in the costume/looks) however I find that ovc 2's color to be more . Aside from that, we have a lot more new cooks to pick from; eagle, mouse, octopus, beaver and etc. +1 to the teamThis is a major section to cover. The dev's expanded on the existing mechanics & level design of ovc 1. They really up their game with some of these changes. The notable ones:These are just from the base game. If you own the DLC's theres even more creative/weird stuffs; moving around the kitchen via cannons, water squirt guns to wash dishes, backpacks to pick ingredients from, Marshmallows, hot dogs, drinks, milk shakes and more..Looking just at ovc 2, base product (excluding the dlc's) overall, it "feels" as if ovc 2 is more polished than ovc 1. The level design is more creative - where it forces players to do more/interact/react more as compared to ovc 1 which makes the game feel more intense. Does that mean it's more difficult? I am highlighting this because , overcooked games will always be coach co-op/co-op centric product that tries to make you have fun with friends/people. It is  dark souls. The fact that the devs made ovc 2 to allow players to make some mistakes/blunders and still manage to obtain 3 stars is to cater for the general audience. From young kids to adults, from casuals to hardcores. Each one of us have different preferences. I dont want to play with 4 perfectionist players. It's stressful. I also dont want to play with 4 jokers. it's crap. ovc 2 offers that balance. Those jokers will never be able to obtain 3 stars - or what if they do? or what if some of us can play or cannot play as good as  but still be able to obtain 3 stars. Whats so damaging? Is there any harm to lower the skill ceiling? to the community? to the mass market? or it's just your pride and ego? or your butt?So, coming back to ovc 2, i expected the devs to build on ovc 1 mechanics  what i did not expect is to this degree of change. It is a massive amount of effort and one that i have to applaud to all the teams involved in the production of ovc 2. The DLC's are great addition but also very challenging/brutal experience. If there's any negative point(s), i am slightly disappointed that they took out the rats and blackout levels from ovc 1. Yes, those were really annoying levels but I have some fond memories from there. I was also really hoping for a final boss, but what i got was a defense game mode. But as a whole, the product offers more positives than cons. So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for overcooked 2 is a  Crispy Golden Taco worth 9/10. *Eats the crispy golden taco in the cannon while the entire kitchen is on fire*

author: Nudle
review: Games today are released prematurely and mostly feels clunky. Some worse than others.  It leaves you with disgraceful taste in your mouth after spending a full price of 60 USD only to witness the horrible gameplay and terrible false advertisement. If you are like me and just wanted to look for a fun game after being disappointed, again and again from triple-A studios.  Then this is the review for you. I will do my best and shed you the truth about this game and my experience playing through it... (WARNING It's a long read. TLDR at the buttom.) Overcooked 2 is one of the few games that support both local and multiplayer.  A good feature on paper, but I've seen enough games struggling with the input and lags. Overcooked does not do this. They were able to execute the host system flawlessly and it feels great to move around.Like the host system, the gameplay feels polished. The mechanics are simple. Collect, Cut, Cook and repeat. The first maps are set up to be easy, to make you feel accomplished, confident for the next challenge.Suddenly, it all stops. You are surprised at not getting the three-stars in the first attempt. You frown, but laugh it off. The next map is unlocked. But you are not going anywhere until you get that full star.700 Score for three stars? That's easy, you just got 650 and you barely tried. And so you Collect, Cut and Cook. You get past 700 scores, but you keep going. This map had tarnished your hot streak. 800, 900. A thousand... You showed that level designer. No longer would they underestimate your skills.The adrenaline fades but does not completely vanish. It lingers in the background, ready to answer your beckoning call. A small smile form on your lips. And you are pumped for more.As you progress through the maps. New challenges appear and you are forced to be more creative. You are stuck again. 1500 Scores for the three star.You use more time studying, watching. Then you see it. It was so obvious... The answer radiates like a second sun, and the route is set.As ingredients are flying through the air. You start understanding its more behind the gameplay. No longer is it a cooking simulator. But an acrobatic dance. Suddenly, the ingredients collide and fall either off the map or in the worst case; Staring back at you from an unreachable spot. Your brilliant flawless cooked steak is chilling in the cold wind. The time is moving, you grit your teeth and collect, cut and cook another. You barely make it, and a heavy breath escapes your lip. Just to realize you have been holding your breath all this time. Sh*t... The game is really pushing you now.Buttons are pressed, fires are spewing, tables are rotating, people are blocking...What the hell is going on?The level designer you showed earlier has stepped up his game. The previous strategies become useless. The randomly generated actions take you off guard, and you are surrounded by fire. Unable to move, unable to reach the fire extinguisher. "Bull Sh*t" You press restart.Again, this time. Your finger slip and you throw your dish into the trash instead for adding an ingredient. Your eyes dart to the time, then to the score, and back to the timer. You realize you won't make it. You press restart. Ingredients are collect, cut and cooked. The time is ticking, you realize this is it... The tip is at x8 and this chocolate cake would get you enough score for the three stars. You pick up the plate, run over to the oven. The beautiful majestic cake sits on the plate perfectly. You nod to yourself inside, the art team have done a fantastic job. Who in their right mind would not take a piece of this cake? After all, it was filled with the best ingredients in this world, and better. It was fueled by your hard and passionate work. Shaking yourself from the thought, your eyes dart back to the timer. It's blinking. In a panic, you move past the spewing fire, and charge the rolling belt head-on. Your eyes widen. In the brink of panic, you forgot it was rolling the opposite direction. Gritting your teeth. You press the dazing button, and it works. You are moving forward!Another button press. Your one step closer to serving your masterpiece.Another, it's so close right now. You could smell the three stars now.Your hands drenched in sweat, you go for one last push.And your thump slip, the character is slightly tilted in another direction. A sudden gasp is audible all around you. And a horrifying scream fills the room. Little-Jimmy in the corner is crying, your best-friend Bob is furiously cursing in the living room. Your girlfriend is looking at you with one of those familiar looks... But unlike the previous time, her disappointing look felt more disturbing, perhaps it was the clothing. Disgusted, defeated, ashamed, you rise up from the couch and turn around to look at all the familiar faces, and freezes. Grandma Maria is holding your gaze. You hear her mutter to herself "The cake is a lie."TLDR: The game is one of my favorite games in 2018. Do not let the family-friendly art deceive you. This game is brutal, it's been a while since I laughed out loud playing a game, especially for my own stupidity. This made me realize again how fun games could be. I would recommend playing this game together. But if you like to be challenged further. Playing alone would take some serious effort.

author: jonkelling
review: Finished the game in almost 6 hours. My wife and I were really excited about this game having played through the first one many times over. We will keep playing in case we're just judging this too soon, but so far this is a disappointment compared to the first one. My wife is a professional game designer, and we spent a lot of time just picking apart details and poor executions, which was kind of sad :( the story mode map was just made unnecessarily more complicated and brings nothing extra to the game. In fact it's annoying. We were excited to finish and switch to arcade mode so we didn't have to mess with the map, but arcade mode didn't appear to display our previous scores, so we didn't know what to beat. The levels are either poorly balanced, or we just haven't figured out a good strategy for each yet. The levels have so many little things that get in your way, though, that we often didn't want to replay a level to perfect it. They just were not that fun. In the first game, we would finish a level and be like "awesome! We can do better! Let's try that again!" That sadly just didn't happen in OC2. Some levels change 2 or 3 times throughout--the first game did this, but in that one the dynamic levels never seemed out of place like they do in OC2. We would have happily paid for more content in the first game with similar philosophies in level design.To be honest we're not that surprised. So many good games make you think, "wow this is great, I hope when they make the next one they understand what makes this one so good and don't mess it up."My advice: If you are looking at this game for the first time, just go get the first one instead.

author: ekualajzer
review: Just finished the campaign with my wife. All missions apart from secret levels with 3 stars. It is way easier than the first game, we actually had no challange at all. We completed the last mission, supposedly a bossfight, with 3 stars on first try with no effort. Then the game made us watch credits which i couldn't skip so i quit the game and my progress didn't save. The game is lacking any novelty, apart from several new recipes, dashing and throwing it's all the same, but easier. Almost no UI improvements were done, there's no quick way to restart levels, you have to come back to the centre of the map after each area to hear another boring part of the story. Don't get me wrong, the mechanics are still very fine, the core of the game is really fun, we enjoyed our playtrough, but we feel a lot of disappointment as well. In my opinion the game is not worth its price at the current level. I expected more from a sequel.Disclaimer: We  didn't play any online features of the game, just the main story.

author: Dean Ambrose
review: For new players this could seem a good couch game with interesting gameplay....For those, who're a bit familiar with the original game, this one will be a total disappointment. Overcooked! was an incredible place to use teamplay and develop strategies to beat challenging levels. This one is all about chaotic running throughout maps full of dynamic motley things and getting 3 stars in the end even if you fail a lot.I don't understand how the same people, who created the incredible first game, could turn such a great gameplay into something like this. Taking into account the reviews on Steam, I'm not the only one, who is disappointed.

author: The Greater Sphinx
review: Overcooked 2 is a hectic co-op game where you play a chef, cooking a variety of recipes in a variety of crazy kitchens. You'll have to cooperate with your teammates to fill orders in time and collect enough points to pass through the levels. It's very similar to the first game, but there are a number of improvements to it, including online co-op and some small improvements in the controls.This game can be played with up to four players. I think you can play alone, but I can't imagine it being all that enjoyable. The fun really comes from playing the levels with your friends and figuring out the best way to run your kitchen efficiently. I've played the game with 2, 3, and 4 players before, and while some of the levels are best suited to one particular number of players, I think all of the levels are playable even with just two players.Story mode has a variety of levels to play through, although it really isn't very long. However, there are a variety of other goals to complete as well. There are 4 stars to collect on each level, there are a few other game modes to try, and there are a number of bonus levels as well which are still being added to. I also think the levels are incredibly fun to replay even without much new content.I love the art style and the music. It's all very cute and rounded. The chefs you can unlock are all very cute, with a variety of different people, animals, and other creatures to choose from. The background music is nice to listen to and well-suited to the game. The story in story mode is pretty bare bones, but it's fine, a game like this doesn't really need an amazing story.The DLC in the game is worth buying, but not necessary. There is a ton of content and replay value to the base game, especially with the occasional free updates, and the DLC is all self-contained. However, each DLC adds new recipes and level mechanics, and the DLC levels all have replay value of their own.Overall, Overcooked 2 is a great game to play with your friends. I've had a lot of fun playing the game with various friends and will probably continue to come back to the game over time. If you don't have people to play with (in-person or online with voice chat), you can probably skip it, but otherwise I'd highly recommend it. 10/10

author: FunkyPigeon
review: Played with friends as a 4 stack. Everyone has their own role to be doing. Fun but also sometimes challenging. The amount of laughs and fun which came from this game was insane just from a cooking game. Thank you for an amazing game!

author: trapdoor
review: Overcooked 2 is a fantastic game, far superior to the previous edition, and utter chaotic fun with friends. Bringing Online Play to the table, Overcooked 2 already is an immense improvement from Overcooked. The level designs are creative, diverse, challenging and great fun. The level requirements themselves or time constraints can be difficult at times, but overall a great experience, and I deeply enjoyed 100%ing this one with my friend. Didn't cause any rage or arguments or even general burnout for us, but I think that's largely because it's overexaggerated for comedy how difficult the game is. Mostly you'll be laughing or too focused on your tasks at hand to think of anything toxic. Tons of character options, tons of themes/levels/foods, and tons of DLC that only enhance the experience and are also very worthwhile to purchase. Additions to the game only need to be purchased by one person for the whole party to experience them as well. Along with the expected levels, the game also features tower-defense that breaks up the flow in a much needed way.I can see myself playing this game for dozens of more hours, and my only qualm is that I wish the online matchmaking was more active. However, if you're already have someone in mind, you've nothing to lose.:) I strongly recommend this one, full price or not.

author: Sgt.H
review: While the game never strays too far from the 1st installment of the series, it doesn't manage to evolve following the same brilliant path of the first one.Quality is good, graphics fancied up (and got a bit less readable too), a few interesting actions were added (throwing items, water pistol, etc) and it has loads of new recipes, but always feels more like an expansion of the 1st one than a full sequel. In a way that's no problem, we loved the 1st one (yeah, I am another one of those that did play it with his girlfriend) and we couldn't way to play more of it, even if it didn't add much stuff.What falls short compared to the 1st one is level design and balancing. The 1st one was a gem in that sense, with each level absolutely well tuned and requiring to be played multiple failing times until -bam!- you could get 3 stars.Overcooked 2 levels tend to be far too easy in general (the surf'n'turf DLC is far better balanced), using map dangers more as an obstacle than as part of the complexity (e.g. the leves where you can fall).Then comes the 4th star, and it's close to unachievable in terms of difficulty.One really bad side of the new visuals, if you have multiple food items on a surface perpendicular to the screen surface ("vertical"), it's impossible to understand what's where and what spaces are free.All in all a pleasant game to play, but could have probably evolved much better than how it did. Still got a 75/100 in my books, and I do recommend playing the Surf'n'turf DLC.

author: quacktagon
review: Overcooked 2 is a fantastic cooperative cooking game that will have you and your friends laughing and shouting as you work together to serve up delicious meals. The added online multiplayer feature is a great addition, allowing you to play with people all over the world. The graphics and level design are also top notch, making for a truly immersive experience. Whether you're a fan of cooking games or just looking for a fun party game to play with friends, Overcooked 2 is definitely worth checking out.

author: cocaine bear
review: Overcooked! 2, wow, where to start. This game has truly stepped up in an fps and MOBA dominant gaming world and delivered a unique experience that all players will find both challenging yet enjoyable at the same time. I find myself playing this game with a constant smile on my face, no matter the chefs I am working with at the current time. The game has a unique way of uniting players together as one, which is a key facet of the games immense success and I thank the developers sincerely for providing the community with a game that has so much potential in such a seemingly endless journey of benevolence and comradery. As a result of this, I have awarded Overcooked! 2 a 6.9 out of 7 raw tomatoes. I thank you for your time.

author: (üíï) Pink Lily
review: The game for someone like me was intense. Im not the best in general with games that require a lot of effort and complicated mechanics. Im one of those gals that prefers those cute, straight forward games that are simple and fun. This game might look overwhelming but is actually fun. The game is chaotic in a group setting but if you want to actually know whats going on trying it solo a few times after playing with some friends and building up some confidence. I really enjoyed it and after exploring for a few hrs have come to really enjoy and appreciate this game. I do believe to really take the experience to a new level you need a group of people who you enjoy gaming with or a buddy who can be as invested. author: Serieus
review: Overcooked 2 is a multiplayer extravaganza!  If you play with family members or friends, I hope that your relationships will survive this game, as it will strain those relationships to the max.In this game, you must prepare food of different kinds for your customers.  You must grab ingredients, chop, cook, bake, steam, and plate them and deliver them timely in order to reach a certain amount of points.  Three stars is what you're aiming for, and while it may be easy on the early levels, it becomes vastly more difficult at the later levels and in the DLC add ons.You will prepare pies, pancakes, salads, hamburgers, hot dogs, smores, kabobs, pizza, and so much more.  For some you will use a BBQ or a firepit which requires you to use blowers to intensify the heat or add chopped wood in order to cook faster.  The worst part, and this is horrible, you also have to do dishes.  The amount of work required to get three stars in the amount of time given is not easy.  The more players you have the more points is expected that you will get.The storyline is forgettable, King Onion, or something like that, and his sidekick dog Kevin need you to save their butts of their kingdom, and cooking wonderful meals delivers the saving grace they need.  Ridiculous, but ultimately funny and forgettable.  In the main game, there are several worlds, I think 5 or 6 with 4 levels each typically.  Each world provides a different atmosphere or different scenery to move around in.  The DLCs offers three worlds each with 4 levels a piece.  Overall there is more than enough levels to keep you busy for a long time.I will admit, I've never played this single player other my experience of doing a two player versus.  You must click a button to switch between your two chefs making the need to get things done quickly rather more difficult.  Did I mention you can burn down your kitchen if you overcook something?  You can fry mixers or burn things, as a red exclamation with a loud alarm starts to sound to alert you that you need to hurry and save it before it's too late.  This adds to the stress of everything else that you are doing.  This will get you screaming, yelling, complaining, blaming, and shouting at your partners, and hopefully it's all for the good laughs of what this game does.  It is the most stressful multiplayer atmosphere ever and I loved it.There are many achievements, none too impossible to obtain, I have a few left, but I think I'll be able to unlock them all before I'm done with this game.  The game can be played 4 player couch co-op, versus (2 on 2) or can be played online as well.  I only played with controllers and the controls are great, nothing sloppy, but I'm not sure how this would play only using the keyboard.If you're looking for a laugh out loud exciting multiplayer game, this is definitely one of the best I've played.  This is originally a time management game, but they've never made them like this before.  They took these a to a whole new level, and it's very fun.  Pick this up if you haven't already.

With a range of game modes ‚Äì story, arcade and versus, there is endless replayability, particularly as you‚Äôll want to collect the allotted three stars (or four stars after completing the story mode) and will keep the family entertained ‚Äì which is of utmost importance during times of pandemic lockdowns.

review: This game is fun. Throwing stuff around is the best part.The only real issue is it gets slight desync issues when it's 4 players.As a little criticism for the gameplay:This game makes use of movement impairments quite too many times.Moving platforms, wind blowing you away, moving bands etc.It becomes struggling and waiting for the level to line itself up so you can bring the 4th ingredient into the weird fish mash thingy you are mixing in a blender, then you wait some more for it to get mixed then it's another struggle until you arrive at the cooking station.I would rather like if they had more "optimization" levels, where you had to find the fastest route, the best way to keep the food going. More like a real restaurant where you have to sort out the dishes, figure out if you need the pan or the fryer. Organizing rooms and ingredients.But it's not like a huge issue.

author: Corrin
review: prefacing this by saying i really love this game and it's been a lot of fun to play with my partner while we have to be apart thanks to the online multiplayer, but that's the same exact feature i'm writing this negative review over. the online multiplayer sucks. if you can even manage to set up a lobby at all (theirs won't no matter what, mine occasionally doesn't let me), you can get about halfway through any given set of levels before it'll start disconnecting your second player no matter what. it is not a wifi issue or a steam issue. over time, it just gets worse and worse. googling for help finds tons of people having the same problem and the dev team offering NO solutions whatsoever (clearing your downloads cache and manually deleting save files seems to SOMETIMES work for us). it's honestly a little ridiculous that there are so many complaints online specifically about the online multiplayer system not functioning properly and yet the dev team refuses to fix any of these issues. i love the game when i am actually able to play it without my player 2 disconnecting every five seconds and i really wish it would not do this. the game itself is extremely fun and it's genuinely being hindered by how bad the online multiplayer is.tldr game good online multiplayer system horrible please fix it for the love of god

author: Lau
review: Super fun game to play with online friends, it helps if you're on the same page about what you want to achieve (my friend and I agreed on attempting as many times as necessary to get 3 stars on EACH level, whereas if I played with my sister for example she'd be happy to get just one star per level and go through all the worlds as quickly as possible). I played with a friend on the same city and we would get a bit of lag sometimes but nothing terrible, however I can't speak for online friends playing on different countries/continents, hopefully another review covered that.I love all the challenges and the cute little chefs, I wish we could've gotten the calico cat chef for free thoughReview was made after completing all the worlds, levels and secret levels of the main game, we haven't tried the free DLC yet

author: tempzest
review: Overall, this is a great co-op game with some technical flaws (AYCE doesn't really solve crash problems with online play, but reviews under that game say more about that than I feel like stating here). You can 3 star campaign levels solo pretty easily, but you'll need a decently skilled friend to get you to 4 star those levels, if that matters to you. Best feature of the game imo are the versus levels (couch doesn't have any issues, but online is stupidly buggy, esp cross-platform). There are only 6 versus levels that come with the base game, but the Surf n Turf DLC adds two of the best levels, and is well worth it for the price. My boyfriend and I have spent a good number of my hours on this game exclusively playing couch pvp and yelling at each other. Fun time, 10/10 would recommend.

author: Artibius
review: + creative levels+ fun soundtrack+ plenty of stages (36+8 hidden)+ online co-op included+ new game plus+ FREE Seasonal Updates DLCs (32 stages)+ FREE All At Sea DLC (5 skins)+ your friendships/relationships might get stronger- cannot rebind gamepad buttons- your friendships/relationships will get stress testedMaybe seems easier than the previous game. But it definitely felt more fun than the first and for sure less stressful (at least the main campaign). But that doesn't mean it's totally easy. In reality, the difficulty seemed all over the place when you get stuck on some random level but the final one you can 3-star in two tries. So keep playing, it's possible to 3-star most of them with a bit of practice. Worth mentioning is the new game+ mode that unlocks after you get all stars. In this mode you need to be even faster and get 4-star ratings, effectively giving you and endgame goal after you would normally be done. This sequel looks just as good, maybe even better, than the previous game. Smoother UI means it is easier to see what is going on and what you are taking/placing. And overall they worked to improve the aesthetics & level design but kept the art-style. A nice addition are hidden (Kevin) levels although I would prefer if the requirements were visible somewhere outside of Steam guides. Included is the FREE Seasonal Updates DLCs which, as of time of writing, consists of 27 levels (5 + 5 - Winter Wonderland; 7 + 5 - Spring Festival; 5 - Suns Out, Buns Out!; 5 - Moon Harvest Festival). It's a mix of all previous DLCs (recipes, mechanics, tools) plus a couple of new ones, all coated with their unique art styles. This is dispersed between six areas accessible from a central hub. No story with the Onion King (and Kevin) this time. The difficulty is often higher, especially for two or three levels in Winter Wonderland. These levels might challenge you A LOT and are no joke even compared to some of the DLC campaigns. Overall 70+ levels to try out (including the free DLCs) in one of the best co-op games currently available. Playing solo isn't great but if you have someone to play with this game is a blast!------------------------------------------------------------------

author: a passerby
review: + Fluid, easy to master controls+ Like the first one, this game is designed for every demographic (gamer nerds and casuals)+ Music and artstyle is as charming as the first one+ Singleplayer trains you to have 200 IQ+ Probably one of the best multiplayer games around (fun both on couch and online)+ Being able to merge both local and online multiplayer into a single game is a bonus+ The addition of new game+, AKA the fourth star, introduces a whole new challenge (and it is )- Height sometimes can be hard to tell; you don't know which cook has the higher ground on certain levels- Couch multiplayer with split keyboard can be a little confusing (keyboard cook has to be player 1)- Switches on the world map to activate ramps are rather an unnecessary additionRegardless of whether you played the first one, I highly recommend this game. Although I feel like you'd be missing out if you haven't yet played the first. The cons I listed aren't really cons at all; this is just a great game all around, and a great addition to everyone's Steam library.

review: My partner and I have really enjoyed this one!Really captures a crazy feeling of chaos but we love the challenge of having to decipher the best possible work flow for the stage! Lots of extra modes and additional chefs for cute cosmetics.Nothing beats pounding out the sashimi to a killer jam while playing as a raccoon in a wheelchair, ha ha!The nice thing about Overcooked 2 as opposed to the first one is if you're playing 2+ player they've added this handy 'throw' feature; where you can THROW each other ingredients which makes some stages hilariously work out. Hard to imagine playing without that button...work the extra few dollars on sale or off IMO.Thanks!

author: Ganking is 300 Bucks
review: This game feels very rushed. The core gameplay is fine but there are a handful of quality of life changes that need to be made.1) Allow players to change chefs prior to starting the level, not at the main screen.2) Also, I have had the game lock to 'keyboard' when you have a gamepad and had to restart; I think the solution is just to avoid pressing keys prior to the main menu.3) Players that try to spam A to skip the opening screens are thrust into the level select screen and then have to back out back to the main menu; a minor issue that can be fixed by forcing the players to press START rather than A to open the main menu once the opening credits are finished.4) Game will occassionally freeze at the loading screen for levels.5) Netcode is inconsistent and desyncs are not uncommon.6) Difficulty for 2 and 3 players (I haven't played with 4 players total) is generally too easy, but also inconsistent: with the exception of 1 level, I was able to get 3 stars by an extra 50% or more. In particular, level 5-3 is very challenging, but 5-4 is at a difficulty that I would expect for the first world. In general, the numbers for the stars need to be tweaked. Overcooked 1 was challenging, perhaps a bit too difficult (I had to solo a few maps to get 3 stars, or 'cheese' them by playing with 2 players rather than e.g. 4), but this is too far in the other direction imo.7) The ending is incomplete. The final level hardly has any build-up and is very straightforward (also it seems a bit cramped), especially compared to the final boss of the first game. The end scene is a few lines of dialogue; I was expecting quite a bit more for the ending, even if it is just a short cinematic in the style of the opening scenes for the game.8) Throwing is inconsistent. It would be nice to see a highlight on the map of where your object will land once you throw it.In general, the levels seem to have fewer good gimmicks and are less inspired than in Overcooked 1. Even though the first game had some misses (e.g. the ice and lava levels), there was a lot of variety and I was willing to overlook a few bad levels. Overcooked 2 doesn't have many terrible levels (except maybe 5-3 or 6-2), but is definitely lacking in overall variety, particularly with the recipes. I'm surprised things such as the flame thrower from the holiday DLC didn't make it back to this game.All in all, the core game is still solid, but there are a number of QoL and polish issues that make this game closer to an 7/10 rather than the 9/10 I'd give the first. Fix the bugs and improve the netcode and I'd say the game is a 8.5/10. Not quite as good as the first but still worth a purchase.

author: P
review: A bit of a let down. New mechanics are introduced haphazardly and nothing differentiates the different chapters apart. Difficulty is also all over the place; one level takes us 2-3 tries to get 3-star rating, then the next level we get twice the score needed first try. It's as in no work whatsoever went into balancing the game.The first game had a much better progression of mechanics and balance. This sequel costs twice as much and is honestly half  as polished. Honestly the only thing it does better is online support. So unless you really need to play with a remote friend, I would just recommend playing the first one instead.

author: FixxxeR
review: This game is everything a party game should be. Frustrating. The catalyst for arguments. Rewarding and challenging. This is a classic 'spinning plates' type of play that's scales up and up and up.My only gripe with it is that some of the levels stop the 'flow' of the game, by putting obstacles in your way that prevent you from moving or performing an activity - I sort of think that at all points in time during a level, I should have to do 'something' even if its not the thing I wanted to do exactly - some levels miss this mark and you end up literally watching the clock tick away while you wait for a platform to appear. The best levels are the ones where its simple - nothing is moving around or floating - and its just you and your mates cooking against the clock, and the only reason why you fail is because your best simply isn't good enough, rather than you were blocked by a level script for 60 seconds.

author: nablet
review: Is not really like other games the average gamer is familiar with.It's not a Battle-Royale game it's not Massively Multiplayer and some may say it relies heavily on co-op or being a party game.However even in single player you can have a different but equally as fun experience.Just keep in mind that the graphics may be cartoon-ish and the game might be childish but it still tests your reflexes and gives you an adrenaline rush in it's own way.Overcooked 2 is an arcade-y cooking oriented  fast-paced top-down view..err game.The idea is you get certain recipes that you have to make in an extremely short time and some recipes require ingredients that have multiple stages of being processed and that's sorta where the  leans in.In short the game is basically a fun adrenaline rush filled experience for you or one/two/three other friend(s).The game supports controllers, local co-op and distant co-op and Steam remote play which is pretty much a full house in this case.+ Fun and exciting + Additional DLCs to keep you playing+ Local and distant/online co-op- Might be potentially over-whelming or boring in single-player- Hard to get into if you're used to other "popular" games- Potentially repetitive to some people or in lengthy sessions

author: Ricky Rat
review: Overcooked 2 is a stellar sequel to Team17‚Äôs first co-op kitchen experience that builds on an already delightful formula and imbues it with even more flavors and features to keep the experience fresh.People will often say that they never knew they needed something until that something was announced, an observation that‚Äôs about at the point of triteness, but Overcooked 2 firmly fits that bill. Perfectly content with the first Overcooked after three-starring every level, the announcement for Overcooked 2 that came in June was welcome and exciting news. Knowing that a sequel for a much-loved game is in the works does conjure up some concerns about whether what made the original so successful would be built upon or pivoted to a worrying direction, but Team17 and Ghost Town Games knew exactly what made Overcooked click and brought more of that in the return to the Onion King‚Äôs domain.Bringing new recipes to the kitchen while old favorites return, Overcooked 2 presents players with more challenges than the first to diversify the food prep mayhem. From the new sushi dish to everything else players will encounter, the recipes are broken down at each initial encounter to keep new and old players on as level a playing field as possible. While you‚Äôre presented with different recipes at the start and throughout the rest of the game, you‚Äôll find that the core mechanics and co-op antics that made the first so successful thankfully still permeate the game.Having played through the entire first Overcooked game while repeating levels to obtain better scores, it does seem that this one holds players‚Äô hands less than the series‚Äô debut. The difficulty quickly ramps up quickly, not to an unmanageable level, but certainly to one that seems to be at a steeper angle than Overcooked. It‚Äôs clear that the game expects players to be familiar with the first, and though it‚Äôs hard to speak from a new player‚Äôs perspective having experience the first, co-op gameplay with an Overcooked newbie suggested that the difficulty incline wasn‚Äôt just anecdotal. After retrying the beginning levels a few times to get the hang of it, everyone was on the same page, a necessity that hopefully won‚Äôt deter new players from enjoying Overcooked 2 without prior experience.The sequel has challenges in store for new players as well though with more dynamic levels that do their best to get in your way. One of the biggest examples of the level improvements that you‚Äôll see early on is a sequence that throws you from one setting into another mid-level. A hot air balloon ride seemed like it‚Äôd ended when the balloon and the kitchen basket came crashing down to make it seem like we‚Äôd done something wrong, but it was actually a dramatic transition to a new kitchen below. There are even portals in some levels that players can either walk through or fling ingredients into to make them pop out somewhere else. If you thought the first Overcooked‚Äôs levels were creative with players eventually cooking in space (expect more intergalactic challenges here), you‚Äôll find that Overcooked 2 provides a fresh set of memorable levels ranging from swamps to mine shafts, all with fireballs, moving structures, and other obstacles looking to delay your progress.The throwing mechanic is one of Overcooked 2‚Äôs most notable changes, the other contender being the online play that now connects chefs across the world, and it‚Äôs far from a gimmick. It‚Äôs a helpful tool when every second counts, but it‚Äôs also not option. Players will find that many levels force them to throw items to one another, if not to obtain a higher score than simply to get a passing one. Overcooked isn‚Äôt a game where you‚Äôd do something and think ‚Äúthat was a great play!‚Äù but Overcooked 2 allows for that feeling of success by tossing and catching ingredients in time to complete an order.Co-op is still core in the new Overcooked game, and that‚Äôs something that both helps and hinders it. While games shouldn‚Äôt necessitate that you play with friends for them to be enjoyable, Overcooked 2 is simply more enjoyable when played with others. Going solo is still a viable option, but the premise of having at least two controllable chefs in the kitchen will always mean that having more than one player is the intended way to play. It‚Äôs simply not as much to play solo when you feel like you‚Äôre sharing a controller with yourself while still somehow operating on two different wavelengths, but the online multiplayer at least gives everyone with Internet access the chance to experience Overcooked 2 alongside someone else. There‚Äôs a new emote system in place to assist with this, and while it‚Äôs enjoyable enough to do some goofy gestures at one another or inform teammates of basic actions, it‚Äôs hardly a replacement for the teamwork, frustration, and excitement that comes with voice comms or couch co-op.Overcooked 2 will at times make returning players wish that it could‚Äôve done just a bit more with the sequel, but playing it safer is perhaps the preferred option to avoid a disappointing sophomore release. Like the first, it‚Äôs better with friends, but that also means that it‚Äôs got exceptional replayability with the experience being different depending on who you play with. Overcooked 2 ‚Äì and the first Overcooked, for that matter ‚Äì is a game that belongs in every co-op campaigner‚Äôs collection, and if Team17 ever decides to make a third, I‚Äôll happily return to the kitchen once again.

author: Pouya2010
review: Overcooked 2, at least in its first few hours, constantly displays enough freshness and, more importantly, exciting and lovable challenges.A large part of the attractiveness of the game's gameplay comes back to its detailed and balanced environments in most of the minutes.Unlike the co-op mode, the fun in the single-player gameplay of the work slowly disappears in the short term.The multiplayer gameplay of the game in local mode and in friendly groups is many times more enjoyable than its online mode for two reasons.Strengths+ Intelligent design of steps.+ Fully satisfying artistic graphics.+ Exciting and attractive music.+ Tangible and excellent ascending course of challenges.+ Support for different modes locally and online.weak points- The lack of balance in some environments.- Weakness of the players' online communication system.- Overcrowding of the image in multiplayer experiences.Conclusion :Overcooked 2 is one of those seemingly small but respectable video game products that create every single part of them with an effort to entertain the audience. The game uses a gameplay full of different challenges, eye-catching and attractive environments, and of course, music that will satisfy every player. Made by Team17 studio, the game is not without flaws. But in many minutes of its experience, you will have so much fun and if you experience it in offline co-op mode, you will laugh with your friends, that you will not find a chance to distinguish between it and perfect works in your mind.Score 8 out of 10

author: soapyyy_rag
review: As a sucker for online multiplayer games, this is a hard yes.Firstly, I have never been a lover myself for playing diner/ waitressing games. (The whole idea of the rush and mayhem of making an order and serving it). So actually enjoying this game was a big unexpected surprise for me. Secondly, be prepared to play this either in real life together, or in a voice chat if it's online play. It's practically impossible to play otherwise, as communication is key. I initially fell in love with 'Overcooked 1!', however to be honest me and my friends probably got to level 10 and everything just went downhill. For such a fun game, each levels' difficulty is bazzaringly escalated like there is no tomorrow. One second your at level 1 playing the introduction, and the next you've lost your voice and your best friend. Unfortunately (or should I say fortunately) to say we never picked up from where we left off. This is where 'Overcooked 2!' comes into play.The progression in the difficulty of levels was just french kiss! The amount of times I have successfully pleaded for my friends to get this game should be a crime. Yet it did not fail to please anyone. So a happy crime :) The tutorial level is such an easy and great way to expose you of what is to be expected. It's so easy to learn and master the fundamentals of the game. All levels can be played repetitively without erasing previous data (duh), so engaging with this level for every newcomer is a positive must!!! Once you have mastered a great deal of levels and have progressed through a big chunk, I would recommend playing with 3-4 players. Not because it's impossible to pass the level, but rather because the maps do become fairly more spaced out, with different work stations a mile from the other. (of course not literally)In stating that, it's also great with playing with just an extra person or two, as the scores for the levels change and adapt accordingly. *If I can recall correctly*O Overall, don't let 'Overcooked 1!' fool you... just skip it and buy no.2! O Everyone could and should play this game! No matter how you would consider your level of gaming.O It really encourages you to learn how to communicate effectively and efficiently among your co-players.O Because who doesn't want to make a fake pizza, sushi, fish and chips, burger, dumplings, salad (questionable), etc. O Oh and you can throw food too. Ingenius. O Washing dishes? You got me in the first half not gonna lie. O Who let player 1 drive around on the map? O Lost my best friend to a shrimp and some rice.To find out more.... get the game :)*This is merely a review to show my passion and love for this game. I hope the message is conveyed half decently, and that this review sells the game to you!*

author: sveyr
review: 4/10 - More like Undercooked! A deceptively marketed, gimmicky, overly short step backwards. Stick to the original outside of a deep special. = Intro = A big fan of the original, the wife and I have dozens of hours into it. Was extremely excited for the second one to the extent that we preordered it.= Gameplay =Make sure you have a gamepad. This is *not* keyboard friendly.The core mechanics are the same as the original. Lots of new gimmicks in each level compensated by a very low 3 star score required. This results in a game that is both more irritating and less challenging. I remember some levels in the original that took me and the wife upwards of a dozen tries and we still had a blast. There were perhaps 3 levels that took us more than one or two tries, and we were glad to be done with them as these levels felt like we were working against each other. One in particular had a purple shimmering background that physically hurt my eyes. A wildly inconsistant difficultly level. The game is mostly very easy compared to the original, aside from a few extremely annoying levels. The final boss was an extreme letdown - we 3 starred it on our first try.Tone and theme constantly waffled. Rather than having 'worlds' like the first game, you jump from theme to theme and back again on a per level basis at random. This makes the entire game feel samey, while the original had a unique theme and gimmick each world.The multiphase levels seen in the previews are cool, but there were about 3 of them the entire game and I felt a bit cheated. The vast majority are just one area.After finishing it, we are battling to even remember the levels that gave us difficulty.The hub is also bizarre, with no rhyme or reason - finding switches feels like needless busywork and padding on an already thin game. Constantly having to go back to the middle to progress the story became a chore. We blazed our way to act 6, beat the multiphase 'boss' level and were expecting a final epic act involving the zombies to unlock. The game then just...ended.= Graphics and Audio = Graphics are pleasant and bright and the variety of chefs is cool. Audio is solid with a few catchy themes. Nothing wrong here.= Story = Meh. Compared to the charm of the original, we now have a disjointed, random trip through a bunch of unconnected levels with an overarching but NEVER SEEN 'zombie' theme and then a 'final boss' where we don't even see the zombies! = Value = Poor. There is far less content and enjoyement here than the original game for about triple the price. This feels like a studio mandated product rather than the lovingly crafted masterpiece of the original.= Overall =+ Core gameplay is still fun+ Multiphase levels are cool+ Cute chef designs- Overly short- Gimmicky- Overpriced- Multiphase levels are rare- No consistency between levels and themes- Overly easy aside from a few irritatingly hard levels- Lame climax= Final verdict: This is a sad and disappointing followup to the amazing original game. It feels like something the developers didn't want to make. Wait for a deep special if you are interested, or better yet - just go through the original again.

author: DarkDagger
review: Game itself was OK, but there were multiple issues with player's experience.1. 3 star was too easy for most stages. It was way more challenging in Overcooked1, but was boring in this expansion.2. 4 star was almost impossible in 2 players mode, for most stages. My wife and I were able to achieve 4 stars in some stages, but most of the stages were basically impossible for only 2 player. This was funny because threshold for 4 stars are all same across 2p, 3p and 4p mode, which is not reasonable at all.3. Multiple bugs that affect player experience. One major bug is that when dropping a plate, it does not drop onto the table, but instead in a weird position that cannot be picked up again. Also in some scenario it could be dropped into a corner that cannot be reached. 4. I really like the sound of the onion king "ba bi ba bi bu wa wa wa wu", but it was missing in this expansion. Hopefully we could have it back. 5. Back to stage design, nothing about stars, but some stages was totally disgusting. I remember there was one stage that the in lava keep changing, which is so thin that we have to be so careful when delivering things. I guess it could be better when using keyboard to move, but for controller, a slight offset on sticker could cause a suicide in lava. This is not a good design at all. There was another stage that we control a platform in the middle to make burittos, but for 2p mode it was too much mess because one of us have to keep dropping, picking and control platform. However in 4p mode it was just as easy as nuts because one can just stay controlling the platform while others could just do their own thing. There were 3 sets of cooking material on each side(3 pots, 3 plates, 3 pans), so it was just one for each. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TL;DR1. Star requirement for 2p, 3p, 4p are same, which is ridiculous.2. Some kitchen were not well designed.3. Bugs4. No sound from NPC.

review: My best friend and I played this on the Switch two months ago, and we were doing a level where we cook pizzas. We kept sending out amazing pizzas and getting no points for them, so we fail the level. Her and I are raging that we have to do the level again. About 30 seconds into redoing the level, I put a pizza in the oven and realize that we didn't put a single pizza we sent out to the customers in the oven the first time we tried the level.  Needless to say, we absolutely ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• died in a fit of laughter on her couch for a good 5 minutes.Only issue is that you may have a hard time finding a random person to play a game with in matchmaking. The other issue is that there is no in-game text chat, so if you don't know what you're doing, you're bound to piss the guy you're playing with off. author: Xilks
review: Are you ready for some crazy kitchen culinary action? With the improvement of multiplayer mode, Overcooked 2 is an exciting, occasionally frustrating, and hilariously enjoyable co-op cooking game. The levels and themed and unique. There are many unlockable characters, a bunch of recipes to complete, and creative obstacles to make the job even more challenging. There is no combat in this game. Well, not in the traditional sense. Feel free to throw food at your friends or shove them into the water or off a cliff. The goal in this game is the race against the clock and to make as many orders as possible and send them out from the kitchen. Overcooked 2 is a huge improvement from Overcooked. The option of multiplayer was there in the first game, but the option for online multiplayer allows this game to be accessible by friends and family who may not live close enough to one another to play. [Or with the recent pandemic, where it may not be safe to play with other in close quarters.] The accessibility to play this game is there. The player can choose to use a controller or the keyboard and mouse and of course you can switch up the command layout any way you‚Äôd like.I simply adore this game. It‚Äôs good, wholesome fun where you and your friends will be tossed into some insane situations and laughter and screaming will ensue. The levels are beautifully crafted, and the music does not get old. I would recommend that if you buy the game, give a bit of a test drive and then maybe give the DLC a go if you find yourself really enjoying the game. The DLC is more challenging at times, but you gain access to new playable characters and new recipes. All in all, I found the game and the DLC it to be well worth it. [Check out the most recent FREE DLC update!] Do it for Kevin! Achievement Hunter‚Äôs Note: Some achievements are story based, others are PVP based, and many are level completion based. Take a quick glance over the potential achievements to have a vague guideline of what things you need to be on the lookout for. Achievement Acquisition Difficulty: Easy+

author: ùíÆùëíùíæùìÄùí∂ùìáùí∂
review: Overcooked 2 is an upgrade over its predecessor in many ways. Immediately, I can tell that more attention had been put into how the game looks, functions, and feels. It looks and plays considerably better and smoother than the last one with animations, visuals, and overall performance getting improved. For me, the most noticeable and welcoming of these changes has to be the increase in numbers of level variations. The locations of which you'll be visiting are now much more varied and will be taking you to all manners of environments including underground, air, lakes, urban centers, and so much more. Some will even have level transition bringing you to multiple locations in the same game. It's awesome, and I wish the developers would've done more of them because of how fun they are to play. Aside from that, if you're a fan of verses and arcade mode, there's even more content to gorge down on and enjoy, all with their own beautiful and unique levels to experience long after you're done with the main campaign. There is simply a lot to love about Overcooked 2, and I highly recommend anyone who's in the market for a new fun co-op game to definitely check it out.

author: {SSA} **Emma**
review: Really fun game. Not much of a challenge though. After how hard it was to get 3 stars on every level in the first overcooked, I am a little shocked and very disappointed that I was able to get 3 stars on all the levels, including the Kevin levels, first try for almost all of them and the boss fight was so easy.  The gameplay, I would say is definitely improved. The 'throw' button is very handy. I also like the online part, but with no voice communication, 4 random chefs in a hard level is very difficult.  Plus it is a little hard to find chefs to play with. I very much hope there is going to be a DLC soon with more levels. I was so excited for this game and waited months for it to come out. I wouldnt call 6hrs of gameplay = almost $30AUD.  Sadly..Gameplay etc I give it an 8/10Difficulty I give it a 3/10I do recommend it, but not if you are looking for a challenge.

author: Dewolf
review: This game is only fun if multiple players are involved: The more players the more fun. Therefore, It's difficult to understand why on PCs with split keyboard control the multiplayer mode is not properly implemented. We are three local players at the same place and the only way to play together is to buy three versions of the game and play online via internet. This is because it's not possible to play with more than 2 local players and if additional online players are added all other local players are removed. That is nowhere stated in the game description and i guess only applies to pure split keyboard controls (but also to the Christmas update). Secondly, other online players (not personal friends) can only be found through steam discussion groups. There's no in-game player matching and search engine. For me this is a joke, in particular, for a multiplayer game.The game itself is great - it's just too expensive to play it with family.

author: SuperCrunchy
review: As someone who spent many hours playing the first Overcooked, the sequel is quite fun with interesting new mechanics and level design, but it's simply too... simple! Previously, you had to have a perfect or near perfect run to achieve three stars but now it's possible to clear the three star score by several hundred points each time. There were only a couple levels which took more than a few goes to get three stars and when we finished the final level with several minutes left on the clock, it was definitely more "Oh, that's it?" as opposed to the euphoria from finishing the first game. The charm of the original game was the frustration of missing the top score due to a seemingly insignificant error and toiling away for the elusive third star but that has been ungraciously taken away in Overcooked 2.So far the expansion is promising and has been much more challenging to get three stars for each level! Overall, it's a fun game but it seems like it was designed to please the masses rather than to present a challenging gaming experience.

author: GilliganAU
review: Overcooked 2 is a fantastic multiplayer co-op party game, either remotely or in the same room. It's whacky and super low stakes (nothing is at risk except the food orders), the art design is delightful, and the replayability is high.

author: Linio
review: I'm gonna go "nay" here because of the "2" in Overcooked 2.Overcooked 2 brings no addition to the first game whatsoever, at least gameplay-wise. It brings the multiplayer online which was not something I was looking for (couch coop is the way to play this game to me), but apart from that, zilch.The graphics are practically the same, the option to "throw" stuff is more confusing than anything else, and the mechanism around it are underwhelming, and, having played the complete game in less than ten hours, I can say with confidence that the game is boring.To players from the first one, the levels propose no challenge whatsoever (we gained 3 stars all the time with no coordination, and the addition of the fourth star is a bad attempt to offer more difficulty), no evolution nor main theme (on levels from the same group you will do burgers, then sushi, then pizza... and do it again on the next round), lowering even the bar in terms of immersion or at least lore.Some ideas just fall very short, like the "new and improved" map which brings... well nothing.The game is bugged at times (some items end up in the void of the inbetween two squares), which is not a very big issue but still, for a second opus, it's worth noticing.In fact I'm thinking the addition of the multiplayer is the root cause of the letdown that is to me this game, seeing as I'm assuming they lowered the difficulty to cater for the online multiplayer aspect of the game, and that the bugs must mainly come from there.I'm always bewildered by the praise made around second opus of games like this one. The first one deserved it, but this one gives no reason to be bought, and it needs to be acknowledged.Go buy the first one.

This does not require teamwork or effort at all...Only this reason makes me not want to play it.2. Playing Story mode online only gives achievements such as unblocking new characters to the host. Which is pretty bad. Makes me and my buddies not want to play online...well at all. It loses purpose.Other than that the game is good, but like I said before. These flaws are so big that I would not buy the game again and I would not reccomend it at all.Hopefully these are things that can be patched in the future.
