author: Washed Up Gamer
review: Overcooked! 2 offers a unique arcade-like couch coop experience, adding innovative twists here and there to the age-old, screen-sharing fun when you'd invite your friends back from school to play videogames.  A colourful blend between a fun challenge, terrible food puns and adorable art style--Overcooked! 2 certainly serves up a succulent dish of friendly fun.  Sadly, like a game of Monopoly, it just isn't fun when you're the only one playing.Overcooked! 2 focuses on testing how well you and your team cooperate with each other.  Gameplay consists of orders rapidly being placed, which the team must complete and serve up to earn points which accumulate into a rating out of three stars.  When the whistle blows, you and your friends will be scrambling to meet order after order by preparing meals--mincing the beef; chopping fish; mixing aforementioned ingredients with flour into a mixing bowl... Whilst teams which function together too slowly will find themselves failing orders, overzealous teams will, on the flipside, fight against becoming overburdened as the food overcooks or equipment breaks.  The time-sensitive mechanics of the game gives weight to each player's actions and the game's creatively-designed levels prevent simple routine and muscle memory from diluting the difficulty of the levels.  One mistake after the other my sous chefs and I found ourselves in hilarity amidst a nightmare of problems we couldn't even hope to solve in time.  These moments, I find, are unique in games such as Overcooked! 2, whilst I would have been expected to be frustrated at minor screw-ups and mission failures with other more serious games; the inherent lighthearted music and art of Overcooked! 2 just makes you feel happier overall.  It's a difficult phenomenon to explain, but it's one which can surely be felt.  After all, comedic tension is rare in all forms of media nowadays, from videogames to films.  I certainly did not expect Overcooked! 2 to be so hilarious and so entertaining.However, the game is certainly not without flaw.  Whilst I understand the rationale behind the decision to allow players to instantaneously throw ingredients at maximum power, without any middle ground as to how far the ingredient should be thrown.  Personally, I enjoyed the additional lighthearted chaos that throwing items everywhere could wreak, though I'd imagine the lack of additional control over the palyer's character could cause some frustration among those more competitive than myself.  Furthermore, the detected area of activation for some in-game items can be deceptively long yet deceptively short at the same time.  Overcooked! 2's arcade-y and intentionally forgiving controls sometimes end up fighting with the player, as instead of dropping it through a shaft for the next player in the team to pick up, I found myself placing the bowl onto the nearby boxes and tables next to me instead--something which grew nervously frustrating at times, to the point where I would have lost my mind, had it not been for the game's soothing ukelele-based soundtrack.My initial impression of Overcooked! 2 on the PC was soured by the game's single-player.  It slowed some things down, giving the sole player two chefs which they could alternate between, straining my multitasking capabilities.  Though it seemed slightly innovative and interesting, it completely failed to captivate me with its charm like it did the second I hopped into a party with my friends.  I can't blame the developers for trying to at least make it work for singleplayer, though; unlike how many other couch-multiplayer games out there which can't even be played in singleplayer.  Thus, the effort is still there and I believe the developers should be commended for at least giving players the option to play alone, in a game marketed and designed entirely for couch-coop multiplayer with friends.  Lastly, need I mention that the game is quite a great port and works very well with the keyboard despite being designed with the controller in mind?  Great work across the board!Overcooked! 2 is a simplistic port from the console, and evidently was designed with a controller in mind.  I didn't expect any fancy graphics or shading like I do from triple-A titles, and even so I was impressed by how nicely Overcooked! 2 manages to pull of its art style.  The game doesn't look like anything much and that's a good thing.  Those of you out there with the simplest of laptops should find running this game a breeze thanks to its minimalistic and cartoonish approach, much like its predecessor.  The game looks great enough, without bells and whistles that overcomplicate its accessibility.Finally, there's that great, glorious lighthearted and fun soundtrack that numbs the frustration and anger.  The mixers may be broken, the customers may be getting feisty with their orders, the kitchen may even be on fire as well; but the genius with the ukelele strums away and everyone just laughs the troubles away.  Overcooked! 2 provides no shortage of these moments of juxtaposed havoc and serenity, leading to a very enjoyable experience for the whole party.Overcooked! 2 is simply the cutest party game I've ever played, combining simplicity with the complexity of teamwork, this game will test you and your friends.  It's just a shame that it, like all other party games, doesn't really shine as a singleplayer game.  But then again, why would you be getting it if you're the only one?Overcooked! 2 offers hours of fun for a reasonable price-tag, and is a must-have if you already have a group of friends who are planning to purchase, or have already purchased it.+Low system requirements+Reasonable price+Great fun with friends+Lighthearted and tongue-in-cheek design and atmosphere+Many levels+Great soundtrack-Singleplayer is a bit boring, but that's expected-Only truly shines if you manage to convince your friends to buy it with you

author: Alphadoriest
review: The original was pure un-feta-ed (is that how you do it?) fun that appeared unbeatable on co-op. It's back, confident and emboldened with much of the same antics of 2-4 player cheffing in the least practical kitchens you'll have ever seen. Only this time, the obstacles are more devil-licious, there's now a fourth star for the hardened, battle-scarred unicorn chefs out there, you can throw and catch ingredients to your heart's content, and online invite-only and public arcade sampling of levels is now finally available for the friendless of us out there. The main strength of Overcooked was always that its central puzzle was very much a human puzzle. Pure cooperation. Achieving the flow present in actual kitchens through allocating rolls (yep), synchronising your timing, ironing out inefficiencies, and becoming one mind, one machine. That's why I always thought the later levels of even the original, wonderful as they still were, actually worked to undermine in many ways the main function of the levels, the human puzzle as it were. They'd insert too many flow-stopping complications that would make a single dish hard to serve. Overcooked 2 doubles down on that with new mechanics like lever-controlled platforms and oldies and goodies like the slowly swaying platform - artificially eating into your efficiency. But if you were to remove such obstacles, what could designers do to ever mix things up? I think the key is to allow efficiency and flow to always be achieved. For instance, there can still be some optimisation around a swaying platform given there is enough for the two parties to do either side and its movement frequency is just right. Having everyone stuck on a massive single platform controlled by a lever, however, seems like opting to kill the machine and making the one mind just the guy operating the lever. It's telling also that such a level is nigh on impossible without voice communication in online arcade mode. Other levels have an instant, unspoken understanding of the division of labour. That said, a nifty addition for online is definitely the radial communication for a quick nudge - even if I find the only one I really use is 'washing up' over and over again. It's like being at home.The narrative premise in the rising of the unbread certainly earns its due laughs, but knows it's but narrative justification. Like the original, it's an abrupt end, and perhaps less climactic this time. Less explosion and more an onion telling you you've done a good job. It's not a big deal, but perhaps a little something to sweeten the deal at the end rather than evoking bad arcade game practice would've been better. I still love the overworld. Driving around is still a joy, and with additions like optional attainable levels, platforms, etc, it's only been improved.Completing the game would then grant access to the four stars new game plus, though. Something which should go some way to simmer down veterans with some extra challenge. As a recent update, it shows the devs are committed to delivering this dish well-cooked. I can only give them a full four stars in turn for that.The single biggest boon to my experience with the game is the addition of the arcade online mode. Since I haven't been able to get as much local play going as I would have wanted, this has been invaluable. It's well-populated and you can get a lot of sessions in. Instead of selecting from a menu of specific levels, you choose the themed chapters and have it randomised from there. It would be nice if there was some ability to request specific levels or even replay one you just botched. I assume there's no voice chat since I didn't encounter it. Despite my complaints that some levels seem like they demand it, I think this was the best option. It keeps play thoroughly uninterrupted by bellowing and frustration and preserves a non-toxic environment. It's an excellent time, but online drop-in of strangers to get through some of the campaign would have been doubly marvellous. I suppose I could seek out people through something like Discord if need be, or ask the girlfriend nicely one more time. Like its predecessor, this remains co-op in its purest form - largely because it still plays off people self-organising and optimising so perfectly. It carries over all the presentational joy and fun whilst adding many quality of life changes - the biggest of which, online arcade, is a game changer (this game, that is). The recent post-launch addition of new game plus means it will dominate your chosen party's time for even longer and should work to resolve difficulty concerns. The new more impeding level design elements and mechanics can seem like a downgrade in how they interrupt flow, but this is still the well-cooked experience you know and love.

author: Sushimon!
review: Overcooked 2 is a great game to play with friends which will probably end with everyone threatening to end friendships and cut each other's throats out. It's cute, it doesn't take too much time to clear, and there's a certain level of replayability  (i'll explain why it's only certain later) as there are other modes besides story that you can have fun with. It's the type of game you can pull out during a group sleepover and everyone will have a great time whether playing or watching (unless everyone has already played the game, then it'll probably be dull :/)Other than that, there are several problems I have with it. Read on if you want to find out what I feel are the cons of this game.Firstly, why the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• do I have to drive a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• bus around the map to get to  the level I want to play? I don't get it. Then there's switches that you need to press to activate certain ramps to get to certain stages. Like just why? It's unnecessary and adds 0 value to the game.Secondly, why the heck is there a storyline? Nobody cares. It's poorly written (something about undead bread called unbread), and honestly having to drive all the way back to spend a few seconds rapidly hitting enter to skip through the onion king's speech is  a waste of time.Third, some level designs are HORRIBLE. I understand that they are trying to shake up the gameplay and introduce more chaotic moments but some of the elements added are just ridiculous. Its really just there to piss you off.Fourth, story mode feels really short. Thank god I bought this during Summer Sale on half price. There's only 6 words, each with 6 stages and 8 kevin levels which brings the total story mode stages to 44 levels. That took about 8 hours to clear. Of course, you can purchase the DLCs for more content, but judging from the reviews, it's pretty meh.Fifth, other than the stages the developers have included, and other modes such as versus, there's really nothing else to do once you have played the game for... lets' say 20 hours. The game will be fun for a while, but once you have tried everything multiple times? It will become dull. It would be nice if they could implement community created levels, but that would probably harm the DLC sales so... :') Overall, I still think Overcooked 2 is a decent game to have some chaotic fun. Just make sure you pull some of your friends in or set up Steam Remote Play for co-op. Singleplayer is hell. Oh and don't play it too much. It gets dull after a while.

review: Personally I prefer Overcooked 1 with levels design but 2 is still a good game, you can now toss food, more recipes and chefs, and online multiplayer (I know there's Parsec for 1 but it doesn't feel natural to me, and story mode progress only goes for the host, 2's progress will be fixed for every player soon), though I think online multiplayer can be improved with being able to limit the numbers of players so there won't be long waiting time every session under 4 players, and being able to pick specific level if waiting time has to be that long. Also versus mode 2 vs 1 is just bullying, opponents can steal stuff or squeeze and push your unused character.Around first dozen of stages are definitely easy to get 3 stars for solo as many claimed, tossing obviously makes it easier too instead of running back and forth in first game, the stages get harder and more complexed after that.If I have friends to play with locally I'd just get Overcooked 1 which sadly I don't (unless tossing and more recipes and chefs are good reasons for you), though I still think Overcooked 2 is pretty fun, and maybe get that on sale if you worry there's not enough content.

author: Maengune
review: While I still had a few hours of fun playing this, beating the sequel's story campaign really made me miss the first game so darn much. I find the lack of level differentiation a total let down because I was a big fan of the ice / space levels in Overcooked 1 (because, yes, sliding to your death is still a fun mix when you're hyperfocused on doing something). Difficulty has been generally toned down from something formidable to downright aggravating and thanks to the point multiplier, you can easily get (3) stars in one try. I expected more things happening on the main map since they introduced switched but things got repetitive too which is a bummer. But the biggest let down for me was the last few levels. The last boss of Overcooked 1 tooks us almost 5 hours trying to polish our teamwork, so I anticiapted that same exciting feeling. Sadly, the game blew it off with the most underwhelming finisher. It went like "Oh. Wait? That's it?".Overcooked 2 is still a nice co-op game that challenges you and your friends but the sequel is a half-baked comparison to its predecessor. If you're planning on getting this, I'd recommend that you buy the first game instead.

Loved both games. This one exceeded my expectations. Found a balance between strategy and skill that makes it easy to swap in new users at a party. Story is hilarious. author: Green
review: This game is amazingly fun!  My friends and I were pleasently surprised by the improvements of Overcooked 2 on the first game. The game has much more polish than the first as well.  If you couch co-op you MUST own this game.  There is no better time to be had with 3 friends.  :)

author: Silverdrone
review: I hate to give a negative review for this game, but it's hard not to...First of all, hats to the devs in adding online multiplayer, it was a glaring missing option from the first and although I do not use it, it was a perfect fit for this game.Otherwise there are too much problems and omissions here to recomend it, specially if you played the first game:It is too easy to get 3 stars (at least with 2 players), most of the time we would get it at the first attempt, except for 3 or 4 levels which took one or two retries. I play with my SO and even without much strategy and adapting as we go, it was too easy. Now there is an update which include a 4th star on each level, but as soon as we fired the game, we though this was a mistake. See the progression for the 1-1 world: 20 - 160 - 300 - 2650, it's an incredible jump. Our first playthrough of the level was around 1400. We managed to reach 2165 after half hour of attemps, with an 'almost perfect' riskless execution, which for me is the fun way to play this game. This means dashing whenever possible, no downtime for either player and delivery of 43 dishes in order, so the tip bonus can stack as much as possible. Even so, it was impossible for us to even glimpse what we could do to reach it without using mechanics which require perfect execution. Is it possible? Probably, but this means we have to work in other ways to achieve it, which leads me to my next point.The controls are improved from the first version, but even so they still a little clumsy. The dash has an internal cooldown which is hard to time, you either spam the dash button or try to time it and don't dash sometimes (a little buffer for dashing would go miles in improving it's feeling). Grabbing and dropping items always leave something to be desired, since they are not precise enough most of the time. There is a distance which you can do the actions but sometimes the action does not fire. Other times, it does something you do not want to, like you are on top of a treadmill but it decides to drop your item on the table on the side of your character.With the imprecise commands, it's impossible to execute perfectly on your plans, which sucks the fun out of trying the challenging 4th star scores, specially with a non hardcore gamer like my SO.Tossing was a good idea and mechanically it works nicely, but it doesn't work properly with my next point.I don't like the physics being applied to the floor items instead of the locking to the table ones. To reach high scores, you are required to toss items, but then some rules about the item interaction change. For example, if a tomato is on the counter and you bring the plate to it, it will put the plate and the ingredient together. If the tomato is rolling on the floor and you try the same mechanic, you will drop the plate, then you have to pick up the tomato to be able to put it on the plate. It does not make sense for the mechanic to change because of the environment, it should be consistent if they expect you to reach such high scores.Unexcusable, it does not need to reach Mario Maker levels of sharing but the only thing I want is to be able to face different challenges endlessly (or really easy flows for an extended period of time). Creating custom levels would solve all the longevity issues of the title. The game has more levels than the first, but a lot of them lack personality. In two players, the first raft level (with the item tossing) is ridiculous. One player is on one raft with the cutters and... that's it, no access to the other side. The other player has to collect the ingredient, toss to the other side, receive the cut ingredient, put on the plate and serve. WHY does the game didn't put at least some of the ingredients on the other side is beyond me. Being able to toss the plate would also solve a lot of those limitations (so the delivery could be on that side) but the devs chose to allow only ingredient tossing (which is OK, but limits those kitchens).The map on the first game was charming (and useless). The map on the second one has a useless mechanic to activate some buttons to raise platforms. They are always obvious and add nothing to the game. So it's even more useless.I love the idea of the game, but I hate the implementation of the same problems of the first without all the charm which made it an instant classic at my home. If they reduce the complexity of the 4th star, I will gladly play it and the game goes from a NO to a Maybe.Overcooked 1 continues to be a more balanced game with more engaging kitchens and scores with are on the perfect sweet spot of difficult enough but never too far away to seem like it is impossible, so I recommend you play the first game instead.

author: Tamloo
review: Game isn't any different from the first one with the exception of adding online multiplayer. Either way, I used Parsec to play with a friend so I cannot speak to the online multiplayer implemented inside the game itself. At it's core, the gameplay is a lot of fun and I highly recommend it. The game took me roughly 7 hours to complete with one friend and we both agreed that purchasing the DLC wouldn't be worth it for the price as it just adds new levels. Sure, there are more items to make but I've seen more content packed games for cheaper. However, I do hear only the host needs to purchase the DLC which is nice.No matter what, I would wait for the game to go on sale. No need to purchase at $25. I would probably put this game at no more than $10.

author: Peep[A]
review: Great cooperative game that will sometimes get on your nerves. Good to validate your personal relationships. Not much fun for one player only. Haven't played online, I think the couch multiplayer is much more fun because in this game you really need to communicate - if you don't, you loose and end up upset.

author: ‚ô•Tyknighter
review: Overcooked 2 is a fun cooking sim that is better played with friends rather then on your own as the game is going to get crazy and it's so much fun to yell at your friends at all the wacky things that can and will go wrong in this game.  The story starts out with the Onion King as he has tasked you and a few other chefs if you have them to make food for everyone in the Onion kingdom and on your way you will come across new ways to make food and new challenges for you and your friends to over come.The gameplay is simple yet it can get crazy as you need to cook food, make sure the food is prepared in the correct order, deliver it to the hungry people, wash dishes, take out anything that catches on fire, and fight the time limit.  And having a friend does help out a ton and the game is more fun with friends as you get to yell at them for messing up and they just might do the same to you as well but that's the fun with Overcooked 2.  The graphics are cartoony and and wonderful and every area you go is different as you go into China Town, in the sky, in a mine, on the sea, you name it.  The characters are all cute and you feel bad for them as they are trying their hardest to cook and get the job done and the only thing they get is more orders to cook food but they get tips at the end of the day and that's your score so make sure to get the order right as you want to try and get 3 stars on the level.  Overcooked 2 even with it's simple gamplay is challenging but it is really fun to play with friends and it's best played that way, so grab a friend and get cooking as it's going to get crazy and rememeber, throwing food is this game is fun.

author: Rhysandie
review: The throwing mechanic made this game easier than the first game. It also saved a lot of ingredients' life (but killed many a chef).The 3-star requirement for this game is ridiculously easy (just 5 orders to complete the level, really?) Thankfully, the devs patched it up by adding a 4-star requirement to each level. They have also adjusted the 3-star requirement for subsequent DLCs to be a bit more challenging.I really hope they eventually fix the freeze that happens whenever someone falls off the map for the first time after the game booted up. The issue has been reported, attempted to be resolved, but not fixed for a long time now.I LOVE THE FREE CHEF UPDATE (the girl pirate is so pretty)!! They added 5 free chefs to the base game, namely: 2 pirates, a shark, a narwhal, and a mermaid.

author: Winterspell
review: Clearly intended to be played with friends, single player is unfun and overwhelming.. However with friends this game is hillarious and very challenging. The bread puns were really stupid and hillarious but mostly just running around screaming about your food being on fire, running off the cliff, getting hit by a car chucking food at your friend and knocking them off. It's total chaos and if your friends don't take it too seriously it's great fun. If your friends do take it seriously.. get everyone drunk and try again! You'll probably fail the level but you'll have a blast doing so!

author: R4Z
review: After the enormous fun n joy from the first overcooked was I was so hyped that i preordered this with no hesitation but unfortunately i was disappointed since theres only bout 8 hours to complete the game and its SO DAMN EASY u get no satisfaction for completing the lvls at all.. online experience is too poor, no replayability! Just too little and shallow content for its price.. shame..EDIT (negative to positive review):After the added content to the game both free and paid DLC, the devs apparently listened to the community and did it right! waiting for the next dlc for sure

author: DeadFish.Ê≠ªÈ±º
review: I hate to left the negative review for this game. Don't get me wrong, it's still a great game to have fun with your friends. The chaotic aspect of the game is largely improved with new mechanic and features.But for those who have played overcooked! the amount of excitement just isn't there. In my opinion the level design for overcooked 2 is TOO EASY for experienced players. Me and My friend only had around 10 retry to have all normal level 3 stars. With 10 hours in, the only achievement locked is the dish washing one. Yet I have't finish the story of Overcooked1 with 25 hours on the record. You just don't have the constant "go back for more stars to unlock new level" going on there.Maybe the game decided to work more towards the competing part, focused on the arcade and versus mode. But for me a causual game like this shouldn't give me the pressure of a PVP game. It's easier to have fun in PVE and less likely to get your temper in.Wish there would be more content for this game (DLC maybe?)

author: Gollyflowers
review: Has great potential but is poorly designed for groups of 2.Got this game to play with a friend, the first few levels were challenging, but very fun, however as we moved further on it got to the point where each level was just so incredibly infuriating; one or two annoying aspects in a level is fine but honestly some of the levels are just unbearable to play. One level had a road where you could get run over, with no lights to indicate when the cars were coming, the tables moved constantly and the wind would blow you away from whatever you were preparing and into the road for you to get run over - bearing in mind that if you 'die' with food you lose it permanently. Don't get me wrong, I'm down for challenging, but I would much prefer the challenge to make the cooking process more complex rather than introduce 5 different elements at once that make it near impossible to even do one part of the process of completing a dish. It's such a shame because we were really enjoying the game (and we liked to repeat levels in order to get 3 stars) but it got to the point where every single level was more frustrating than the last until we just stopped playing. I'm sure it would have been easier with more people but if a game supports 2 players it should be able to accommodate it.TLDR: Fun at first but later levels feel like theyre designed to make you tear your hair out

author: Fontrevi
review: Being a huge fan of  there was no other option than to play this game.  is chaotic, hectic and more complex as it seems. Light colours, funny graphics look childish but you will see how it is sometimes hard to beat a ‚Äúgame for kids‚Äù.Here we have a sequel, in my opinion, of one of the best cooperative games ‚Äì . I already reviewed the original game and you can check the review out here: The Onion Kingdom is in danger again and we must defend it by polishing our cooking skills! Hmm‚Ä¶ Anyway as in the original , the story itself does not really matter here, as it is again just a background for all the fun which cooking in  provides.The game in technical aspects is almost perfect. It is not buggy, it runs really smoothly. One of the main features in  is multiplayer which works just fine: it is easy to connect and achievements are given to all the players. However only the game host can select levels/DLCs and moreover only the game host can drive the van to travel on the map :(Original  didn‚Äôt provide much in-game communication as it was intended for couch playing, however with added online multiplayer, the game provides something like that ‚Äì 6 emotion animations ‚Äì which you could use to show what you think about your companion‚Äôs action.  Unlike in  which contained only slap ability (and which was the best, I miss it so much), here the emotions are useless because you simply do not have time to use them if you are really tryharding as I did.The game provides the same joy and satisfaction of completing the kitchens.  also offers a free expansion and a few DLCs for additional price to continue the journey in the Onion Kingdom. In my experience, the game and some of the DLCs are a bit more challenging than the original  and in some ways it is not a good thing. As some levels are more frustrating and it is really easy to forget about the fun. Additionally there is a competitive mode to check who is the real professional chief among your friends and you.Speaking about gameplay, a new game-changing feature has been added ‚Äì throwing. Now you can throw the items directly to your teammate or even to a pot/cutting desk/frying pan or anything else (but I guarantee 100% rage on the diagonal aiming if you use the keyboard, so I highly recommend using a gamepad). The ability is really cool and it allows you to save some time as the dishes themselves become a bit more complicated ‚Äì in some recipes you would mix the ingredients before frying, baking or steaming. So I believe the game still remains balanced. is a great example of a perfect sequel which provides the same fun. There weren‚Äôt that many changes compared to the original game as  was a really really decent cooperative game by itself. So, whether you already played  or didn‚Äôt, it actually doesn‚Äôt matter, you can start your journey to the Onion Kingdom with either of the games :)

author: pb
review: i love cooking games and overcooked is simple enough yet has a lot of potential for chaos and it's a lot of fun with friends, and a fun challenge to try on your own too, since you're managing two people at once. it can be as casual or as competitive as you want it to be, the game isn't unbeatable but neither is it way too easy. i do wish more people played this online because the wait time for an online match can be so long sometimes. it's hard to find friends who like this game too because for some of them it reminds them too much of their work lol. but i really like this game. if you want something that's easy to pick up and something that's fast-paced, this would be a good game to try. graphics are cute too!

author: Ravex
review: Overcooked is one of my favorite co op games. Its so much fun playing it with friends and having everyone bumping in each other and making someone fall off the map and lose an order.Playing with four friends is the best if they are anything lke my friends you probably wont be able to get one star in the end but just because no one can stop laughing.When i finish the main campaing i played it with just one friend. Some maps are clearly easier with four players but that doesnt mean they are imposible. We were able to get three stars in almost every level, some requeried many retries and planning.If you are looking for a good time with friends i cant stop recommending overcooked

author: Controle Anti-Imperialista
review: When you finish Overcooked 1 among the many good things you think about game one was "wow, how creative these guys are to make the levels, impossible to have creativity for a second game". Well, they did, and they did it very well. Needless to say, how fun and charismatic this game is, the perfect option to play coop, play with family, friends, etc., but the highlight here is to do new things with the game that are different, not a repeat of the first and most of all (something they managed to do very well) is not to make the gameplay sickening. If you wanna have fun and enjoy good laughs don't think twice, go for Overcooked 2

author: xSkyuxi
review: SO. MUCH. FUN! Supporting online multi-player has really made it so much easier for friends to play with each other whether they live in the same area or across the globe. I finished my story campaign with a friend from another country and we both had such an enjoyable time screaming, shouting, and laughing at each other. The game difficulty may feel underwhelming at first, but a new challenge arises after completing the main campaign and makes the game that much more exciting and fun. I'm also really enjoying the free seasonal content being released from time to time, which has been very creative and cute. Also, as an individual with physical disabilities, having a character on a wheelchair really made me smile.Would totally recommend this for a good time :).

review: This game is awesome. 1-4 player co-op chaos. Personally, a minimum of 2 people to play the game because in single player you control 2 chefs which can be difficult to manage. I have bought the DLCs for the game which add a lot of content to the game. If you are just getting into overcooked now, I would recommend buying "Overcooked: all you can eat" which includes Overcooked 1 and 2.Can't wait for Overcooked 3

author: SerV-
review: well this game popped out in my youtube home played by some youtubers and its interesting and fun. at first glance i think this game is easy and relaxing, just cook something by following the recipe. me and my friends buy this game and it was very fun like 3/4 first level and think like "a right this game is easy" and i realize that, that was too soon. after 4-5 level later we feel that somethings doesn't right, it supposed to be fun eh? well in fact they give us hell, the moving platform mechanism starts to pop out and chaos start reigning us, either too many order received at once and confused us, too much piling up the ingredient, no one wash the plate, fall of the map, double ingredient in either oven mixer or something, level that does't make any sense to complete, and it goes harder because it just 3 of us doing 4 people job and sometimes the separated person in some static platform goes crazy and wanna die. and after we beat the original story of the game, we bought some dlc and think, this is gonna be easier right ? NOPE, it goes harder, maybe when they discuss the game one of them questioning how to make this harder, just add more moving platforms don't just side to side make it up and down, raft in the river and even DRAGONS. well after all i think that this game is great despite never play the previous overcooked tho, the game mechanics itself is good yet not great either, and for the dlc the levels are quite few and after i buy season pass why i didnt get the surf and turf and must buy it again, i confused because they say its season pass. anyway 9/10 worth playing with friends or family, ya just don't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up too much or maybe you'll have no more friends and family....kevin kills us

author: SyMPh0Ny
review: To be honest, it's the first time I choose to not recommend a game. There are a lot of reasons behind it.I have played both Overcooked 1 and 2 for a quite long time. I have got most levels 3-star in Overcooked 1, and all the levels (including Kevin levels) 3-star in Overcooked 2. Right now I'm playing for the fourth star with my friend, and I really dislike the gameplay.According to the description of the update, the fourth star appears after finishing the story, which means you have to play all the levels at least twice to get all four stars. It is extremely boring, since the levels are unchanged in all aspects, except that the target score is ridiculously high. The gameplay really sucks. In the first several levels, all you need to do is to pre-chop everything and throw it on the ground, so that you can deliver dishes non-stop to get the score. It is not how a kitchen should work. A normal kitchen should not exploit the paused time. In my opinion, the four-star levels should add more elements (e.g. slippery roads and rats in Overcooked 1) to the map to further test the cooperation, rather than to test players to push the right button again and again.Also there are more problems other than the difficulty one. There are NO achievements relative to four stars, which seems really frustrating to me. It took me and my friend almost two hours to complete the 1-1 to 1-6 four stars, but there‚Äôre no rewards at all. The only new feature of Overcooked 2 is the action of throwing. It is fun, but it also has some bugs that can ruin your whole plan. I also wish there will be some additional conditions besides the target score to get the full star, such as not dying in dangerous levels, and not cooking the dishes until the last second. It can make the game more challenging, more reasonable and also more fun. Boldly increasing the target score shows that the designers really don‚Äôt understand the game. Difficulty doesn‚Äôt matter that much, fun matters. Finally, the single player experience does not change much. It is as boring as that in Overcooked 1. I would be glad if there is a separate story mode for single player. I see huge potential in the Overcooked series, but Overcooked 2 just miss most of the points. I hope I can pre-order Overcooked 3 with confidence.

author: 2DKiri
review: I already enjoyed Overcooked and Overcooked 2 does not disappoint. It's again humorous and full of puns, fun levels AND it has multiplayer which was missing in the first one. The levels are not as challenging anymore - it's fairly easy to reach 3 stars - but after you've completed the story, you unlock the possibility to gain a fourth star in every level which seems impossible. I've seen videos of people doing it but you have to do everything perfect. I think it's a good compensation for the story being a bit too easy.

author: Regina Phalange ‚Ñ¢
review: I adore Overcooked 1 so naturally when a sequel was announced with  mode I pre-ordered and mind you that I never pre-order games. The game plays like the previous one with chaos extravaganza as you progress with more recipes. The online play is clearly why people will be drawn to this but sadly I experienced lots of bugs. My chef would stop responding to my controls and appear at later point where I instructed him to be. This happened on occasions where I joined another game and when I was hosting one too. Single mode had lag as well. Something else to keep in mind is that the keyboard plays with awkward controls, as you can't remap the keys. The game is clearly meant to be played with a controller.Overall, the game is fun but I'd advise to wait until they patch some bugs before purchasing.

review: Gonna have to not recommend this until they fix some major usability issues. You cannot transfer your save files even though the game has cloud support. Only the host has the campaign save file, so playing with other people means having to replay the whole game again. You can't swap your start location, so in imbalanced maps, a less experienced player may be stuck in the more difficult position and there's no way to switch. They added a new game + before fixing these bugs. Dev needs to reprioritize.

author: MetalBall
review: There are three types of audiences here.1) Curious players from Overcooked 1 (This is me and my gf)Overcooked 1 was a lot harder. The level design in the first game had no online co op and everyone had a shared space-- meaning there needed to be communication on who was going to play what role. I didn't beat that game because I had a perfectionist attitude and the difficulty really rolled me over. People who beat that game will probably steamroll this game because the roles are often already separated for you and have already mastered the art of splitting roles. If they enjoyed the first game, they might as well get the second one. Overcooked is a one-of-a-kind game.2) New players who play soloThis is a very different game if you're playing solo. There's no communication. There's you switching bodies and doing the work of two people with one person. It's significantly harder this way, but the scoring system (and the chopping/cooking) has been adjusted to make it doable. I hate playing single player on this because it's a lot more work. I'm sure the three stars are much more rewarding, but you know, trying to synchronize your other self with maximum efficiency AND being prepared for the next menu item is a puzzle in itself. I might've enjoyed a little more if there just wasn't a ranking at all, but being a perfectionist ruined my fun as single player. Would not recommend it.3) Players with friends with compatible work schedulesThis is the target audience. If you fall in this category, you should know this game is a must-have.Cons--I hate the weather. I hate the pitfalls. I hate falling into the water. I hated the fact that the conveyor belts switched direction randomly. In fact, I hate when my storage ingredients move around. I especially hate the wind. I found a way to dodge cars at least. Pros--I'm amazed that we beat this game. We got into a rhythm after like the third or fourth try and god I never want to play those levels again. At least the ones with any of the hate I mentioned up there. So yeah, there's a feeling of wow. We actually made a good team. I have never really felt that in any of the Mario games I've played.

author: Yamuchi Kukana
review: This game was very fun to play with my younger brother, even though we only did like 15 levels so far (As of writing this review). We thought to buy it since we saw some YouTubers play it and we thought it looked fun, and it is! I love the cartoonish art style, that's one of the reasons I bought this game. I personally I ain't into realistic graphics that much. Maybe that's because I'm a little bit into weird, funny stuff rather than serious stuff. Not that I don't like really serious games, but the funnier, the better in my opinion. Anyway, about Overcooked! 2; I didn't play the first game, so I can't really say either it's better or worse than it, but from watching YouTube, Overcooked! 2 looks more creative than Overcook! 'cause of the following reasons (for me): more creative locations, better graphics (if you're that kind of guy), and more stuff to cook. It's still the classic Overcooked! with a 2 slapped after it, with more stuff to cook really. Not much of a deal, but it's fun! So, if you have a controller (I'd recommend 2 controllers though, I find it better to play with a controller than a keyboard, but it depends on you) then give it to your friend/brother/sister/child etc. and play this game! It's awesome and fun for the whole family!NOTE: This game can be played online too, like 2 different people playing from 2 different PCs. I find it more fun to play localy though.

author: Weapioneer
review: Zany, insanity, a simple concept met with brilliant execution. The story and characters feel a little , and the cutesy graphics and music  the chaos and fun frustration this game provides, but that doesn't stop Overcooked! 2 from being an incredibly enjoyable experience with friends.The simplistic controls and adaptibility of said controls means that you can rope your dear grandmother into playing OC! 2, and that you and your sibling can share the same controller to play. The short but intense rounds trying to cook up a dish encourage awareness and keeping track of multiple on-screen elements, while coordinating in an increasingly complex and changing enviornment. Overall, 11/10 a great couch-coop game.

author: Uncle Death
review: There are no words to sum up how incredibly stressful (and fun) this game is. As someone who does not generally enjoy time-management games I was actually very impressed how the simple addition of multiplayer made this incredibly fun. Yelling "I NEED BUNS NOT TOMATOES DAMMIT" was not something I expected to ever have to do, but this game has shown me the necessity of that particular phrase. Side note: Not recommended for those with high blood pressure. Also if the customers in this game would be willing to wait longer than 30 seconds for food that'd be great. Overall, I give it an 8/10.

review: Super fun game with friendsI somehow persuaded a bunch of my friends to buy this game, we play together, and we have LOTSS of funI agree that it's pretty easy to get 3 stars on most levels in the original game, and it's much harder in the surfnturf DLCAlso I think adding the fourth star is a great solution for those who complained it was too easyAgain, super fun with friends, definitely recommend

author: i like a stick in my ss
review: The game is really fun, and it is great playing with friends. The mechanics are good, and the graphic style is compelling.But, its just not worth the full price. This game really felt like a cash-grab after the first Overcooked. They didn't add too many new things. We completed the game within 5 hours which is quite short for this type of game at this price point.Seeing how simple this game is, I don't see why there isn't a map editor, with community workshop maps based on a grid system. Or at least, why isn't there different worlds with different biomes... Imagine a desert biome, where food would decay quickly if left unattended. Or an ice biome, where one of the hazards would be that you slip on ice. This game could have been so much more. Very disappointed in the lack of new ideas and new content.Its fun, but not worth the price. Feels like recycled content.

author: amandamm
review: My friend and I spent weeks playing the original Overcooked. We got 3 stars on everything and replayed levels to 100% complete the game. We were so excited for the second one. We waited 2 months, and it took us 7 hours to 100% the game. It was so easy. Incredibly disappointed. The new levels and recipes were fun but there was no challenge, not even in the secret levels. There were only 2 levels in total that took us more than one try to get 3 stars. I was expecting twice the levels if they were going to be so easy to complete.

author: Grimith
review: This game is a great relationship tester. You and up to three other people fling yourselves into the crucible of a, uh, "kitchen." You throw ingredients over rivers, ride hot air balloons, curse at conveyor belts, and suffer a dog named Kevin in a misguided attempt to complete timely orders. I enjoyed the first game, and "Overcooked! 2" is certainly an improved version of it. There's even online co-op, and it's quite stable, but if you lose connection with the host near mission end, only the host will get credit for a mission completion. No big deal; if your squad beat it once, surely you can summon the cooperative fortitude required to do it again!That is all I can teach you. It is up to you now to defeat the Unbread. Bark.

author: HoneyCrisp
review: It is my first time playing an Overcooked! game, i got to play this one with my gf and so far we are having so much fun!!! I like the artstyle of the game, the music and sound effects are average, you don't get tired of it and the co-op gameplay is fun on itself, for newcomers to gaming it may go a little fast and controls can be confusing, we got mixed up at times (we got confused at the beginning with only the SPACE and CTRL lol) but nothing some little practice and patience can solve. I really recommend this game if you want to play with friends or significant other, if you don't, then get some friends!!!

author: Haza_
review: So far the game is fun when you play with friends. It takes practice to master the game mechanism. One sad thing about this game is when I play with online public. Most of public that I met tend to keep spamming the cussing emote when I made ONE mistake. Just ONE. I understand the frustration but I find it is not necessary to do so. It made me feel soooooo bad about it and quit the game immediately and I've encounter this so many times already. I don't understand why people can get very elitist and toxic in a game like this. Seriously chill the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out? It's not a competitive game where you compete with other teams to get highest score smh.To the new players, I don't recommend going online public. Take your time to learn and practice and play with your close friends only. Online public are bunch of elitist players that take things too seriously in a fun game. There are a few nice gamer who can take you slowly but you don't get to pair with them much.

author: PFE Dan1el
review: Stir-frying, chopping, hot dishes, these have become my daily routine in this game. Sometimes I compete with my friends, and sometimes I work with them on levels. However, the only thing that makes me feel bad is that I feel that the operation is too complicated, and it is difficult for me to control these operations. In addition, at the back, the game rhythm will become very fast, so it means that there can be no mistakes, and the hand speed must be fast. However, playing with friends will not have such troubles, so I highly recommend playing this game with friends, you will feel the joy inside.

author: snAK47
review: If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

author: samtheboo
review: Absolute blast with friends, and it works great over Steam Remote Play or just multiplayer if everyone owns the game. This game will totally stress you out, but in a fun way.There are three stars for every level, and the number of points required to get the stars goes up with the number of players. Very slight spoiler about the new game + mode:  I found  just as fun if not more fun than While you technically can, I wouldn't recommend playing alone. It's just hard because this game is really made for multiplayer, and especially four players. I've found two or four works best.Also, the DLC is great. It's just as fun as the main game and includes new elements and mechanics that made the base game great.If the game and DLC is on sale (it often goes for 50% off), it's absolutely worth it.

review: This game was a absolute blast to play and complete with my Family. Overcooked 1 was introduced to me by my wife on the switch a while ago, and I enjoyed the game so much i wanted my whole family of friends to play, and ended up buying Overcooked! 2 and Overcooked! 1 for myself and all my friends so we can all play together.The levels on 4-players was a blast and crazy fun, I played this entire game threw the story and worked on everything with my friends and family threw and threw. I can't saw how good or bad this game is as a solo play game, but as a multiplayer game its a blast, and if your going for 100% completion with a friend or family, you got 50hrs worth of time in this game, maybe even less.Highly recommend this game as a multiplayer Experience, but I can't give any review on how solo play can go. Worth the price, and the Game goes on sale quite often, so wait for a sale and get it for yourself and your family.

author: sergiokitchens
review: One time Gordon Ramsay came to my restaurant for a Sunday brunch. We were all really nervous, but he seemed like he was in a good mood and just wanted a quick meal. When his order came back to the kitchen we were shocked to see that he wanted eighteen live trout in a bowl of sake, and our best hammer. The order ticket wasn't in the handwriting of Carol our waitress either, so we think he wrote it himself. Anyway we're a seafood restaurant so we happened to be able to accommodate him. None of us went up to see what he was doing at first because we started getting really busy, until we heard customers screaming and our head chef Ronald ran into the back telling us to grab a knife. Turns out Chef Ramsay was nailing the fish to his arms and legs and smacking them together spraying fish stuff all over our guests. I've never seen a man's jaw open so wide in my life as he vomited out Carol, who I guess he had eaten like a snake, and then he crab-walked up our concrete wall and onto the ceiling where he dropped an egg sac on the ma√Ætre d' melting the flesh from his bones. Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs eyes had gone red by this point and there were flames licking up from where his hair used to be. He uttered in a voice that seemed to come from every direction at once: "WHERE IS THE LAMB SAUCE" and then he grew to the size of the room, crushing everyone who wasn't lucky enough to get out of the way. We had to close the restaurant after that, and now I know why they call it kitchen nightmares.Ôªø

Got to say I'm not a huge fan of the solo mode as you have to switch between 2 chefs which is a hassle and a bit of a nuisance (I'd rather the levels were slightly easier but you just had one chef to control). Overall, however, it is a great game to play with friends and it's lots of fun (especially when you all end up shouting at each other!) I did buy this in the Steam Winter Sale as I do not know if it is worth the full ¬£20 but if you've got a bit of spending money, then go for it!

author: lijunkangüçç
review: Very funny co-op game. Learning curve is smooth. The graphics is also good, with many attractive recipes and kitchens.One advantage is that it supports local co-op with split control on the same keyboard, so no need to buy a controller if you only want to play it locally with your significant other. Otherwise, it also supports up to 4 players, locally or online but not both. Imho, the more players, the more joyous the gameplay is. However, it seems that nowadays few players are online so it is quite rare to gather 4 players.I recommend interested players to buy the Gourmet Edition to have access to both the main game and all its DLCs (which offer more cooks, more kitchens, more recipes and new enjoyable gameplay mechanics). It takes my wife and me around 50 hours to get all the achievements. After 100% achievements, if you still want to challenge yourself, there is a 4th star to get for each level. Beware though: some levels are frustratingly difficult to get the 4th star.A little complain though: this game is not very well optimised for MacOS. The fan runs fiercely when I play it on my mac with M1, even with only 1440*900 as resolution and the lowest graphics setting.

review: Why does the second generation make me feel easier than the first generation? Or is the mentality already trained?This parting kitchen is the second multiplayer game that I have come into contact with. The style is cute but the content is. . . The difficulty is to persuade me directly, the first generation hit my scalp numb, the second generation feels much better, mainly because there are more special effects, and there is generally a transition animation at the end of each chapter (this level is generally half I can‚Äôt do anything in the other half of the time. The other half of the time is chaotic. The difficulty of the two scenes is really very different.), I use my heart. Although it can‚Äôt be 3 stars, it can‚Äôt be forced to save it from breaking up. . .

review: Overcooked! 2, a better version of Overcooked! 1, which is a great co-op multi-player game. This game is so much enjoyable when you play with your friends. It is a chaotic party game for up to 4 players where you'll have to work together to serve top-of-the-line dishes while coping with and overcoming terrible kitchen designs, bizarre situations and natural disasters. I made lots of friends thanks to the official Overcooked! Discord server, which I recommend if you have no one to play with. Otherwise, don't dare to play this game alone. It just sucks.

No matter the group I play with, Overcooked 2 has a way facilitating good-natured yelling and plenty of laughs, which in my opinion, creates the best memories.

author: bighog69
review: This game has truly changed my life for the better. I was lost. So lost. I was in school for something I wasn't interested in. My dad always said, "son, I you're going to become a financial analyst, just like your paw paw." I believed I wanted this because I love my parents and I wanted my dad to be happy. But then I found this game. And I was introduced to the world of the culinary arts. And my mind was opened. I had this big epiphany moment. I thought to myself, "why am I wasting away at my office job, that I don't really love, when I now know my passion is making sushi and three, sometimes 4 ingredient pizzas?". I knew then that I needed a career change. I cut off my entire family. I enrolled in a culinary arts program at my local college. I graduated with honours. And now I'm a line cook at a Montana's, living out my dream. And I owe it all to Overcooked 2. Thank's

author: 3P.Bunny
review: -Graphics are simple, but charming-Dialogues aren't voiced, but sounds still get a pass-Music is good, not too intrusive but keeps up with the fast gamepace-Core gameplay is fun (even tho it's not particularly challenging to reach 3 stars on overwhelming majority of the levels if you're playing duo)-Potentially unlimited (?) replayability as the fun isn't story based rather just having a blast trying to co-ordinate with friends-Going in solo, the fun-level of the gameplay drops a lot-Story is almost non-existentA great addition to your collection if you're looking for something to play with the SO or random friends popping over for a beer or two, For further info, please feel welcomed to check my thoughts

author: Cdubya1234
review: This game is very fun to play with friends. It encourages you to be able to work together in completing different types of levels, as they increase in difficulty as you progress. The game also has seasonal updates, giving you more levels to play. After finishing the game, my friends and I enjoyed the game so much that we also played some DLCs together. Definitely recommend!

author: FlipChipz
review: It was crazy fun watching my friends play this on their Switch so I picked it up and now I've played this with my wife and we could barely monitor how much time we've played because it's just so good, up to the point where we sometimes delegate when we actually cook.This is co-op at its peak. You really get the best results from playing with others and the challenges vary so it gets interesting between stages. You can just play casually or challenge yourselves in getting full stars. This isn't only limited to those with you physically. You can play online with others, now especially in these unprecedented times. Great gameplay, cutesy storyline (yes, there is!), simple graphics, easy-to-learn controls. It'd be a miss if you don't try this game out.

author: Dstomp
review: With the game's DLC all served, the free updates slowing down, and the next step for the Overcooked! series announced, now seems like a good time to write a review.Overcooked! 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece of party games. I love (almost) every bit of this game, and the game's online matchmaking makes it all worth it. Every single kitchen has some sort of gimmick to it, forcing the players to change up their strategy for each one. Dynamic kitchens, where the layout changes after some time, are always the best, but for some reason can't be played in the game's arcade mode. Either way, all kitchens are fun to play a round on. Except 5-3. Don't talk to me about 5-3. The game's soundtrack is amazing, the large amount of chefs you can pick from is great, and on top of it all, as of the time of writing, you get 5 free mini worlds, and can buy 4 great DLC worlds, adding even more of everything mentioned above.What I don't like about this game: Level 5-3. Also, the ending to the main story was very abrupt.In short, if it wasn't obvious already, I really, really like this game.

author: ∆íisherman
review: Game is amazing. I highly recommend people who like playing casual co-op games with their friends to buy this game. However, this game has a major flaw. The online co-op. I can't even enter a level with my friend without getting the "Session is no longer available" message. I had to refund since I only bought it to play it with my friend without having to use local co-op. But if you can play with a friend locally, go for it. It was an amazing game, I can't deny that.

author: Soogurt
review: I really liked the game, but felt that the campaign was a tad short. The base campaign consists of 36 levels which are pretty easy and quickly cleared (for 3 stars). During this period, it helps me to stay connected with my partner by playing this together! 4 stars are quite a challenge if you are on a 2-person team but I read online and it seems achievable. I recommend buying it during sale (it goes -50% at times) rather than paying the full original price.

author: THE REAL JOHN CONNOR
review: This is an extremely fun game to play with your significant other or friends, but most importantly with others!  When your kitchen feels like a well oiled machine: clear communication and coordination, it feels very rewarding.  My only issue is with the lag during online co-op/multiplayer.  During the quarantine, there is so much server and general internet traffic that makes playing difficult at times.  The lag makes such a great game frustrating to play at times.

author: BS004
review: Overcooked 2 is a fast-paced cooking game where you prepare, cook, and serve dishes within a time limit. It works both as a co-op multiplayer game, or a single-player game if you're up for the multitasking challenge.Overall, the game is fun to play with friends, but it is also playable on your own if you practice a bit. Patience is key, either way! Here are some extra detailed reviews about the game:‚Ä¢  This depends on how well your connection is to the host of a server. If you or the host has poor connection, the game would be unplayable for affected players. Also, there are a few glitches that may cause players to disconnect from the host.‚Ä¢  The game features some challenging obstacles and hazards that can sometimes be frustrating, but they can also yield to hilarious situations!‚Ä¢  If you care so much about your scores, you might want to keep in mind to use different save slots for your solo saves, co-op saves, etc.(I will mark this item as a spoiler because this involves a late-game mechanic)‚Ä¢

Other than that I would highly recommend this game to play!

author: Headump
review: Want a fully Co-OP party game? Overcooked 2.Hosting hangouts of 2 to 10, this silly little cooking game really puts everyone in the room on the same page: get that order out! Although only 4 people can actually play at once, getting a rotation in brings this masterpiece alive. Suddenly, the 2 guys on the couch start calling out orders, the couple on the left start managing the things cooking, and out of nowhere the whole room works together.And as a bonus (which I use to my advantage 100% of the time I play): this game is adorable and simple and thus phenomenal when you play it baked as hell. 10/10. Highly reccomend. Get the DLC too, its worth.

review: Ridiculously fun multiplayer co-op; particularly if you have a good group of friends to play in voice chat or via couch co-op with.  The slight mechanical changes from the first game, such as being able to throw things, makes a huge difference, and the whole package is just really well thought-out and fun.  I'd easily recommend it to anyone who likes multiplayer games.

author: commanderclones (Commissar)
review: Well...well...Right, listen, this isn't some fancy cooking game like Yo Cooking Mama and all that jazz, this game is serious, BREADLY serious. Being a chef ain't easy work. And here, it ain't even easy living.You'll be shouted at, made to do dishes, extolled to run across chasms of water and strange goo, forced to labour in deplorable working conditions such as mineshafts & worked to the bone like some slave in a profitable machine.But you will love it. You will love the feeling of customers rating your hard, sweaty food and you will love it when you make your site supervisor or head chef happy. Surely, there isn't any better thing in life, right? To make people happy.So get going! The damn dumplings ain't gonna cook themselves!P.S: Be nice to the Fire Extinguisher. It is your friend.

author: The Goddamn Fatman
review: Overcooked 2 is an amazing local co-op game on PC, perfect for a game-night or dorm setting. The music is fine, and the art is cute but the gameplay is very tight and fun. You can play this game very simplistically, just running to do each thing one at a time and turning them in but where it really shines is when you go for a new high score and really try to optimize everything.Compared to Overcooked 1, I think 2's levels and difficulty are not as good. A lot of/more levels in 2 are very gimmick-y and barely about the core timing management aspect but rather avoiding death pits/navigating wind/etc. 1's ice levels (and lava levels to a lesser extent) were like this but 2 really doubles down. In addition to these chaotic maps, getting 3 stars is much easier in 2. In 1, my friend and I very rarely got a 3 star on our first try and we'd have to plan for that level. In 2, we often got it on our first try, making somewhat large mistakes and still beating it by a large margin. It's not as fun when you can play poorly and still do fine.The devs added a free NG+ like mode by adding a 4th star to every level but that swings the other way and is ludicrously challenging IMO. Still, OC2 is worth it if only because of online play and the addition of a new mechanic - throwing. Throwing is a fun, skill-based/rewarding way to cut corners and shave off seconds and it feels good to dunk the steak into the frying pan. It's just too bad it's often not even necessary.

Get ready to accidentally trash a fully prepared food, drown while cooking, get hit by a car while trying to get ingredients and cry out of frustration. In a good way.  I don't know how it feels for more people but for 2, this game is really well balanced in terms of being able to achieve 3 stars on each level. And we need more DLCs.

It's called reality TV after all.This game is addictive and fun to play with friends as past time.If you're looking for a submersive experience with real battle achievements, then this game is not for you.If you're looking to better your skills as a multi-tasker and wants to be more organized in your daily lives, then this game is 120% for you.

author: Ahoge-dono
review: Overcooked 2 isn't a far cry from the first game. The only changes to gameplay being the ability to throw food highspeeds across the kitchen and the addition of a 6 recipes with burgers and pizzas carrying over from the first game. What you're really getting are 30+ new levels challenging players to run a kitchen amidst all the hilarious, zany, chaos. For those who felt getting 3 stars was easy, a free update added a 4 star difficulty challenge which requires excellent  teamwork from your fellow chefs, or coordnation if you're controlling two chefs by yourself. The 4 star challenges require near flawless playing and adds replayability to the game. Most importantly with the addition of online multiplayer, Team17 have really added to the awesome experience that was Overcooked; and though my time with the game was short, the days I've spent playing with the people on the game's official discord were very enjoyable.   I hope to come back to the chaotic fun that is this game with future DLC.

author: RedRazorWolf
review: Overcooked 2 sticks pretty closely to the formula from Overcooked 1.  It adds a few interesting mechanics like throwing food and some of the level designs are tricky.  Overall if you enjoyed the first game or are looking for a good cooperative game to play with friends, I'd highly recommend Overcooked 2.  The only downside I found was that the difficulty was rated poorly in this one and getting 3 stars seems too easy.  Pushing for 4 stars, and just getting high scores is still fun though.

author: Melli
review: I really like the idea of this game because I consider myself a task-driven individual. In that sense, it's pretty fun. The first game didn't allow for online play, so the fact that you can play with friends on the other side of the country is also a big plus. The downside is that the net coding seems to be a bit weak. Somewhat understandable as this is their first stab at it, but I'm hoping there's an improvement in the future. My internet tends to drop packets now and then, but this is the only game I have that really chokes on it. I have other friends with stronger internet than I that have had issues with connectivity as well. Other than that, I find this game extremely fun! Playing with friends is a must.

author: thatdiesel
review: Being a chef in the real world can be a hassle: it's hot, frantic, and difficult.  While the constant practice and the ferocious pace can be very taxing, being able to create the perfect dish is a very rewarding experience.  With the initial success of the original ,  looks to build upon what has already been made to create a delicious second course to their meal. puts you and up to 3 other chefs back into the Onion Kingdom to fend off the next threat that terrorizes the land.   brings The Unbread, puns abound throughout, to stumble through and its up to our chefs' hands, and tools, to help satisfy The Unbread's hunger.  Don't expect a whole lot of plot in , as this is mainly a placeholder to give the chefs a paper-thin reason to be where they are.The name of the game is to make meals and make them fast.  The chefs take their stations in a vast amount of areas: from up in the clouds in hot air balloons, to rafts down swamps, to magical doors in a medieval castle.  Meals will need to be made for The Unbread, which they will constantly be pouring in orders during the 3-5 minute rounds. Completed meals will grant the chefs points, with a tip for a quick delivery, as well as deliveries in the correct order; get enough in the allotted time, and you can earn up to 3 stars in each level, which these will help you unlock new characters, as well as progress through the story.The Unbread are a hungry bunch, so chefs will be tasked with making all sorts of meals.  Starting with easy combinations as a tomato and cucumber salad, to more intricate dishes: meat lover's pizza, mushroom pasta, and seafood sushi to name a few.  Chefs will use frying pans, ovens, chopping boards, mixers, and much more to prep and cook.  Once a groove is set and chefs feel comfortable with the frantic pace,  will throw wrenches into the well-oiled machine.  Chefs will have to throw specific items across pits to other chefs who can only cook in a certain part of the level.  Some levels will have small fires pop up that will need to be put out, with some levels using rotating equipment to throw chefs off their game, and make sure to wash those dishes!After doing battle with The Unbread,  includes a Arcade and Versus mode for chefs looking to continue cooking.  Arcade allows players to play levels in the story and compete for the highest score, while Versus pits chefs against each other to see who can crank out the most meals in the allotted time.  If you're feeling a real challenge, beating Story mode grants a sort of New Game Plus addition by giving each stage a 4th star to earn.  These stars require the utmost concentration and communication from the team of chefs, and will require a lot of pre-prepping dishes and coordination in roles.While multiplayer is clearly the name of the game for , single-player feels a little lacking.  While you control multiple chefs, it's not quite the same feeling as being in the fast-paced gauntlet with friends, yelling at each other about orders, and celebrating 3-star victories.  The Story map requires the player to hit switches that are semi-hidden in the world in order to get towards the next level, and it's really confusing as to why these were put into the game in the first place.  They serve really no purpose other to temporarily halt the player from speeding onto the next level, and just feels unnecessary. has an amazing ability to not only bring up to 4 people together to work harmoniously in a hectic environment, but to have real laugh-out-loud fun for hours on end doing it.  The simple art style, addicting gameplay, and tactical levels really bring a joy to cooking, even if your friends don't think you can do it.

author: Luchin Stiglitz
review: Its Ok

author: faizkunja
review: The game was great but u have to play it with somebody

author: Tessering
review: It's tons of fun, especially if you have a full group of friends. My friends and I progressed through the levels fairly quickly (although we haven't finished), but I'm not sure if that's more of a testament to us figuring out a system/good communication (my friends are especially articulate and aware of their surroundings). Game Mode+ was a nice addition, and I appreciate the developers' alacrity when it came to remapping keys (this was a big issue when four of us were sharing one controller and my laptop keyboard on OSx).My only request would be some kind of reward for getting to four stars in NG+; the achievement in it of itself is nice, but... *something* would be nice? Something simple; another unlockable cook, maybe? Otherwise I'd be more than happy with the addition of a couple of more formal Steam Achievements. It doesn't have to be an in-game thing.

author: MechMK1
review: I honestly don't know how to feel about Overcooked! 2. On one hand, I was laughing my butt off while playing. On the other hand, I feel so frustrated when playing.It's one of the few games that made me feel like I failed hard, even when I get three starts in a level. This is really not good design.Playing on one of the later stages requires a lot of coordination, and it feels like some levels are really designed for three or four players, which is a bit troublesome if you play alone or only with one friend. Perhaps this is intentional, but still a bit frustrating.All in all, I would say my feelings for this game are mixed. It did have its moments, but it's very exhausting to play if you want to get three stars in each level.

author: Rafuszka

author: mariskaas
review: I never picked up overcooked 1 because I wanted to play with friends that don't live nearby. So I was very happy hearing the second installment had online co-op! I've played through the game about 2.5 times now, once couch co-op.I thought it was a very fun and hectic game. Yelling at eachother, throwing tomatoes in eachothers face, really good. A lot of the levels are pretty easy, with some extremely hard ones. The game is quite short though, took probably 5-6 hours to complete. I really hope more levels, or a level builder, will be added free of charge since the price is a bit steep for what it is.There are some problems:When playing online only the host receives the new chefs and progresses in the story (however I read the chefs thing is a bug so I hope they fix soon, and they also said they are looking into changing the way online works).When we finished a world in one sitting the joined player would get achievements, otherwise did not.There is some other minor bugs, plates/pots getting stuck in countertops for instance, but didn't happen often enough for it to be a bother.What really was a bother was the lag that sometimes was experience during an online session, we've played for hours without issue but at some point there was a crazy lag which resulted in a lot of falling off platforms. Besides that the game crashed three times in an hour for the joined person (which was me, but didn't have issues when hosting). So yes, the game has issues, some major problems some minor. It was/is still a blast to play and I do really hope some more content is added, because it's a bit expensive for the current content.If you really want to play online and have the money, I would say get it. Otherwise get overcooked 1 (very good discount right now) and wait for the bug fixes and maybe a price drop.

author: Nanorphi
review: I love the pre-order chefs and the game in general. But the game is just way too easy, especially having played the first game. I wish it was more challenging or had several difficulty levels. Hopefully the developers implement difficulty options or make the 4-star update difficult enough. I also  hope the fix for player progress in online co-op will come soon. If they can fix the difficulty level and the player progress in online co-op, then I can definitely recommend this game.

review: Pros:- definitely a fun multiplayer/couch coop game- easy to pickup even if you haven't played the first title- levels are more dynamic and emphasizes teamwork compared to the first titleCons:- hardly anyone plays online, rarely get a chance to play online coop- connectivity issues during online coop-  IMHO, easier than the Overcooked! which can be a turn off to returning players as we don't get the satisfaction of getting that well earned 3 stars after several attemptsOverall, I'd still recommend this game for returning and first time players.
