author: Agent Hugh Jass
review: I had 6 hours of fun with the main story. Got all three stars in each level and Kevin level. I had a lot ot fun with my wife. It was much easier than the first game. I see the general improvements like online lobbies. But we had no difficulties in making the last boss fight at first glance. I am looking forward for a new game+ DLC or some online matches to fulfil the last achievements. So far I was too hyped for Overcooked 2 and got disappointed by the non existing challenges in comparison to the first game. Although I can recommend the game as it is a lot of fun. But do not expect a long lasting game.

author: Recherch√©
review: I'm really enjoying the new features like the portals and moving the crates to get ingredients. Makes everything more challenging and definitely more fun! The throwing feature was something I didn't know I need and I love it when I throw a chopped piece of food right onto the pan. The online multiplayer is alright, I think there isn't as many players in South East Asia so I have to wait really really long to actually find someone to play with. Hopefully there will be more people in the coming weeks. I came from Overcooked 1 where my friends and I spent HOURS on each level just to get 3 stars. We even strategise before playing each level to maxmise our efficiency to get the 3rd star. The new one is too easy. We overshoot the 3 star points all the time and it doesn't feel like we 'worked hard enough' to earn those stars like in Overcooked 1. TL:DR Make the game more challenging to get 3 stars (I guess just change the scoring?) If you're thinking on getting whether O1 or O2, go with this one.

author: sam
review: This game is a welcome sequel to one of my favorite games--co-op or otherwise--of all time, Overcooked. This game takes the strong foundation of the original game and innovates in meaningful ways on gameplay, map design, and even level selection. They've refined the co-op experience to feel more fluid and organic, while levels don't seem to suffer the pitfalls of design that some of the more bothersome levels of the original have. With a cute cast of characters, smart writing, and clever little details interwoven in every facet of the game, this game is a winner.That being said, the best litmus test for whether or not you'll like this game is to honestly play the original. This game starts you off strong, teaching you a new recipe in every single level stage that I can easily imagine would be a bit overwhelming for players brand new to the Overcooked series. By all means it's not impossible to jump into this title without playing the first, but new players definitely might find some of the complexity a bit much right from the start.Overcooked 2 is well on its way to becoming as beloved a game in our household as the original, and for very good reason. Overcooked 1 + 2 offer fun, clever co-op couched in a cute style, snappy writing, and engaging gameplay.

author: Mezimo
review: "Casual or hardcore, alone or with friends it can be enjoyed in all ways!"Team17 have a pat on your back, you achieved something great once again that brings hours of fun to all...HOWEVER don't think you got an A+ by making this game...CONS:- Only player host gets unlocked characters on online multiplayer. You have to be a host to get all of them (tons of replayability but at what cost)- From time to time a lagspike happens. At one moment i'm running on the left to my friend but then I end up bumping into him in the next second (rarely happens though and it was with online multiplayer)PROS:- Brings tons of hours to play (even if we ignore the fact of unlockables) we can still play online with others, competitively, together, at home...etc- Very challenging levels! At some point we struggeled with my buddy but still had fun in the end.- Graphics and music are amazing alltogether!PERSONAL SUGGESTIONS:- Personally I was missing some of the old recipies (like fish and chips or soup) and stages (actual space not planet)- Listen to the community a little bit more perhaps... (online multiplayer was a good thing you listened to but theres so many possibilities we would go within the game that would bring more value to the game example: editable stages, unlimited survival...etc)SUMMARY:A great game to play for long hours while enjoying the game itself, even if it causes some frutrations at times due to online connections or 1-2 overly complicated levels (yes im looking at you "cars and wind strike obstacle Kevin level") but all in all with all the amazing features the game has the coomunity will be satisfied... for now...Until we meet again! TooDaLoo...

author: PureCells
review: I'm rating this 8/10. It's a good game to get if you're a fan of overcooked or if you're looking for a game to play with family and friendsUnlike the previous overcooked, this has much more mechanics which will really test your teamwork and without proper communication it will lead to a total disasterThe dev have done a really good job in enhancing the chefs model and the surrounding design.They also have a so called online system which allows you to play with friends online!Just like any other games, this as well has room for improvements which may or may not applies for everyone.  : I always feel that to obtain 3 stars in overcooked, everyone should do their part and play the mechanics properly and be punished for making mistakes. However it seems that even with bad gameplay it's easy to obtain 3stars which makes it feel that there's no incentive to perform well. : This can be applied in overcooked 1 at stage 5-4, 5-5 whereby it's a pain in the ass to complete. As you progress along in Overcooked 2 you will feel that some stage design were questionable in terms of complexity, like the devs wanted to create alot of chaos but they were not quite there. : As much as I hate to say this, if you played overcooked solo and then proceed to overcooked 2 solo, you would agree with me that the solo gameplay in overcooked 1 is much better than the latest series. However, it's the problem mention above and the new feature that kind of leads to this problem which is the reason why it's better to play this with friends. Getting 3stars in every stage with ease makes solo players feel that the game is too easy to play, Semi bad solo stage design makes solo plays very painful and some other things that I might missed out. : From what I've observed, their online feature is a Peer 2 Peer model which means if you have friends whom you wan to play with in lets say New York, he/she will have to play with about 200+ping or something like that and you know, casually hangs once in awhile. : This 1 I'm just being anal, I prefer overcooked 1 chopping sound effects compared to the 2nd series. It feel lackluster compared to the 1st series.

review: A very great kitchen party game, I have experienced a few bugs in my playthrough but its a super fun game, and the best part it's online and it's open to all consoles and computers! review: This game is superfun so far. Been playing it with my gf. Only problem is that it tends to get stuck a lot in loading screens so we have to restart :( Overall this game is great and really worth it, had a lot of laughs and every other sort of emotion <3 !

author: JazzedIceberg
review: So this one is tricky for me... I played and absolutely loved the original. I spent 60 hours on it with various people I live with over about 2 weeks in lockdown. I bought this game hoping for another great time, and it had promised even more levels and game modes, so I was all in. 6-7 hours later me and one other person have finished the game finding all the levels dull. There were lots of improvements made to do with polishing up the movement and I liked the idea of being able to throw food, but this game lost something. In the original, every level eventually fell into complete chaos, and it struck a really good balance between chaotic and not being frustrating, but this one just didn't have that. The unpredictability felt very forced, and once we'd had one try at a level we knew what would happen, so it wasn't fun to try again.On top of that a lot of the new content (like the pvp stuff) was all locked behind another paywall, which I really didn't appreciate. Ultimately, I think this is still a good game, but if you've played the first game I don't think you should play this one

review: It's a lot crazier than the first one, and it adds a bunch of recipes. Definitely recommend buying it if you played Overcooked 1 and felt like you needed more, or just wanted to try out new combinations of ingredients.It did feel a little bit easier than Overcooked 1, but that might just be the experience talking: my brother and I completed Overcooked 1 before jumping into this game, so even with the craziest kitchens we kind of knew how to handle the pressure.I encourage you to decide by yourself which installment of the series is better :D

author: puki.cro
review: Really like the 2nd game, me and my gf have a lot of fun with this title. The pros:- really fun gameplay, especially for hotseat (which was why we bought it really)- lots of new dishes, although I wouldn't mind some more- no bugs worth mentioning- works like a charm with steam controllerCons:- We didn't encounter anyone in the online play, wonder what's up with that- It's a bit overpriced for what you get. If you're unsure, I'd recommend that you buy it on sale- Not really a con - the soundtrack of the first game was a bit more memorable and catchy than this one, though I like it reagrdless.*The gf says buy it anyway.

author: freedirk
review: Overcooked was a joy to play. Incredibly simple mayhem.Overcooked 2 has tweaked the recipe (!) to make simple mayhem more complex. The addition of online multiplayer has bridged a problem i had with overcooked, which was that as a 40 year old, my friends don't really come round to play computer games with me anymore. They havent done for probably 15 years.So online multiplayer sounds amazing. And it is. BUT.Without chat support, a way to communicate more directly with players, the issue is it is damned hard without open comms. Which now brings it around to making it necessary to convinging your friends to buy it and play it with you. Atleast they can now play from the comfort of their own homes and countries.Problem is . . . How do you convince someone to buy a game about a cooking panda making sashimi and cakes? . . . In conclusion, a great little game, but how much longevity does it have? especially at 22 euros. Now if it was 10 or 11, i reckon I could convince quite a few people to buy it. But at full price, few will take a nibble.

author: izzbizz
review: I got this game as a gift so I could play it with my sister. The game is great & really fun but there is a big problem with the graphics. There's a million tiny pink & green dots all over the screen that makes it terrible to look at. Looking up solutions, apparently quite a few people have had this problem and the dev team's only solution was to have you send them your computer's info so they could basically tell you that your graphics card wasn't good enough. While I do have an admittedly older system, it can run any other, newer game just fine. My sister has a newer system and it too can't run the graphics correctly. I shouldn't have to buy a shiny new graphics card to play the game, so it would be great if the devs could fix this on their end instead of having the players do it. Other than that, like I said its a great game and really fun to cook with your friends. The art style (without the dots) is cute and the gameplay is unique. Definitely improved on the first Overcooked game (esp. with the better multiplayer connection). Definitely recommend esp. if your graphics card is good. :)

author: 15x
review: My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

author: Chaotesque
review: One of the best chaotic co-op games I've played, I've probably replayed story mode way too much with different friends. An absolute buy for people who like food related games, adorable graphics and CHAOS! It's great to see that there were different free seasonal updates for players but also DLCs with new recipes and chefs for people who can't get enough. I ended up getting every single DLC for this game because it's just that much fun, especially since different DLCs adds new mechanics and themes! The game definitely has it's challenging components, especially when trying to get 4* for all the levels when you're playing as a duo even when you do everything perfectly so I wish there was a slight tweak in the scores required to achieve 4*. However, If you're not a completionist you'll definitely be able to get through the whole game pretty easily. Unfortunately if you're a single player person the game is probably not going to be as fun or achieveable. Definitely an upgrade with the game mechanics and playability than Overcooked 1.Eagerly awaiting for the upgrade scheme for "Overcooked! All You Can Eat"Hope there will be a Overcooked 3 or new level updates in the future. :)

author: Frito Bandito
review: I love this genre of game in general, and this game IS great fun. BUT do not get this game if you intend on playing it with young children. I try to play this with my 5yo girls, and the learning curve is so steep when trying out new levels. Delegating tasks can be so stressful it stops being fun. Every time we want to play a new level there's tons of stuff we have no idea how to cook or assemble. It would be nice to have a more expansive tutorial, and maybe even an EZ Mode for parents like me that want to play this with their kids who also want to play the game with them. Maybe even a "creative" or "free mode" without a timer just so you can try to get the hang of learning the dishes (or even just an option to expand the timer a la Easy, Medium, Hard difficulties). Something less punishing so you can build up to the more intentional hectic pace. I still recommend this game as it IS a ton of fun and can see how fun it would be with competent friends playing together, and the game itself is made really well. I just wish I could play it with my kiddos more without us all stressin'. Might put this one on the back burner until they are a couple years older.

author: Katrial
review: Favourite multiplayer game with the right people. Best with 4, but 2 and 3 are also good. Can be a good couples game (but beware, it's all about communication and teamwork in fun but pressured situations, so while I find this the perfect fun couples game, for others it could just cause fights and frustration). Wouldn't recommend as a single player game, though I've not really tried much. Always been a bucket of laughs and a fun coop challenge for me! Just wish my group of friends could organise to play it more often!

author: Cely
review: This is chaotic, crazy, delicious fun. It makes me feel like a kid again in all the best ways.* Overworld map - I don't know why, maybe the Mario nostalgia, or how the food truck transforms in cute ways, or how I can run over the unbread like this is GTA (I should get points). * Being cute characters - I picked the unicorn. Because of course I did.* Bullrushing... er I mean, accidentally bumping into my friends - who doesn't love a bit of bumper car action?* Laughing - My world was dark and dreary until overcooked made me remember how to laugh again. (Queue violin)* Dumplings and steaming things. Enough said. Omg. It is the worst.

author: JaxTheLumber
review: Played locally with a couple friends as chef Mouse, Panda and Shark.Earlier games was more of a warm-up: mouse teaches the others how things work and how to do what.A few rounds in, mouse, panda, and shark started cooking on a hot air balloon. It was a mess. And I mean . Mouse was screaming for clean plates while Panda was dashing around and shrieking about how the kitchen should not be on fire. Shark had to pause the game because he was running out of air laughing.Later in the game, the three had to call in reinforcements because the levels are getting harder, and so, joins Cat. The training was hard and includes a lot of Cat falling into the void. Nonetheless, Cat's paws are definitely what they needed to achieve culinary greatness.Going through the game, the formerly goofy chefs continually learned on how to cooperate and finally became heroes that the Onion Kingdom needed.Seriously though, if you have some friends to play with, a couch, a device to play the game on, and some sort of interface to control your chefs, you HAVE to try this game. The price is worth it for the good times you're about to have. By the way, local co-op is more recommended since you can't beat up the person who throws the finished dish into the trash can in online.15/10

author: microparsec
review: Every bad review seems to discredit this game due to either two or a combination of both flaws:1) Player progress is not saved if you're not the host of a multiplayer game2) You can't reconfigure key(board)-mappingNow I don't think it's particularly fair to judge the game of Overcooked on the multiplayer "mishap", since this is actually the first game of Overcooked to support an online multiplayer mode. That this is even a possibility, makes this game already a lot better than the first one. That people encounter complications with this is a bummer, but not particularly word a non-recommedation.I have played a few worlds of this game locally with a friend, and we were happily surprised with the difficulty and improved visuals, animations and gameplay elements. Throwing is hilarious, especially if you manage to throw the cheese onto the pizza, and adds a new skill for the players to learn. In the world menu, the car changing shapes depending on the surface is traveling on is quite fun, as well as the switches you have to press.The game is literally an Overcooked 2.0. Better visuals, animations, and more levels. I cannot NOT recommend this game, since it is precisely what I expected of Overcooked 2.0, and I think we will be playing this game for a few hours every time we meet in the future. The game is simply fun, and therefore, certainly recommended.

author: Jeremy Sunshine
review: This game and its DLC are loads of fun with friends. The levels offer a variety of creative challenges that have often kept us on our toes. Generally, I'd say it's important to play this as a team of 4 people that can talk with each other (it's certainly the ideal), but if you fall a bit short of that, the game will scale down the score requirements of each level to account for your handicap.It's a good experience trying to 100% the game. Initially, you're only challenged to score well enough to earn 3 stars on each level, which will require you demonstrate an understanding of the workflow that a level demands of you. Not too hard to accomplish, but it requires a bit of thought and coordination. Once you've gotten through all the levels, they give you the real challenge of earning a 4th star on each level, which often demands a nearly perfect performance. You don't have to be insanely skilled to make it possible - our team has our share of bumbles and confusion along the way - but the goal is to get as close as you can manage to working like a well oiled machine as you blitz through orders.We've laughed, we've screamed, we've jumped off the ledges and drowned in our despair... Awesome group game.The only thing stopping me from saying this game is perfectly executed is the fact that the interactions can be fiddly sometimes. The game does it best to figure out what you're trying to pick up or put down based off of what direction you're vaguely facing in, and sometimes if you're in a rush you can end up struggling against that and/or being caught off guard by it. It's not a big enough deal to stop my group from earning 4 stars on every level, but it can cause some confusion in high pressure moments if you're trying to press buttons at the soonest POSSIBLE moments or have littered an area with too many items on the floor. So overall, that can be frustrating by I also think most of its interference goes back to user error to some extent. I'd rate the game as 9/10.

author: Adzazel
review: Worst online multiplayer coding ever. NO local vs. online functionality. Then developers proceed to blame it on the community for being too stupid to turn off VPN. Really!?!?!10 hours on record, 4 of which are attempting to play online!I bet they will release paid for DLC before fixing online!

review: This game is addictive and super fun. It starts out feeling really chaotic until you get into a groove with your friends. Also, I can't imagine how difficult solo playing some of the harder levels would be....

Also the star goals are far too easy, it's unnecessary to optimize very much in order to get 3 stars.  I wish there was a "hard" mode with extreme goals to get more value out of the existing levels.Not very may people playing online yet, but hopefully that changes soon

review: A fun cooking game to play with friends. Now with remote play it gets even better as I can play with friends who dont own the game. It's a happy little game but will make you stress but that 3 stars appearing infornt of you will make you smile. I highly recommend this game just as a time waster or to play with others OR just have a delightful game.

author: ^_Kamomon_^
review: This game is very entertaining when played with a friend, though the controls are one of the most awkward ones I have ever seen and key-binding is not available at launch so I will imagine me having a hard time playing, something which stopped me from playing Overcooked 1 because of the lack of key bindings. However, key-binding has since been introduced post-launch and I have been quite enjoying the game. Difficulty spikes of levels are left to be desired as at one level you can breeze through it no sweat yet the next you are busting your arse off trying to even reach 3 stars, and the game can be considerably short if you manage to 3 star every level in one go. Improvements that I can think the game can make the game better includes making the environment more detailed, such as customers actually receiving our food, and allowing us to use the money we earn to actually do something like upgrading equipment or placing decorations. I also love the constant seasonal free and paid updates the game have been getting, but I do want more achievements please. Also, the connection is horrible at times. The game would freeze for a few seconds at a time if you were to fall down. Lastly, one of the levels can be hard to play for people with motion sickness, so do be wary. Multiplayer mode exist but it‚Äôs just more of the same, either compete with each other to get the best score, or allow the system to randomly pick a level for you to play. author: Flyerfang
review: This is a recent game that I've picked up! My friends got me to start playing it one random afternoon and I now own it on multiple platforms. Great for small groups of friends and is significantly more fast paced than I anticipated! The story mode is playable with up to 4-friends and I think that's really fun! I just wish it has more options for versus and arcade mode rather than what seems to be the 1st level of each "world" in the game. The DLC is also fun and challenging! Overall, this is a really enjoyable game despite the lack of versus variety. Would definitely recommend!

author: b0fh
review: ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOWComing back to it after 1 year, the game has been incredibly polished and added tons of new content. Definitely worth getting !-----The first one was an amazing game and gave us tons of hours of fun. So I preordered this one without hesitation, and I was a tad disappointed.By absolute standards, this is an excellent game. But it feels more like a polished version of the previous title. Graphics and usability have been greatly improved, but it falls a bit short on content, especially given the price.The only real new gameplay mechanic is ingredient throwing. At the beginning, you may get the impression that the world map will add an exploration/navigation challenge and nonlinear progression, with a traditional color-coded key-and-door mechanism, but that turns out to be a red herring. I'm happy they removed the boring soup recipes, and the dumpling/pancake/cake recipes are interesting, but I expected more variety.Difficulty has been drastically lowered. I'm playing with my wife, Overcooked! 1 took us about 20 hours to finish and we had to retry many levels multiple times. We finished this one in half the time and got 3 stars on the first try on all but a few levels, sometimes racking up ridiculously high scores.It really should have been called Overcooked!: Redux. I hope DLCs will add more content at a reasonable priceEDIT: The NG+ mode may change the deal very much, thanks !

author: Electro
review: Overcooked 2 undoubtedly shines in local co-op and the versus arcade modes. New recipes and obstacles provide a fresh challenge for veterans, but it remains approachable for new players with simple controls and short playtimes. The new throwing mechanic, too, adds a new dimension to both strategy and the inevitable chaos without overcomplicating things. It's a strong foundation, and with the right friends, Overcooked 2 is one of the best couch co-op games around. 7/10

Also you can play it on a potato with the only issues being coming up with a baked potato and thematically thats a win too.  Dlcs are worth it too, only downside from where I sit is it doesn't include bacon, sour cream, and chives to properly dress your baked potato.

author: Allsen
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Meowish
review: This is a fun game that's built in mind to be played in co-op with friends. Can be super fun and addictive when you're having a couch co-op party over. But, playing it alone REALLY makes you feel lonely, though in this sequel the dev have addressed to that problem, this is still a best played in co-op game.So some advises to those who plan to buy this game:[1] If you plan to buy this and play it alone, you will definitely find it a lack luster. Although compared to the first series, this one actually put the solo players into consideration in design.[2] If you plan to use this game in a house party/play it with your family, this is definitely a great choice.[3] Unlike their other titles, this one actually have an online match maker. So you don't really have to play alone if you have no one to invite over for a coach play, especially during the Pandemic where everyone stays home and can't visit others easily. As long as you have a good internet connection, this game can provide long hours of fun.Gameplay itself, like the first series, is very exciting and the time rushed limit makes your heart beat almost as fast as those horror games. And it gets more and more difficult over stages. Definitely will give a good laugh when playing with friends or on this case, online co-op. The title menu is more easier to navigate than the first series, and it certainly provide ways of play style suitable for all needs, may you want to play the game solo and offline, you can. If you want to play it at home co-op during party or with family, you can too. If don't want to play alone but has no one to play with, you can try their online co-op play.If you are in for the fun, just avoid those serious players when you're playing online. They play the game for perfection, taking it more seriously than their jobs in real life. If you don't mind repeating the same thing over and over and over again until you perfect it, then yes, you are probably one of them. And the best of them perfect stuffs and guide those alongside them to perfection at the same time. But for a player that plays for the fun alone, you will probably call it off after repeating the same stages a few times and call it boring, just like any MMO games out there. Honestly speaking, couch play is more fun when played with jokes and laughter with someone you actually know and able to see their reaction real time.

author: Jarago
review: Overcooked: All you can eat Edition Warning - Overcooked AYCE is literally the same game, that already contains all DLC's + devs are making more DLCs exclusively for Overcooked AYCE. Unfortunately those, who bought everything in overcooked 1 and 2 are left out as none of the new content is not included in this version. Therefore if you don't own any overcooked yet, AYCE is a better choice for you. Anyway, since it's still the same game, this review applies to AYCE as well.Overcooked is a game where your task is to prepare requested foods as fast as possible. Sort of similar to old browser or mobile games, but this time on PC and improved! A good one! There are two main features that make this game unique:- Cooperative nature of the game makes this perfect party game to play on couch or online. Game truly requires communication with coop partners for effective goal fulfilment of each level. - Dynamic level design. Levels often change the placement of ingredients on map in the middle of level, add some crazy condition like kitchen in the middle of car traffic or on air balloon and introduces new recipes every couple levels. Every level is unique.Each level can be completed with star rating - up to 3 stars as best results with also unlockable 4th star goal. Each level has a time limit during which players can work towards the goals. These star goals seem a bit imbalanced in the first half of the game, as it is quite easy to reach 3 stars on first try. Reaching 4th star is however quite the opposite and requires truly masterful performance/ Game also offers training mode without time limit and versus mode where players play against themselves for best score in mirrored kitchens. As game lifetime progressed, some free DLCs were released themed around xmas and chinese new year, which add couple more levels with new gameplay features. + Fun & enjoyable cooperative experience+ Dynamic and unique levels- Some environment mechanics may be a bit annoying, like random flame strikes and moving islands.- A bit too easy to earn 3 stars in first half of main campaign8/10Conclusion: Must buy for local parties and for fans of cooperative focused gamesDLC Reviews - as i don't want to write for each DLC separately, ill describe them here:Offers couple new levels (about half a lenght of main campaign). Star goals are significantly more difficult than main campaign, making is much more balanced; makes 3rd star quite difficult to achieve. Campfire features requires players to chop wood to light up campfires. Another new feature in couple levels is ingredient backpacks, which players carry around with them. Personally disliked backpacks as they only made a mess and were annoying to work with.+ Campfires+ More balanced star goals, also more difficult- Backpack featuresConclusion: If you enjoy main game, you wont be disappointed. Adds about 20 new levels featuring some new mechanics, one of the main ones being horde levels where you have to prepare meals for horde trying to break through to your kitchen. First half of the DLC is easier, late horde levels may get quite difficult and long. Hovewer when lot of things happen at once, you may go crazy from all the warning beepings. Other than horde mode, there is little number of minor new mechanics. Worthy addition for those who loved main story mode.+ Good addition; horde mode offers fresh take on game- Beeping on horde mode may get on your nervesConclusion: If you enjoy main game, you wont be disappointed. Latest addition to season pass brings once again nice amount of new recipes and gameplay mechanics like cannons. Star goals seem to be balanced nearly perfectly here and new levels are very enjoyable. + Fun new recipes, mechanics and levels! No negatives here!Conclusion: Would be first DLC on must buy list for overcooked.DLC once again brings couple extra fun levels to beat. Couple new recipes are introduced. Only negative i'd give this is this DLC not being part of season pass and has to be bought separately.+ fun new recipes and levels.- is not part of season pass and has to be bought separatelyConclusion: If you enjoy main game, you wont be disappointed. Personally don't own this one as they only add skins for chefs, but its nice way of showing support to devs.

Unless you have a similarly competitive friend, this game is only going to frustrate you.Overcooked 1 was much more balanced and fun to play than this sequel.

author: Advendra
review: Overcooked! 2 is unique and fun. There is probably no other game out there like this game if you think of a cooking arcade-genre game, full of fun and laughter, when you play with friends, family or anyone, and this game can be played co-op or versus. Doesn't matter if you win or fail. It will give you laugh when you fail, and satisfaction when you win the score. This game is casual but with its stage-based and score-based concept, it could be challenging to your hand-eye coordination if you want to get the highest score in the game. Cons is you'll probably get bored fast if you play solo. Here's a good news: you can play any DLC in online multiplayers, as long as the host own it. The other players don't have to own the DLC.

author: GeneralArse
review: I never played the first game, so I can't say for certain whether or not this game is better or not. But it's a darn good game when you're with friends and it has online co-op as well which the first game didn't have. Levels can be pretty difficult at times but once you focus hard enough and stop messing around you actually get a hang of each one and figure out just how to finish them with the best score and minimal failure. It's got a pretty simple story and a wide selection of playable characters to choose from!Definitely recommend picking this game up, just remember to bring a friend and maybe a controller while you're at it.

author: Pinstripe
review: This is my favorite couch co-op game. It keeps the tension high, it's pretty funny, and the adversity that you face on a lot of levels makes for some ridiculous situations, and a lot of yelling. I got this game in hopes that my wife might be open to trying it out, and now she approaches me to ask if I want to play with her, something I never thought would happen.I do think some of the main game levels could be a little more challenging or have a higher requirement to get 3 stars, but the expansions definitely make up for it. They bumped up the challenge level big time and did a really good job with creativity in adding fun new mechanics and recipes for each expansion. I bought the season pass and I'm very satisfied with it so far. Looking forward to moving out!

author: PinkRayne
review: Fun co-op puzzle/cooking game. Cook a variety of meals in chaotic kitchens whilst the timer counts down! To be successful you must avoid fires, seagulls and river rapids, whilst navigating magic mirrors! Craziest cooking game around. I like that each level only lasts a few minutes... great to hop in and out for a few rounds. Overcooked is a cute, funny and chaotic coop game that's super fun to play. Recommended,

author: Bio
review: PROS: The game is really fun and engaging. Great co-op game and gets harder just after tutorial ( good thing )CONS: Although the graphics are ok, and the maps have lots of detail, the playable area is too small compared with the rest of the map ( just decoration ). This means that in anything smaller than 22inch the game gets quite small to play. The screen zoom should be adjustable to account for this. Specially since its a co-op game and the area for each player is divided even further.

author: mad cuz bad
review: The Onion Kingdom, still ruled by the wise and competent Onion King, is in trouble yet again. The Onion King‚Äôs camping trip, beachside vacation and circus festival (which are parts of separately bought DLCs) are also a mess, which is surely a coincidence and has nothing to do with the royal person‚Ä¶ Fortunately you are going to help, and you can be much better at it now than in the original Overcooked, for a few reasons.Overcooked 2 includes real online multiplayer apart from couch multiplayer and streaming via Remote Play Together. This is a very welcome improvement ‚Äì of course the game can be played comfortably via streaming, and your team only needs one copy of the game that way, but online multiplayer provides the best latency and responsiveness. When you are chasing the highest scores, or when one or more participants don‚Äôt enjoy a fast and stable internet connection, this is invaluable.Game mechanics are vastly changed, because cooks can now throw raw ingredients. Throw things into pots, throw them to your teammate, throw them at your teammate or just throw in desperation ‚Äì the possibilities will make you wonder how did you manage to play Overcooked without this skill. Throwing changes the dynamic of the game a lot, but mechanics are overall still easy to grasp and execute even for casual gamers.If you have a perfectionist streak, prepare for a harrowing experience. After beating the game you can replay kitchens for an attempt at reaching an even higher, 4-star score threshold. Even the 3-star thresholds are badly chosen on some levels played in a 2-person group, and some of the 4-stars seem to be straight up impossible. Luckily ‚Äì if you buy the story-based DLCs ‚Äì there are tons of new kitchens, ingredients and recipes to explore. That, plus an arcade mode which provides a ton of randomly chosen kitchens, make for a lot of replayability. A great portion of full priced AAA games are much shorter. I did not enjoy 2-person versus mode much: controlling two characters was a lot more troublesome to me (and it's the same when you play solo).I strongly recommend playing on a controller. Throwing at other than right angles is hard or impossible with keyboard and mouse; you can play and enjoy the game, but you won‚Äôt be a .

author: Korrava
review: This game is a really fun. I've gotten through majority of the story mode with just one section left, and so far I've enjoyed it. The game offers a challenging experience whether you play solo or with friends. Striving to achieve 3 stars for each level makes the game intense. Playing with friends puts your communication skills to the test. It's interesting to see how either goes.I love that the game is also online multiplayer. I've played with people online and communicating without speech is another interesting challenge. There's also a survival and practice mode, which is pretty neat. There's so much content for the game that I can't imagine getting bored with it. The multiplayer mode will make each game a different experience since you're playing with various people who also play in their own way.On top of the fun game play, the style of the game is also really cute. It's really polished compared to the older game. If you've never played Overcooked! 2, I definitely recommend it to anyone interested. Despite the game being a couple of years old, it's still very entertaining and a purchase I'd never regret.

author: ÊòüÊ≤≥
review: This is the first time that I write a review on Steam. I like Overcooked2, but still disappointed. I paid $25 for this game and wished for a good game but the gaming experiences are just not good. I bought this game because it has good graphics and it looks interesting. Then I played it, I realized that this game's single player mode is REALLY JUST YOURSELF. You can't have the option to play with a PC or something. Even though this mode gives you more time but it's just not fun to keep switching back and forth between characters. I wanted to play this game because it has an online multiplayer feature. I'm assuming that's one reason why most people bought it. The problem is that this mode isn't really stable yet. Sometimes I will see myself floating around, suddenly disappear in the game, failed to grab something, or transporting to different spots without my control (I'm pretty confused). My friend and I actually have to get a VPN to play the online multiplayer mode. When my friend isn't around, I thought about playing with others at the public center, but no one ever showed up. It almost made me feel like I'm the only person who plays this game. Another thing is that the game design is a bit too hard I would say. Probably because I keep getting bugged out, the game just became even more difficult for me. My friend and I can barely play the newer levels without helps from others. Anyways, I'm still supporting you all because I liked the concept and game design (even though it's hard, it's still creative ;)  ). I just bought the DLC from you guys to show my support. However, I would suggest you guys work on the online multiplayer mode more. Make sure it's stable. I want a fun and stable gaming experience. Thanks.

author: CesarDaSalad
review: I think other people reviewing this game are missing a key aspect: Yes I know it shouldn't be the case when you can do up to 4 players, but that's just the way it is. People's negative reviews are about 3-4 player games. If you have 3 or 4 players in a game, the stages will seem too easy. Of course they are gonna be too easy when you have twice the people you need to get things done. That's just how the stages' obstacles and timing is designed. So you'll have a much more fun and challenging experience with a single partner. Anyway, this game is fantastic as the first one, but even more so thanks to online multiplayer (which I said was the main flaw of the first one, the lack of online). You can indeed try 3 or 4 players, but the fun exists in that sweet spot where 2 players have to tackle all the mayhem.

review: It is such an addicting game. I love it. However, it made me realize I have a controlling problem. The fact that I am now in my midterm with tons of exams and deadlines but I spent almost 14 hours playing since I bought it. I COULD NOT control my life, I headed downhill and I found just a tiny bit sense of control. And it was honest hard work. Or I am just a natural cook. Anyways, the graphic work is adorable. The gameplay is super easy to catch up. My friend who does not play game that often can comfortably hop on and enjoy. SHE HAS A HIGHER SCREEN TIME THAN ME!!! The music is 10000/10, very relaxing, even though I muted it for better concentrating. In conclusion, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! but watch out for your life :( I would love to tell you how I first knew this game too, but it would showcase strongly that I have another set of issues. My mental health cannot deal with that right now haha. I AM NOT OKAY but whatever. Peace out!

author: Ivecte
review: I found Overcooked! 2 to be a fun and challenging game. The gameplay involves working together with other players to prepare and serve meals in a busy kitchen. The levels are varied and creative, and the tasks required to complete them are often hectic and fast-paced, which can make for a very enjoyable experience. The game's art style is colorful and whimsical, and the sound effects are well-done.One aspect that I didn't like is that the game can become quite difficult as players progress through the levels, which can be frustrating at times. Additionally, the game requires a lot of coordination with other players, which can be difficult to achieve if you are playing with people who are not familiar with the game or who are not communicating well.Overall, I would recommend Overcooked! 2 to others who enjoy fast-paced, cooperative gameplay and don't mind a bit of challenge. It's a great game to play with friends and family.

author: Krobelux
review: I got this game, along with my girlfriend, because I enjoyed the first one (and my girlfriend is a huge fan of the first one) and we beat it in a couple of sittings. We beat the main campaign in about 6 hours total, 3 starring every level. For most of the levels, we were able to 3 star them on the first attempt. Only a couple of levels gave us any real trouble, and the one level that gave us the most trouble was only due to the fact that the netcode is very poor. We both have good connections in our place, and I would let her host so that she would get all the progress (before they patched that) and so I would lag quite often when I would bump into her character. This one particular level I would repeatedly fall off the narrow islands connecting the two bigger islands, despite not walking into the water hazard my character would rubber band constantly, and end up in the water. It was extremely frustrating, and I think the level in particular is 6-2 (but I could be wrong about that). After you get through world 6 the campaign is over. There is versus and arcade but we never really got into that. They say they are planning on adding a New Game + variation down the line, which will be great when it's added.For the price (almost $30 CAD) I cannot recommend this game. If the game ever goes on a 50% off sale, and you liked the first one, it's definitely worth it. If you're a fan of the first one, you will definitely enjoy this game but I think for the price, you don't get enough content to justify the full price tag. I think what would benefit this game, would be a level editor that would support the Steam Workshop, that would be pretty awesome and add more than 6 hours of replayability. For now, we're just hoping the New Game + will be a fun and challenging addition.[Update] After not playing this game for about a month, I see an update in my steam and see that they've added new content. My girlfriend was excited, until we found out that it's 6 bucks. Now that's not bad for DLC in some cases however the game itself was almost 30 bucks (CAD) and released as an unfinished mess. Now that they've added New Game + (which is literally only a new star of difficulty) and shared progress, I guess the base game wont get anymore love. It's a shame because the game didn't take longer than a few hours to complete with one other person, and we 3 starred the entire game (before the 4th star difficulty came out). 6 hours to complete the entire game is not worth 30 bucks.If this game ever goes on a 75% off sale, absolutely it's worth it. But for the amount of content you  get for the price you're paying, absolutely not worth it now as of October 3rd 2018.

author: Filthy Casual
review: Contrary to popular belief, Overcooked is a relaxing and straight forward cooking game. Through its linear level system, Overcooked challenges players to work hard together as a team to achieve those sweet, sweet stars. Each level unlocked sparks joy within the players as they are proud of their accomplishments and are ready to face any challenges that come their way. If you looking for a laid back yet rewarding game, Overcooked is for you.Said no one ever.In reality, Overcooked is a disaster kitchen. There are constant fires and burnt food that need to be dealt with, piles of ingredients left carelessly on the ground and of course, the management of your team mates. The voice call fills with frustration as the one friend keeps washing dishes instead of preparing ingredients and you're three orders down. Meanwhile, the stove is burning and one other friend fell off the edge. Honestly, if you're looking for a bad time in the kitchen, this is the game for you. Buy it for all your friends. It will really test your friendship.7.5/10

Beat in eggs, one at a time, then stir in vanilla. Dissolve baking soda in hot water. Add to batter along with salt. Stir in flour, chocolate chips, and walnuts.3)Drop spoonfuls of dough 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets.4)Bake in the preheated oven until edges are nicely browned, about 10 minutes. author: frank
review: The first one was brilliant--the levels would yield to careful planning and tight teamwork. The levels in this one are mostly just annoying: it's like the difference between escaping from one of those escape rooms using your puzzle-solving acumen, and escaping from a locked prison cell using a rusty nail file.I'd avoid, tbh.

author: Mid Tier God
review: Has potential. Learning curve gets a bit steep but not too bad. Very fast paced gameplay and no real room for mistakes in the later levels. My biggest complaint and really the one that makes it hard to enjoy this game for me is the controls on keyboard. Adding in the ability to remap them at least on PC would be extraordinarily helpful and make the game far more manageable and fun.Otherwise I unfortunately have to stick with the rating above. Grab a controller when you pick this game up.  NOTE THAT WHILE I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME, IT IS NOT BECAUSE OF IT'S LEVEL OF FUN. THE GAME HAS VERY GOOD POTENTIAL IF THE CONTROLS ARE EASIER TO MANAGE IN THE FUTURE.

author: Powerful Cow
review: The thing about the first Overcooked is that it was intuitive. You knew exactly what you had to do and where to improve, if you wanted to get "3 stars". Mastering a level after a good amount of practice felt great. Overcooked 2, on the other hand, has 100 times more levels, 2% of which are awesome, but the other 98% look like you will absolutely hate playing them. We couldn't understand what was going on, and, what is worse, the game didn't expect we would. You are given 3 stars if you perform just a bit better than terribly. We found it impossible to finish more than 3 levels in a row without getting tired and quitting the game.Don't get me wrong, it's still a decent game. It does look much better than the first one, but certainly doesn't feel nearly as good to play. For us it was a disappointment.

author: Katasana
review: TLDR: This game was never balanced and is way too easy.Level design is gimmicky and detracts from gameplay.Don't get this game, get Overcooked1; that one's actually fun.--From all these positive reviews.... has no one played the first Overcooked??!!?!Ignore the hours on this account, I played through the whole game as couch co-op on my partner's account.After playing the first Overcooked (11/10 btw), I knew I had to get the sequel. The first one was so perfect, it really raised my expectations for this dev team to go above and beyond in their next installment. Annndddddd..... crash landing to Earth.It is abundantly clear this game was not balance tested. At all. The only reason you wouldn't get 200% of the 3 star mark is if you got screwed by the poor level design. And then you would get your 200% on your second try. The gimmicks for the stages do not add to the original purpose of the game: to cook your orders and serve them. They're there just to slow you down, make you wait for platforms to reappear, or otherwise just get in your way.They patched the game with NG+ by adding a 4th star. This is an ok attempt at saving this but you still need to finish the game with 3 stars before 4 stars is unlocked. The 4th star is hard. Like endgame Overcooked1 hard or even harder, which is fantastic, and really should be in the original playthrough.Overall, this game was a big disappointment. Game developers never balance tested the game, and tried to throw in too many gimmicks that detracted from what made the first Overcooked perfect. This is a classic case of being too worried about the "could you" that they never considered the "should you".Get this game if you have 10 year olds who can't take losing.

author: Bryteside
review: The game has solid puns, which I blooming well love, but sadly the overall game is somewhat underbakedHere is what I didnt like:-Controls are not good enough to make this enjoyable:too often do you find yourself putting things on the square next to where you intended due to slightly woolly controls.-level design is too complicated too quickly. Learning a new recipe whilst dealing with an obtuse layout AND that layout can alter several times during a mission ... its too much. Let people get to grips with your recipes THEN go silly with the level design-While we're talking about level design - out of bound areas:If you are going to have sections where you can fall off the map, having the penalty set as losing everything you were holding AND having to wait 5 seconds to respawn is too harsh. Its a party game, not a rogue-like-certain hazards are poorly optimised for 2 playersIm looking at your hot air balloon with fire spouting everywhere-it isnt funny when things go badlyThere are plenty of games where doing badly is hilarious - broforce, helldive to name but a few.-the pause button obscures 1/2 the map so you cant even plan who does what during a pause.-the throwing mechanic is fun, but an aim laser pointer would be a welcome additionBasically the concept is good, but the finished product is lacking - there are more fun co-op games out there

author: The_Tressonado
review: *I have played many hours on another console*This may be an unpopular opinion, but I feel that Overcooked (both original and this sequel) have a fatal flaw that is one of the reasons that so few people get seriously hooked:Overcooked does not know what it is trying to be. Is it a casual or strategy? At first glance it appears to be a casual game in a similar vein to the Diner Dash Series. Unfortunately the strict time limits and overly complex variations that each level brings cause it to drop out of that category - You cannot just sit and muck around. The moment you get into any sort of comfortable groove, the game throws a different recipe, a new transportation system, or at the very least starts re-arranging the work space mid-level. The game never allows you to become very good at it, until it says "well that was good enough for 3 stars, now move on"!So what is the genre? Is it a strategy game that requires careful planning and coordination in order to master? Well, yes... no... kinda. Its just too chaotic to be master-able. You can get very good, but never master it. It's like dangling a carrot on a stick.The game even seems to recognise this fact. You can fail many orders and do quite poorly in some levels, but still get all 3 stars. This self-acknowledged un-master-ability creates a kind of depressing air to the whole experience. Knowing you can never truly achieve a clean run in a game is kinda like designing a level in Mario Bros. that has unreachable coins. It just torments you. This, coupled with the random generation of most orders, means it doesn't feel like a strategy game, you can't really plan. If the game allowed you to play a more career style campaign - playing rounds to purchase new equipment and recipes, actually allowing you to feel progression, or at the very least made the length of each level far, far longer, it would be possible to curb the frustration that comes with the Chaos that it tries to bring to the table.Unfortunately, in its current state, Overcooked is a "I don't know what to do until we fail twice", and then "oh that wasn't great but somehow we got all the stars" kinda experience. Only add conveyor belts, pits, flames, portals, and every form of annoyingness thrown in. Think, would the game suffer without those things?Overall I do *like* the game, but I can't love it. The chaos is fun for the first few hours, but ultimately takes away from the game play long-term. I can only play it as a social experience.

(It was soo hard that it is not that of a good quality lol)Overcooked 2:The challenge is to walk through the stages and not to cook more with less effort and time. I found Overcooked 2 just went insane early on.Maybe it's because I play it with my wife and kids, but I just didn't like it.  I could see if you were a hardcore group of friends wanting a silly crazy challenge, then maybe it fits the bill? Still not sure.

author: dog
review: Amazing concept, very lazy execution.All things considered, my review should probably be positive, and I would like it to be, but as someone who's been playing this series for a little over 4 years now, I and many others have noticed a very sharp decline in the amount of care that team17/ghost town games puts into their product. I've played a number of "new" games over the past year that are still being updated and significantly altered by their developers. They span across a variety of completely different genres, so not much point in me recommending a first person shooter to someone looking for a cooking simulator, but playing those other games has shown me what a developer that cares about their game can do, and I would encourage anyone interested in this game to consider other options before pledging their allegiance here.

author: YellowCellPhone
review: I really enjoyed Overcooked 1. It was a legitimate challenge to three star every level, and toward the end we only passed with concentration, assigned roles, a game plan, and a bit of luck. Some levels took us legitimately over half an hour of attempts to get a three star, but it was a decent and satisfying challenge and full of hilarious dumb happenings the entire way. Losing was fun, and victory at the end was worth it.Now in Overcooked 2 we found ourselves having smashed the three star requirement in about two minutes, usually while barely paying attention. The last minute of every level was spent throwing food at each other in a half-hearted attempt at staving off boredom, because why bother trying when we're already 200+ points ahead? I legitimately believe that in a 4 player mode, you'd still be able to hit 3 stars if 2 of your players were afk. If we played 1 as lazily and unfocused as we were during 2, we would not even have gotten a one star rating.I'm aware there's a NG+ that asks for a fourth star with drastically higher point totals, but me and my group cannot force ourselves to march to the end of the campaign if we legitimately are not having fun the entire way there. If there was a difficulty mode at the start of each game that raised the point requirements, or an option to start in NG+, or an option to remove the tip multiplier, I have no doubt we'd be sucked back and grinding for those stars. But after we finished the first area, we ran out of patience and closed the game.There's nothing functionally wrong with the game, it is a lot more polished and full of content compared to 1, but the lack of immediate challenge really killed its vibe. This is why I really do not like games that lock harder difficulties behind beating the campaign. I would recommend it to people who found 1 too challenging or too lacking in features, but I would advise people who enjoyed 1 for the challenge to walk away.

author: WildWayz
review: First up, I received this game for free for taking part in the closed beta and providing feedback. However, this is not going to sway my views. This review is based on the final game.I never played the original Overcooked! but I can see this is a fun game. It's one of those games where you can either play a quick game or two before work, or a longer session when relaxing in the evening! There are several arenas, each a bit unique with different challenges. This game is best played with 3 other people to get the most out of it! There is a couch mode where if you have your buddies over, you can all use the same PC. Also online modes too. When searching for public games, sometimes you only manage to get 1 other player - but it could be because it is new. However, it was really good fun. It would benefit from some form of in-game chat as opposed to using Discord or whatever for doing it, as we couldn't reallly communicate. If you are in a lobby with a guy and you play a few games, you do end up learning what works best for each other ie one of you does the chopping, plating etc the other puts out fires, washes dishes and brings ingredients to the chopping boards etcI only spent about 1.6hrs playing, but I really like these "pick up and play" games - this ports well to the PC, Xbox, PS and mobile platform well - as the controls are simple. In fact, I play with a gamepad on the PC.All in all... would I recommend? Yes! It's not expensive - worth a punt or wait for the sale if you are not sure. Either way, it's a good, fun game. Will it end up being a best seller ? Probably not - but the sales should be steady.If you see me in game, say hi!

author: sweaty
review: Fun party game with a surprisingly impressive hardcore competitive scene. I enjoy the graphics and the gameplay mechanics; the DLCs are great as well (if anything they're better value than the core game). My only gripes are that this game is bafflingly hardware intensive and that public lobbies have a lot of difficulty filling up most hours. Because this game is marketed as a party game for friends, the number of people interested in public lobbies is incredibly small. And versus mode is just a graveyard.

OG Overcooked fans will probably find this game a little bland, its very much more of the same experience with only a few new gimmicks.  Overcooked 2 is just overcooked with a little more polish which is nice but underwhelming also. Without the online features, this probably could have been released as DLC for the original.TL;DR: Good game but 5 hours of cooking game content is not worth $25 wait for the sale or just buy overcooked 1 if its cheaper

author: JulleK
review: Don't get me wrong, the game itself is really good and fun, BUT if you want to play with friends, that play on other platforms (epic games, xbox game pass) you will probably find it difficult. The crossplay is really poor because if you want to play with people from epic games, you will have to change the version to "crossplay branch", and you will need to download additional ~5 GB (when you change to this version, you can't play with people from "normal" version). Sadly you can't even play with people from xbox game pass.

author: Wild Cat
review: It's a boring game that has probably never been tested otherwise they'd have noticed that it needs several more gameplay settings. The porting is not terrible but not great, either.For single player, the game is playable for about 10~20 minutes and then the difficulty ramps up to unplayable level. For multiplayer, you have to be 4 players to get anywhere in the game; if you are 3, the game splits you in an almost-always-bad way across most split maps.The maps are boring, frustrating and lack gameplay options to make them any better.The recipes are ok except it would have been nice to have a sandbox mode where you select the family of recipes to play with any map.The most annoying part is the strict time limit, that's not exactly fun at least imo; there is another gameplay but you only unlock it after playing in standard gameplay first and even that one is then limited.Overall this is one of those game I wouldn't recommend at all, not even if it were free.

author: Dwight Schrute
review: Overcooked is a very fun game. I mean it. I've been playing the game since forever I recently I got enough money to purchase the DLC. But the thing is, IT'S TOO LAGGY. To the point of being unplayable. Usually, the person who gets invited to the session will be the one to experience the annoying lags.Now I've read other reviews and I can see that I'm not the only one experiencing the issue. Some reviews describe the exact same problem, so it must have be a chronic bug and which desperately requires fixing. Games like this should not suffer from these unnecessary bugs which would greatly undermine the value of the game. That being said, I really hope you developers can fix your bugs, so us gamers can finally fully enjoy your product.

In All You Can Eat. Look, I know this probably wasn't the intention, but it makes me feel like I'm being held hostage and either have to suffer with a game that flares up my sensory issues, or buy the remaster or whatever the hell it is that is a lot more expensive that comes with a game I don't even want. Please, if any dev ever sees this, could you consider *something* at all? even anything lazy or low effort, just as long as it helps with accesibilty. I love this game so much, just god please.

author: sunf7ower
review: Overcooked is madness personified in the kitchen.It is the funniest game I have ever played, and at the same time very stressful in some levels (if you are a perfectionist you will understand me) since coordination and organization are needed to beat the established records.You can play it with a friend or your partner, and you will die laughing to see them running around the kitchen so that the food does not burn.The game provides a lot of base content, once you finish the main campaign, you can continue playing to measure your speed and your own limits in duels against your friends.The more you progress, the more chefs with cute and funny features will be unlocked, and I understand that the DLCs also have their own chefs. (I'll check soon)It also has a free expansion that is basically a small summary of what the DLC provides, with a lot of variety of kitchens and environments.It is not recommended to play it alone, the fun is undoubtedly more intense with another person, so the work is divided and more rewarding.10/10 without a doubt

author: n0v0leg
review: No, Team17. It's 25 years of re-releasing abandonware. For instance, Worms Revolution still kills it's own process on your opponents PC's whenever you deploy a parachute during the free fall. Instant win which anyone can abuse. But why bother to support the game, when you can just release another one, right?Now, with Overcooked being re-released... For starter, the first edition didn't even had an online multiplayer. This second edition has numerous network issues, such as desync when people teleport back and forth, or major bugs when you suddenly get random teammates in a private match.This game is currently in the early access stage.

author: Mosche Dajan
review: While Overcooked was simply amazing, this game gets a little out of hand. The levels tend to become too absurd and thus easily frustrating. The actual cooking is neglected and you only have to figure out the level design. If you do, you outplay the necessary 3* points easily. This kind of challenge, for me, destroys the entertainment of the game.As I always want to have 3* before moving on to the next level, on Overcooked 1, we sometimes had to redo the map because we were just short. In this one, I either restart because it's not going well or I'm at 150% of the necessary points for a 3* rating, which doesn't imply a balanced level design.To top it all off, sometimes you have to look for the ramp switch on the menu map for a minute to even access a level, because it's hidden somewhere outside of the screen range (see lvl 6 or 7, red switch/ramp), which is absolutely unnecessary and dumb.It's sad, but luckily there is at least one competitor which focuses more on kitchen efficiency than absurd level design.Update: After playing it through (5h), there's a next star level unlocked that's hard to achieve, so there is more of a challenge for a higher rating. My problem with the game, however, is still there unfortunately.

author: Xephrit
review: The game is really fun, but it is too difficult to get started playing. My friend and I can't play together. We can't join each other's lobby and get the "Game could not be joined" error when we try. We cleared DNS, which worked once, but now we're getting the same error even after clearing DNS. We have checked that our games are up to date, ran as administrator, checked devices for updates, restarted devices, and checked that the game is allowed through firewall. None of this has helped. I'm not sure what to do at this point and am beyond irritated that we each spent money on a game we can't even play together. I shouldn't have to go through all of this to play the game as it is intended to be played.

If you really like this style of intense micro management game, it's probably going to be great with any number of players.I played my with my partner and we finished it in the end out of obligation, so it became a chore. Would massively recommend Orcs Must Die 2 though!

author: Ang√´l
review: After playing the first overcooked and completing it, I was waiting for the next instalment. It's a fun coach game and does get more interesting and challenging as the levels progress while always aiming for 3 stars. Local coop is what makes it quite fun for me. Would recommend for those that just want to chilli at the coach and play with others and very family friendly. However Online game play has a wait time to find another player that is longer than 10 mins. Some minor bugs when throw objects close to the sink or stove. Also, to be noted that the dev's are working on a new game+, which would be awesome for more replay-ability. I would love it if the devs would release a level editor for making steam workshop level, can be fun designing your own nightmare kitchen.

author: Draktok
review: Tentative upvote. The game is a ton of fun and I'm having a lot of fun with friends. However unfortunately the game does not let players other than the host unlock chefs and achievements which is lame, and the game is relatively short (easy) to beat / 3 star with a couple of competent friends. It's too easy on a couple levels honestly, we'd blow out the 3 star score by double or higher. I remember the first one being more difficult than this one even.And lastly there's not much replay value past the campaign unless you like Versus, because there's no endless modes or level creator, so we get what the devs gave us, and that's it.

author: Stelios.
review: At first, We really liked the idea of the game. Then after launching the game at the first time, the controls were unclear. It did not gave the option of playing with the mouse instead of keyboard (despite the simplicity of the mechanics). Furthermore, the level design itself was at least frustrating. Having moving ramps that pushed u to the other side while trying to chop things, or placing the ingredients  on the other side of the "map", having to throw around stuff, was at least frustrating for me. To conclude, the idea of the game, the graphics etc. were excellent. However, the level design, and controls were really frustrating. Would not recommend for impatient people.

author: superqam
review: I LOVE OVERCOOKED!! This is definitely a high-stress game which is great for some people, but not the best for others. It's a great first game for beginner PC players; controls are easy to learn. Characters are cute, story-mode isn't the most interactive but still cute, achievements are relatively easy to obtain. OC1 is definitely easier than OC2, but for first-time players, OC2 is a little more difficult. Game and levels are replayable. Story mode is somewhat short, but I love that there's expansions and arcade mode.

author: Leif is Life
review: I loved the first Overcooked. It busted my balls and caused many fights (and resolutions) between my girlfriend and me. This one feels like an upgrade in graphics and some nice additions like showing whether to fry or boil the ingredient, but otherwise it is a huge disappointment. We got DOUBLE the score of 3 stars on the first try on the first 6 levels. And playing on a big screen is pretty difficult, trying to see the shapes and objects...maybe I just need glasses? I have a feeling if I had played this one before Overcooked 1 then I would like them both better...but as it stands, I'll stick with the first one only.

author: n3kkun
review: You can't change the controls. At all. The "settings" page for controls just shows you a jpeg of what the buttons do. You can't customize any button at all. You're just locked in. It's extremely frustrating to play when you can't have custom controls. I have to manual code my controller to tell my trigger button to be dash, instead of allowing me to do it in the game. I hate the default controls and until I can change it I'm not going to recommend this game.Everything else about this game is 10/10.Audio is perfect for the setting. Characters and cute and fit in perfectly. There's an actual story now... But the controls... Completely ruin everything for me.EDIT: After reading the update that allows for custom controls, I am disappointed to find out it's only for the keyboard. Controller support is subpar. Do NOT buy this game if you need to use a controller to play. This is a keyboard game. Until I can edit my controls for my physical controller without editing any ini files or anything, I am going to continue to not recommend this game.Everything else, again, stellar. The new ways to cook. The new reciepies, the story mode works wonderfully and is cute and fun to engage in, multiplayer support works PERFECTLY. It's just the controls that make it not work for me.

author: Meyers07
review: GET A GAMEPAD IF YOU INTEND TO PLAY SOLO! CHARACTER SWITCHING IS NOT COMFORTABLE AT ALL. ALSO YOU NEED TO PLAY STORY MODE TO UNDERSTAND SOME BASIC GAME MECHANICS.Overcooked! 2 is... i skip the first because this is like the same game but more content and actual online mode It is reimagining of the classic Diner Dash with all new characters and simple but fun controls.It's so crazy that your first assignment is to learn to prepare food while a king accidentally bring the bread to life!Only minus is that no BOTS mode, you play solo, you have to control two cook, either alternating or using two part of a gamepad. And how the plot is random, like, after trying to fend off the living bread, you go to Japan?Don't know what to say about anything else anymore, but i give it 8/10

author: Spicebag
review: Having not played the first game I wasn't sure what to expect from this, everything I saw looked like it was going to stress me out. Instead what I got was a charming but difficult game that felt fair and fun in all the right ways. I played through the story mode with another player and it felt like it was just the right amount of challenge, you end up splitting the work and zoning out until you perfect whatever you're working on and it's very satisfying to complete a level. The only issues I have would be that the controls could be tighter, too often you've to cycle through items dropped in close proximity or you select the wrong table because your character turned slightly less than 1 degree of where you wanted them to be, also corner tables are annoyingly useless as you can't reach them. The game is far too short for how fun it is so I'd definitely recommend getting some DLC with it to make it last longer.
