author: RockstarCRO
review: I saw the game on sale and pulled the trigger. The game looked like it was casual and easy for anyone to jump into. Upon playing it further, I wasn‚Äôt too pleased with the game. As an avid gamer I didn‚Äôt mind it, but found the challenges a little bleak and boring after a while. The real reason I bought it was to bring friends and family who weren‚Äôt avid gamers into the mix. They found the first few levels easy enough, but later levels required too much skill with the controllers. Besides not being able to play with casual gamers who don‚Äôt like the game due to its complexity, I simply don‚Äôt find the premise of the game engaging. Overcooked 2 is a game based around completing orders as fast as possible. You (and possibly friends) are cooks in a kitchen tasked with fulfilling food orders. As far as the game premise goes, that‚Äôs about it. The levels change and provide different obstacles, but the premise stays the same throughout. You may play the campaign with up to four friends which is a huge positive for the game. The  is simple to figure and follow for veteran gamers. For the newcomers, it will take a lot of thinking and skill to move the character efficiently. The biggest difference between Overcooked 1 and 2 is that in two you‚Äôre able to throw the food. I‚Äôm not sure how sanitary that is, but it‚Äôs completely possible. Basic controls include character movement, movement boost (momentarily), interact, and throw. Different foods will require different methods of preparation. For example, fish will have to be cut up while rice will be put in a pot to boil. This was an interesting attempt to make the game dynamic. New players will have to take their time adapting to sequences, meaning they will have to learn how to put the recipes together. You can‚Äôt just throw a whole fish on a plate and hope by adding seaweed it will magically turn into sushi. You‚Äôll also need to be careful not to overcook things unless you‚Äôd like to start a fire in the kitchen. The  are suitable to the game‚Äôs premise. It is meant to be a little goofy and silly and the devs did deliver that with the visuals. Your kitchen may be between two air balloons, in the middle of a busy street, or simply in a regular kitchen. What I do like is that there will be random factors that potentially can interfere with your orders. During one level, there will be random civilians walking through your kitchen that‚Äôs interestingly situated in the middle of a walking path. I do like the goofyness of these situations. The  are okay for the most part, nothing too over the top in this realm. I do wish they changed the music or added dramatic sounds when the kitchen starts to light on fire. Overall, the game is alright. I‚Äôm not recommending it as it‚Äôs not my type of game. I was disappointed when a fewer older family members and friends found it difficult to get into. The controls were a little clunky (think counter tops on the corner that don‚Äôt release food properly) and the difficulty in some levels rose a little too quick. I would rather recommend buying another couch party game.

author: frontman12
review: 8.5/10Once I saw that Overcooked! 2 had online co-op, I was ready to dive in. Much praise has been rightly bestowed upon the first title in the series, but I don't have any pals close enough for local co-op play. Therefore, this is my first experience with the co-op cooking title.When we started the first level, I was overwhelmed. Where are the ingredients? How do I need to prepare each one? Oh, we have to wash the plates? What do I do with this burned food? However, soon afterwards we found a rhythm. Overcooked! 2's ability to induce that feeling of "flow" within the player is superb. You're constantly thinking about your next steps - for instance, as a general rule, if you are making dishes that require beef, you'll want to be cooking it constantly. As it is one of the slowest ingredients to prepare, it can bottleneck your orders. A lot has been said about Overcooked! 2's ability to force players to communicate with each other. I found this to be 100% the case. Not only is it prudent to create an efficient division of labor with your partner, but certain levels switch kitchen configurations in the middle, so you'll need to adapt or switch roles on the fly. Although apparently the previous game didn't allow players to throw ingredients, I found this to be a very exciting aspect of the gameplay. Sometimes, you'll be able to throw ingredients directly into preparation, such as throwing pasta across the map into boiling water. Although I recently played a similar game, No Heroes Here, Overcooked! 2 displays a bit more creativity in the tasks required of players and stays fresh much longer.Although I loved the gameplay, Overcooked! 2 still has a number of irritations. First of all, I felt that the overworld was completely extraneous. You and your co-op partner will drive around in a bus from level to level, and you may need to drive over switches in certain locations to raise a ramp to the next stage. I felt that this added nothing to the title, and would much rather the levels simply continue one after the other. However, perhaps driving the bus gives the players a break from the tension inherent in the co-op gameplay. The story itself was pretty silly as well, but I suppose it's difficult to devise a great reason for these two cooks to be creating dishes in hot air balloons and on rafts in river rapids.A few quality of life enhancements would be:1) The ability to choose when to begin a level once players are in the kitchen. Perhaps players could have a chat about where the ingredients are, and who will take which duties beforehand? Then, perhaps the level would begin once a player touches an ingredient or item in the map. We often restarted maps, especially when shooting for performance benchmarks, because the first few minutes of each run were spent getting oriented.2) The ability to restart a level from the results screen. Very often, we'd want to shoot for that third star, but then we'd need to load the overworld, select the level again, and then watch another loading screen before taking another shot.3) It would be nice to have a separate menu that explains how to unlock each of the Kevin bonus levels. We had to find a guide outside the game to figure out what we needed to do. The Kevin levels are often wilder and more creative than the main game kitchens, so it would be a pity for players to miss out on this content because they didn't know how to unlock it.Hopefully, none of this comes off as nit-picky - I had a wonderful time with this game, and my co-op partner and I picked up the "Surf n' Turf" DLC immediately after completing the main game. If you're looking for a true co-op game that demands communication and coordination, look no further.

The online function is the only reason we got it in the first place since the single player isn't nearly as enjoyable. Developers: FIX WHAT WE PAID FOR!!

author: cabato
review: My girlfriend and I really enjoyed playing the first Overcooked!, and were hoping that some of the issues with the first game would be resolved by this one.  We were disappointed.  I'll speak shortly about non-gameplay related issues.This game, like the first, should most definitely be played with a controller.  If you do not own a controller like myself, the game is nearly unplayable.  I found my character constantly dropping items immediately after I had picked them up, which is a big problem in such a time-oriented game.  The controls for keyboard in general also just feel less responsive and more "sticky" than the first game, which also had poor but mostly functional keyboard controls.  Dashing feels less responsive in particular, and while the throwing button is a nice addition, I feel like it is simply too obvious an addition to warrant much praise.The user interface and menus were of poor quality in the PC version of the first game, and although they received a slight visual upgrade they remain the same in functionality in the sequel.  Trying to navigate them is a bit of a mess, especially when adding multiple players.   This is only a slight annoyance and you will get used to the nonintuitive menus eventually.The audio for the game is similar to the first, and is appropriate for the setting.  No complaints here.The story was more of the same with the Onion King telling you what to do as you are his chefs at hand.  I never cared for the story as the writing was lackluster.  That may just be me though, I see that some other reviewers feel as if the story has improved.------------------GAMEPLAY-------------------Now, surely the developers had focused their efforts on the gameplay since the rest of the PC version of the game seemed so unpolished.  Unfortunately I found that this was not the case, and the laziness of the developers was clear here as well.  The first game had a very fun but simple mechanic for its core gameplay.  You take the ingredients, process them appropriately, then combine them on a plate for the customers.  This trend continues in Overcooked 2, and the simplicity of this system would be fine if the developers wanted to put their energy into thoughtful level design. Unfortunately, the most limiting factor for both games is the subpar level design.  Some levels in Overcooked 1 were terrible, and made me wonder if the developers played their own game.  There were also a decent quantity of wonderfully designed levels in Overcooked 1 that kept my attention for quite some time.  Unfortunately the core gameplay is so simple that even the well designed levels would entertain for only a short amount of time.  The game desperately needed a level editor, which I can not imagine would be hard to implement.  I'm not saying making a level editor is easy, but with the grid-based design of Overcooked it certainly seems more adaptable than many other games to that end.  Instead we got 2 overpriced DLCs, one of which was completely AWFUL and the other was barely acceptable.  Now it seems that the developer has no plans to add a level editor, perhaps because they are afraid people will make levels that blow theirs out of the water so no one will buy their DLC.  They could solve that issue by adding new mechanics with DLC, but that would require some actual work and thought.  Unfortunately I did not make it far enough to see all the levels in this game as I refunded it, but it seemed to be the same mix-mash quality of some good, some terrible.While I'm sad that I didn't make it far enough in this game to enjoy some of the more well-designed levels, the game simply did not grab me like the first did, even with its glaring issues.  The core gameplay is so basic that it makes the developers seem extremely lazy when the rest of the game is so trite.  To add to this point, the game is ridiculously easy and provides no challenge to moving through the campaign.  This gives the player absolutely no sense of reward/progression.  The developer has plans to address this with the NG+ update, but for the game to be of such poor quality on release in this regard as well as the other issues indicates the developer is not the be trusted. If you want to play this game, just pick up the first one on sale sometime and have your fun there.

review: Ok so this game is disappointing, yes I got all the stars but it was not really funny to get them.The level design is really boring, instead of making recipes more complex, we could have really fancy stuff (for example ramen :boil the egg, cook the noodles, grill the pork, prepare the soup ...) that could have required a lot of cooperation to be optimised. they decided to make the level design just harder.You have to walk on edges, drive platforms, use portals etc... it's not funny and with the unperfect controls it's sometimes really anoying.The multiplayer is total crap, bad servers, no competitive mode and levels are not funny.I can't recommend this game to anybody that played overcooked 1 and if you didn't then go play overcook 1.This game is like a bad extension of the first one.

author: Electronic Toaster
review: My playtime is low, but I played longer with a friend on their computer local coop. It wasn‚Äôt a long time.Overcooked seems to place two layers of complexity over the game. There are the foods you must cook. And there are the kitchen environments themselves.Both of these things change rapidly between levels. This was our experience in the story mode.Perhaps I was wrong to think that the story mode would offer a tutorial. I think that it was a tutorial technically. But if that‚Äôs what the game is like when it is stripped down, I am not sure how complex it will be later on. The rate at which it introduced new elements was ridiculous.Local coop games are supposed to be fun because chaos is generated via the many players trying t o work together. It is supposed to come from the players trying to play the game. The game itself is not supposed to be completely chaotic. I played with one other player. Each level starts with you being thrown into a kitchen with all the ingredients and cooking stations you need to use just randomly placed around the space. The timer starts. So you spend the first minute or two trying to figure out where anything actually is. This could take longer. For example, we both sat there for minutes sometimes trying to figure out where the plates were. Then you need to start making meals that are at the top of the screen. Some of these will be completely new to you. Then, you need to start figuring out how to even walk around the environment, because you are locked into small spaces or passageways and with moving conveyor belts. Then you have to figure out what some of the implements do because you might not have seen one of them before. Then you need to figure out how to divide the tasks up between the two players to be in any way efficient. Time is up!You can make any game chaotic very easily. Why don‚Äôt you just have the controls all randomly change. That‚Äôs fun. And chaotic. Or maybe the screen turns black sometimes. Or you are now controlling a different character to before. Or maybe you controls stop working sometimes. Why don‚Äôt you have a friend slap you in the face randomly. Imagine playing a difficult game with those things happening. I honestly think dealing with those things might be easier than the type of chaos given to you in Overcooked. Because at least the vast majority of the game is stable. These interruptions are momentary interruptions occurring to a generally stable game. This isn‚Äôt all the elements of the game in random order like Overcooked 2.And that is the thing that is important. Stability. Repetition. Some element of the game needs to be somewhat similar to the earlier bit for improvement to occur. Not even improvement, just ability to play the game. There are limits to human concentration. It is not unlimited. A person cannot see every ingredient and station on the screen, organise a completely different plan in order to get to each station for each recipe, alter the plan to deal with the particular hazards of the stage, develop a way of breaking that workload into parts based on proximity for each player, and then execute that plan in the time limit given. Somebody might say ‚Äòbut isn‚Äôt that the fun part not being able to do it in time?‚Äô Well then I ask you, what is the part that makes something beyond human concentration limits fun? Is it the fact that you gain a score? Is it the fact that you do it with another person. Is it the fact that you do in on a computer screen? Well let‚Äôs invent a fun game according to the parameters.Get together some friends and find a paragraph in a language none of you know how to speak. Post that paragraph in a chat window. You now have 3 minutes to decipher it.  For each second less than the three minutes it take you to decipher the paragraph you get 1 point. There, I invented a fun game. It doesn‚Äôt cost anything and anybody can play anywhere in the world, as long as they have a phone and an internet connection. If you actually manage to gain any knowledge in that time limit, it will even help you get better next time, which is more than seems likely for Overcooked 2.Maybe the game becomes more understandable later. But I honestly couldn‚Äôt cope with the early stuff.I don‚Äôt recommend this game, because the chaos is in the wrong place, and it is entirely too high to deal with using my human brain.(I looked up some videos on youtube, and I see some levels that were nowhere near as obnoxious as the ones in the story, so maybe story mode is an terrible choice for a beginner. Though I don't know where they got their levels from.)

author: Bloomy
review: Ive had this game ever since 2019, and since then I've experienced trouble with playing with my friends. I often get kicked out of the game while playing with others or my friends get kicked out. Playing arcade public, the matchmaking takes at least 20 minutes.  I've contacted the devs and they've tried helping me resolve the issue several times, but the problem seems to be the game. Its not my internet, and its not my computer. All other games on Steam seems to work perfectly on my computer except overcooked 2. It seems as if the devs has abandoned Oc2 completely and now focuses entirely on "All you can eat" instead, because they know they did some major screw ups with OC2 that seems to be irreversible. Or else the problem would have been fixed by now. The game is best played with controller, its not PC friendly. Just the general scrolling through the menu and user experience is so laggy on PC and keyboard. It's very surprising that they haven't allowed voice coms in this game, considering its so dependent on teamwork. Not even a chat. Instead of making the original OC2 better, they developed "All you can eat" and enabled voice comms there, something that should have been in OC2 in the first place. They also charge handsomely for "All you can eat" for basic functions that were missing in OC2. Also they've a discord in which you can join to find someone to play with, because their normal in-game matchmaking system takes you nowhere :)

author: Levi
review: Overcooked! 2 is fun, but it has (mostly fixable) problems.Unlocking chefs on Overcooked! 2 that we've already unlocked in Overcooked! 1 isn't fun. Overcooked! 1 chefs should have been unlocked from the beginning of Overcooked! 2 with brand new chefs to unlock.Unlocking Kevin stages by doing specific things in specific levels, while those things aren't told to the player isn't fun. It makes the game a grindy chore, and we can just look up how to unlock them online. We replay the game over and over to have fun, not to get maybe/maybe not unlock the level we want to play.Bugs that can completely ruin what you're doing and force you to restart a level are not fun. I don't know how many times we've permanantly lost a plate or finished dish or ingredient several minutes into a long level.The Star score-system isn't fun -- it's too easy, but neither is a New Game+ mode that just gives you a 4th, unreasonably high score-star to beat. Getting 2650 in 1-1 is unreasonable and doesn't feel at all skill-based. 2000 should have been the original 3-Star.

author: Botty Botsworth
review: First off, I'm going to say I with I could a neutral review. See as how I cant but cant recommend this game, I have to give a negative review.I bought this game because my friends want to play with it. It is not my type of game simply for the controls. All I want to do is use my mouse to click on things. Far too often I find myself standing in front of an object and picking up the item next to it and it could easily be solved simply with a wads movement and letf/right clicking.That's my small nit pick though.I dont enjoy the game simply because it's not my type of game. That's all, I find the gameplay loop boring. It was fun for 30 mins or so but every round is combine X ingredients in Y ways to make Z with slight obstacles from the environment. It's one of those games if I picked it up for 5-10 dollars I would be alright with it but for 25 I cant justify the purchase.Like I said though, that's all me. This game wasn't designed for my tastes. I just wanted to throw in my two cents on the controls and the gameplay loop. If you have fun with it, which a lot seem to, then that's all that matters.

author: ‰∏úÂåó‰∫∫Á¶èÊòü
review: This is not a game that is fun for too many hours, I am done with it in 3 hours. To be honest, single player mode was very boring. Also, I try to play with my friend who was in another country, but the control setting was all messed up and I couldn't even move the character in the game. This is crappy and not worth the price. I will never change my comment unless this problem is fixed. I have never written a review for any games so far, but this experience made me want to say something. If you are in for the "multiplayer" mode, this game is not developed enough. I would fix the bugs before I sell something like this. Overall, there is also a lack of variety in the games. Even with all the updates. the control setting was confusing. In addition, games like don't starve together cost about the same as this game and that one is more joyful to play.

author: Souler
review: After playing for a while I have to admit it is legitimately good. It's more like a great vehicle for co-op fun, than it is mechanically satisfying by itself. And that's fine. People say anything is fun co-op, but some games are designed specifically to enable you having fun between yourselves (like a ton of board games), and this is one of them. It causes synchronized chaos, and you just let go and revel in it. Or you scramble to succeed, and laugh at yourself either for somehow doing it right or failing horribly.Great level design/setups too.

We tried with a third person and the results were the same. Requesting a refund.

author: Batchi
review: I lost my entire save due to an overcooked steam update. Now I can't get it back and I'm not about to play through the entire game once just to get to the actually interesting part - NG+.  Three stars is so easy to get on each level that you'd have to play blindfolded to get less than that. I emailed the dev team asking if there was a way to get a save game that has the first three stars already complete but I never got a response.  Guess I'm not gonna play this game again.

author: Voerman
review: When I shut off the game and my first reaction is "Let's write a negative review" it's not enjoyable. The movement is super floaty and inaccurate, the level design is obviously supposed to be obnoxious but certainly not to the degree I'm really willing to put up with.We did finish the game, but I was barely enjoying a moment of it.It's like Mario Party without the charm of the mini-games and it still ruins friendships.Don't @ me.

author: Son of Gloin
review: I got into this game after playing through the first Overcooked game with my SO. At first, I didn't appreciate this game and thought that it'd lost some of its charm from the first game. The first game encouraged multiple ways to solve a problem rather than lock players into a certain strategy, but the devs continually provide free DLC for this game and whenever anything's announced, my girlfriend and I eagerly await its release and then play the game to completion. I will say, the four star mode can be frustrating at times, but for the fun levels (which I'd say is about 70% of them), it's worthwhile and not too difficult if you've been playing for a while. I'd give this game a solid 10/10, and it makes for a good party game to play with beginners as well as a game that encourages and rewards mastery (when achieved with a partner).

author: <‚Ñ¢[-=> Cookiez <=-]‚Ñ¢>
review: Overcooked is a kitchen simulator game where you play as a cook. Your objective is to cook in a battleground and fulfill the orders the customers send to you.Gameplay-wise, best with controller. Pickup/drop with A, throw/action with X. There is no jump.There doesn't seem to be a way to conduct chat. You can only emoji to indicate your intention. This is no different from playing with an AI.Conclusion, Overcooked 2 is a no. The game actually requires a 2nd player to be fun. It is not fun on your own.1. Well-Advertised1. Fundamentally BoringIt's just an infinite loop of cook and repetitive delivering.

author: Cheezabel
review: I love Cooking Games.I love Co-op games.I enjoy both console & pc gaming for different reasons & the corresponding gameplay.The only reason I didn't buy the previous Overcooked was because it didn't have online co-op.So I was pretty excited to hear that OC2 had that feature.I was worried about mouse & keyboard controls but it turns out it's ok. What I didn't expect was that this game would have such terrible level design.The greatest sin for a game is to expose their players to having absolutely no fun at all.Conveyor belts, disappearing floor tiles, magic portals (seriously?) were apparently introduced in this opus to um, increase the challenge? You have a couple of minutes to prepare a seamingly neverending string of orders but most of the time you & your partner are just standing idle because well... you're just literally stuck & waiting for that floating tile to please be so kind as to let you resume your activities.Most of the time, you're only halfway through the timer and you know perfectly well that you'll fail that level, so you just restart or... well just go and play something else.So there you go, in Overcooked 2, you don't actually cook, there's no specific goal (always an infinite string of orders, doesn't really matter if you're chopping meat or potatoes) and so as a result there's absolutely no challenge at all, you're just left with the horrid obstacles.Strangely enough the Story Mode is exactly the same whereas you're alone controlling 2 characters or you are 2 players controlling each 1 character (played until stage 3-5). This should give you a hint as to how not very deeply the gameplay.This feels like a mini-game that got its own spin-off - a lot of features are just cosmetics & have zero game design value.The Chef you control is just a skin, recipes hare just skins of other recipes, there's no bonus powers, nothing to unlock apart from stages, the only variety you'll find is in where the floating tiles, moving stations and gaps on the floor are placed.Like I said, not recommended.Play a mobile game if you like cooking, play a Mario game if you like console co-op.

author: bert
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Gshadow5
review: "Music in the background by Stuart Mitchell YEEAAAH!!! TOAST!!!" As the Undead  raise from grave oven, they begin wonder what's racket? As someone said french toast, All heck break lose. YEAH TOAST!! "Ticky tick tap tap"  YEAH TOAST!! rap raddled tip tip tack". All sudden onion king comes, begin summoning his royal chiefs, they begin making toast YEAH TOAST!!, YEAH TOAST!!!. Then they celebrating with Toast.(giggles)Overcook 2 is a great little party game that you can play with four friends off or online in crazy work environment, It just a simple fun cute game that makes the best meal in a arcade style for the best high-score. It also haves remote-play together that if, someone have a bought it they can join for free. Some of the level layout is very challenging to complete to get 3 starts, but replay ability help home your skill to reach  top score. I say it really fun for the whole family and with great friends to boot.I hope the Developers continue to make more and add DLC in the future as it just a funny great game. One things I'd love to see if they add a level map layout for a community to create maps for everyone to try and win a prize to put their idea in a future game.

author: Rangerous09
review: Overcooked 2 is a sequel that offers new recipes and levels on the plate and still retains its charming and chaotic style. With its new online mode, distant friends can now enjoy this title to their heart's content, although the ultimate experience is local, something that loved ones will appreciate.The GoodThe best cooperative arcade cooking game you can find.Improved control precision.Highly polished soundtrack.Online play.The BadThe game's story continues to feel unnecessary.Lack of more educational game modes.

author: Dayne
review: Cooking simulator for 1-4 players. Throughout the campaigns/maps you will get more recipes, tools and kitchens that are also available in the arcade mode.The achievements require finishing all of the campaigns, getting 3 stars and performing tasks x amount of times. It can become quite tedious if you're playing the game by yourself. Guides are available, expect about 30+ hours. DLC is required.This game shines when you are playing with your friends. Alone you control and switch between two characters, which can be both challenging and boring. If you're a fan of cooking simulators this might be the game for you, otherwise I strongly recommend that you play with your friend(s).

author: LooseyGoosey
review: Overcooked 2 is a cooperative cooking simulation game that is sure to test your teamwork and coordination skills. Players work together to prepare and serve meals to customers in a variety of settings, each with its own unique challenges. The game features a wide variety of recipes and ingredients, as well as new kitchens and levels to unlock. The graphics are cute and colorful, and the sound effects and music are engaging and add to the overall experience.One of the strengths of Overcooked 2 is the ability to play with friends and family. The game is designed to be played with 1-4 players and the fun comes from the chaos of working together in a kitchen. The levels can be challenging and require players to work together and communicate effectively. The game also includes a variety of game modes, including a new online multiplayer mode that allows players to team up with friends from around the world.Overall, Overcooked 2 is a fun and entertaining game that is perfect for families and groups of friends. It's a challenging game that requires teamwork and communication to be successful. It's a great game to play together in a party or just to enjoy some laughs with friends and family.

author: Burdee
review: Oh, Overcooked my beloved. This game has provided my friends and I with many hours of fun, laughs, frustration, panic, and gratification. When I'm playing Overcooked 2, I feel the push to be as efficient as possible in every single aspect of my play, and its deceptively simple mechanics allow you to improve your skills in a way that feels incredibly fun to me. My friends have taken to calling me the "Michelin Star Chef" because of my love for the strategy and speed that the game requires.I will say that one frustrating part of online play for my friends and I has been desyncing in the online multiplayer experience. It's hard to say whether or not it's because of our respective internet connections, as none of us were having any other internet issues outside of in game, but we all found significant issues with inputting commands accurately. Since the game is so fast paced, this can be a significant setback, especially when pursuing the four-star challenges which you unlock after beating the game. I haven't noticed these problems when playing offline.Overall, it's a great game. Play it with your friends, play it with your family, get mad at each other, give each other high fives when you do well. And above all, keep cheffin'.

So far it has been our favorite online co-op game :) This game is sooo chaotic , sometimes (almost always ahahah) me and my bf were yelling at each other, and laughing, and OMG, the characters are soooo coool and funnyyyy! We are still trying to find games like this one but unfortunately, nothing works in both Windows and MacOS. I wish I could make myself forget this game and play it again :(((I hope, there will be Overcooked 3 with different levels and characters. I am sure that there bunch of people who would like to play more! I did not buy Overrcooked 1 ecause the levels are the same with the Overcooked 2. So please, make new different levels and not the same!Brifely: better to buy Overcooked 2 than Overcooked 1. You will enjoy :))

review: Servers are dead - there's no one to play with online - so I had to uninstall the whole thing. I know there's a story mode but I like playing with other people so if your intent to buy this game is to play with others - than don't there's not many people playing.It's cute though, maybe one day when there's more hype and people are online I'll come back.It's also no single-player friendly with a keyboard. I highly recommend a controller (which I don't have one) because there's a lot of multitasking to do and I particularly couldn't play on my own. Despite my negative review, I would recommend it though if you have friends, solo, not so much.

review: - DIFFICULTY -üî≤ Not difficulty basedüî≤ Easy‚òëÔ∏è Normal‚òëÔ∏è Hardüî≤ Insanity- GRAPHICS -üî≤ Pixelsüî≤ Badüî≤ Graphics don't matter in this game‚òëÔ∏è Goodüî≤ Beautifulüî≤ Masterpiece- MUSIC -üî≤ Bad‚òëÔ∏è Musicüî≤ Goodüî≤ Beautiful- STORY -üî≤ This game has no storyüî≤ Very mind numbing‚òëÔ∏è Available if people want itüî≤ Well writtenüî≤ Epic story- PRICE -üî≤ N/Aüî≤ Underpriced‚òëÔ∏è Perfect priceüî≤ Could be cheaperüî≤ Overpricedüî≤ Stupidly priced- REQUIREMENTS -üî≤ You can run it on a calculator‚òëÔ∏è Mid Specüî≤ High endüî≤ Top of the Range- LENGTH -üî≤ Very short (0 - 3 hours)‚òëÔ∏è Short (3 - 15 hours)üî≤ Average (15 - 50 hours)üî≤ Long (50 - 90 hours)üî≤ Extremely long (90 - 110 hours)üî≤ Continuous- FUN -üî≤ Deadüî≤ Hard to enjoyüî≤ Repetitive‚òëÔ∏è Actually pretty amusingüî≤ Ride of your life- REPLAYABILITY -üî≤ Noneüî≤ Only for achievementsüî≤ If you wait a few months‚òëÔ∏è Definitelyüî≤ Infinitely replayable- WORTH BUYING -üî≤ Noüî≤ Wait for sale‚òëÔ∏è Yesüî≤ Free‚è∞ How long to beat Overcooked 2:- Main Story - 43¬Ω Hours- Main + Extras - 83 Hours- Completionist - 137 Hours‚≠ï - Conclusion -:Overcooked 2 is a great co-op cooking game. author: Sprasshu
review: Bought it specifically because support for it was added to a multiworld randomizer called Archipelago that me and my friends constantly take part of. I owned the first game and enjoyed it with friends, even though we were constant denied making any further progress because the game kept skill checking us. Figured the second game would be more of the same really. Don't fix what isn't broken and all that, but to Overcooked 2's credit, I didn't feel as challenged with needing perfect scores in every level to progress, which definitely helps the pacing of it. There was also quite a bit of variety with what there was to cook as well, so it never really felt stale to play either. Story and soundtrack are whatever.Recommended if you have the friends for it because solo, this game is a miserable bloody experience. Feels like with some levels that perfect 3 star scores aren't manageable without some mates helping you out, but I did manage to unlock the final level playing it solo without having to replay too many levels, which is something I couldn't be bothered to do with the first game admittedly. Probably never gonna pick up the DLC though, base game is enough mileage as is.

author: stratakarius
review: Even though they aren't exactly the same game, I find this better than plate up if only for the lack of failure conditions. In plate up if you run out of time, you're done, which gets really old really fast. Not only that, but the restaurant layout changes every time so you can't even practice to get better. Plate up is better in that you can move everything else around though rather than relying on the counter setup designed by the devs. Plate up also lets you chop on any counter too which is a huge plus.Overall I definitely recommend this game to anyone who's into this genre.

author: Nagaram
review: This game is very much saved my relationship. It's heavy need for team work is truly a make or break for the relationships that we hold and strengths bonds or cuts loose ends. Fortunately for us, in the year it took us to beat this game, our bond has never been stronger and we are looking forward to our wedding and whatever challenges lie beyond... so long as it's not a moving platform level, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• those.

author: ashwood_blaize
review: I'm absolutely in love with this game, my entire experience with this game has been nothing but positive. I've tried it out with different groups of people and the dynamics are different every time. I love thinking of ways to make the process more efficient, and the constant problem solving scratches a specific itch in my brain. I have way more hours of this game spread across different friend accounts when we play on their version instead of mine (I'm probably at 200 hours cumulatively), and it's been a blast every time. The concept is fairly simple and it's easy to get the hang of. I can't recommend it enough!Just make sure your friends are all at around the same gamer skill level, otherwise things get frustrating really fast if you're in it to win it. Keeping multiple tabs open in your brain is very important while playing!The story aspect is a little meh but I don't mind at all because the gameplay more than makes up for it. I got this game in a bundle, and although I adore this game, I would definitely wait for a sale to get it OR get it with a bundle with its DLCs (Season Pass for sure).Rating the game modes:-Main story: Classic, lots of variety in both dishes and difficulty level to shake things up as you progress through the game-Free update: Amazing, great addition and also a lot of variety-Carnival of Chaos: It's alright, but nothing to snuff at. Similar to the above-Night of the Hangry Horde: Be prepared for the long haul, and one little mistake can ruin the whole thing. Personally not a big fan because the pastries are right in your face and there's much more panicking than the original gameplay, but I'll play it with the right people-Campfire Cook-Off: I am not a fan of this one. I know you're using ingredients found in a typical camp setup, but the ingredients do not look good which throws off the whole vibe of the game, and the backpack concept, while interesting, sucks so much in practice.I do not own any other DLCs, but I heard Surf 'n Turf was not a big fan favorite either. Overall, it's super great and I've had an amazing time with it!

author: CreedanceFTBBL
review: My friends had been looking for new group games to play and one of them had found and suggested we give Overcooked 2 a try. I wanna preface that this review will only be about base Overcooked 2 and not include any of the DLC, but I am including the seasonal update as it was free added content. I'll also preface that we haven't played one so the story wasn't the main focus, but are interested in picking it up. This is also a 3 player co-op experience and merely from my perspective.Base Game CampaignThe game eases you in with some easy levels, where the main focus is learning to communicate/cooperate with the other players and throwing out some kitchen layouts that are the basis for the evolving kitchens and situations you'll be working with. Each level section focuses on learning one recipe and mastering how to best assemble and complete that order as fast and convenient as possible. Towards the end of section 1, dish washing is introduced as well as some of my favorite levels, evolving levels. I describe evolving levels as kitchens where over time the kitchen layout completely transforms like a phase change. At times even changing what foods and recipes are requested by guests. As the game advances, kitchens get more creative and diverse, challenging your groups ability to communicate and get the job done. I will say we also forced ourselves to get 3 stars on all levels our first go through and oh man, that was tense at times. A lot of fun though, lots of moments of just breaking out into hysterical laughter because we chopped a tomato and then yeet it accidentally into the ether for no reason. As well as the honored tradition when possible at the end of a level of sending your cute little chef off the map to an untimely death. And the final level is a real great playback of everything you've learned throughout the game. And as of now we are going back for 4 stars on all the main story levels and no idea if we'll reach that, but it'll definitely be a good time.Seasonal UpdatesThe season updates were the 2nd or 3rd extra content that we tried and they were overall enjoyable, if not at that point a little too simple at times. The added recipes are for the most part fun, I find Ramen to be one of the more satisfying recipes, Hot Chocolate is different and fun, but then you get fruit cakes and fruit platters which are literally reduxed cake and salad. But for free content and an extra 6 or so mini campaigns it's definitely a nice addition to an already tons of fun game.KevinOh boy. Kevin levels are....ok I guess? All Kevin levels are the same recipe. And its geared to be harder, which makes sense because they're hidden bonus levels right? Well, maybe I'd feel different if my group had one more person at the time, but 3 person co-op Kevin levels mean 1 player is left alone with a majority of work to do. And while i'm sure it was intended for 4players, it is sooooo rough in a 3 man at times. One person frustrated and having to do everything, while the other two are stuck watching someone else play while the have the monotonous task of taking turns chucking ingredients or serving. Not really fun for anyone involved.Arcade/SingleplayerOvercooked 2 is not a single player game. However with that said, you need something satisfying to do for 30 mins, singleplayer is fine and can be alright. But not for the main game experience. Arcade can be done solo or with friends. It's also ok, randomly picks a campaign map. Nothing special but it can break up monotony. In ConclusionOvercooked 2 is a great multiplayer experience that even if you've beaten, its fun going through with a new party. The maps are really creative, the star scores are a real decent challenge but not too frustratingly hard. And the dozens of fun chef characters you unlock along the way make the game really charming and a good time to be had by all. The game is definitely best with at least 2 or more people. 4 player being the best set up. So if your group is looking for a new party game challenge, pick up Overcooked 2. It'll be worth the purchase! Not to mention, it's almost always on sale!

author: Dekka443
review: This game is exceptional. It's easy for friends and family to learn but most importantly very coop/hand-eye-coordination-intensive and great fun. Its amazing library of levels keeps it fresh and replayable, and its high frequency of amazing sales makes it affordable entertainment. With the addition of remote play, everyone can join in the fun and compete against or cooperate with each other. Extremely recommended to play with friends and family, although solo playing is supported. Recipes are fun and fair. With the controls fixed (you can now edit the controls. Some old comments complained that the controls are awkward and you're unable to customize them), it becomes instantaneously better. The music is a banger, and I would give this game a total of 5/5. I hope you agree with my opinion and consider purchasing it if you are interested :)

author: GiraffaRappa
review: This game is the best. I played it with friends and it was chaotic fun. I saw some reviews that said that people were having trouble playing single player... I found it to be super easy and I was able to beat the game in about 10 or 12 hours. I think that it is easy enough if you are ambidextrous or split brained, and can divide tasks so that each chef is active at all times when the other is running around. It does take some alternating, and you can't expect to stay in one place the whole time. I really enjoyed this game and still pick it up to play solo or online multiplayer. The multiplayer community can either be really nice (sharing gestures to encourage each other) and other times the online community can be kinda rude and rage quit if they don't think you're keeping the pace. It really depends, and I think that can be somewhat discouraging to newer or less skilled players who might not have a friend to play with. Overall, I love the variety of the levels and the bite sized challenges. It was well worth the money I had paid when it was at a slight discount.

author: denver_broncos06
review: Really well made, what quirks there are in the game are user only.  Trying to get used to the mechanic and the challenges are challenging enough to be fun even after having to do it over 20 times.  I can tell that all the mechanics in the game are operable and the Developers did a great job all around.  Even down to just the right balance of sound volumes and ambiance.  From the sound of the bus low idle, and roaming hum to the background music.  Too many games over do it and background music volumes are too loud from the start, even though they have adjustments for the sounds, the importance of getting this right from the start is crucial.  Overcooked! 2 is really well made, so a big thanks and congratulations are in order for making a game I enjoy with my family.

So it gets extra points for that.

author: papercranegamer
review: 4/5 -- Overcooked is one of the very best co-op game experiences you can have. My friend and I love the challenge of the gameplay so much that we also got the season pass and are working on getting max scores on every level. Most levels feel like a fantastic blend of chaos and strategy. A few of the levels suffer from some too-random gimmicks that I'm not a fan of, but the amazing-good levels definitely make up for those elements.

author: YourSignifigantBother
review: If you like your friends sometimes but also want to yell at them for not just throwing you the god-forsaken cabbage, then this is a great game for you! I had a blast of silently breathing at my partner chef for telling me to not do something before proceeding to do the exact thing and get run over in traffic, thus losing the fish n' chips we made in the progress. Anyhow, very fun to get semi-mad at your friends with and to use as an excuse to poke fun at them, and of course, to tell them to just. throw. the. cabbage.

author: Neha >3
review: The game was well designed and fun. In my opinion, one of the best local co-op games there is. The levels were creative and the concept simple yet with challenging twists, Only thing was, it was quite laggy on my computer, though that is an issue on my side. I would also like the ability to skip levels (after a certain amount of tries) as it gets quite hard later in the game. I'm not sure if this feature already exists? Otherwise, gameplay was entertaining and without problem.

author: Selachimorpha
review: Recommended for 3-4 players. Co-ordination is key! Just like irl kitchen, communicate with your friends constantly to avoid confusion.Some tips for 3-star and 4-star ratings...Just one player: You control 2 characters. Sometimes confusing, but relatively easier to organise tasks.Two players: Recommended for experienced players. Might be a good choice to try for 4-star ratings.Three players: Also recommended. Just enough people to get 3-star and 4-star ratings!Four players: Make 1 player control 2 characters. Minimum scores for higher star ratings will increase but it probably wouldn't matter. Though, you've got to be INSANELY co-ordinated for this strategy...

author: Xenalia
review: What can I say? After 57 hours and an attempt to play this duo with two different individuals it wasn't until I assembled an elite 4 stack of unrelenting pain and suffering that I am my friends really excelled at this game. We screamed, we yelled, we even cried a time or two, but now we go through the levels like we're back in chapter 1 of the main scenario. Overcooked 2 is that special kind of game that either makes or breaks your teamwork, coordination, and persistence to complete the goal no matter how insane the path. I for one love playing this game with my buddies and IMO for most levels 4 people is best. If at first you don't succeed retry and retry again. My best advice, whenever you can yeet a loaf of bread and dome your buddy off a precarious path, DO IT. ‚ô•

author: Lily
review: I was so excited to get this game three years ago, but I'm still halfway done with the levels and I just don't want to come back to it. This game has a lot going for it and I want to love it but I can't. The main problem with overcooked 2 (and the original) is that it feels too gimmicky, often taking away from the quite solid main gameloop of efficiently managing a kitchen - sometimes it wants to be a platformer, sometimes a sports game, sometimes a puzzle, all of which feel too random and distracting. A natural way to raise the difficulty might be to have more complex dishes. Instead, dishes aren't varied enough to keep it interesting and the challenge is working with a specific map layout, which will be completely unrelated to the next. When I get three stars on a level, my reaction is relief at not having to play again. Case in point: The level selection shouldn't be practically a game of its own, the gimmick here is more annoying than immersive. I just want to see all the missing stars quickly and pick a level.

review: Love it. Me and my bf play together and it's the most grating game but it leaves you all triumphant when you get the 3 stars. When you aim to get 3 starts for all of them you tend to get the hang of how to cook one thing properly, then another thing gets thrown into the mix and it throws you off. COOK THE RICE FIRST and STOP BUMPING INTO EACH OTHER. Even when you establish one person to chop and serve and the other person to cook and plate up you end up doing a mix because of the DAMN SLIDING PLATFORMS THAT STOP YOU FROM DOING ANYTHING YOU'RE JUST STOOD THERE LIKE A LIMP LETTUCE AND PORTALS THAT YOU KEEP ACCIDENTALLY GOING IIIN AND OOUT OF JUST AS YOU HAVE A PLATE READY TO SERVE AND THE CLOCKS RUNNING OUT AND THOSE FREAKIN DISAPPEARING STAIRS THAT END YOUR DISAPPOINTING LIFE JUST AS THE MEATS ABOUT TO START BURNING AND IT SCREWS THE REST OF IT UP. And why can't the customers just walk that lil extra step to get their damn food?! IT'S RIGHT IN FRONT OF YOU! This game makes me sympathetic to the Lord Ramsey.Overall, highly recommend. It's made my relationship with my bf stronger and gives us something to do when we're not around each other, do not recommend to play with anyone who gets you angered though.

author: Zenzimon
review: My favourite co-op game of all time. It plays simple but it takes a lot of team planning/organising to pull through the harder levels and getting a level right is deeply satisfying. Later levels can be overwhelming at first but finding the groove of each level comes with practice, but not in a tedious way. Figuring out the best strategy for a level is a bit of a puzzle, but the good kind where the solution becomes increasingly obvious the more you play a level (save perhaps getting 4* on harder levels, but by the time you reach that point it's not going to be an issue).Don't play this one alone (besides perhaps the tutorial). It's more tedious than anything else. 2-4 players is where it's at. Thankfully this game has online and local co-op.Overcooked 2 is a particularly stimulating game, so you will get fired up playing this. This is not a bad thing unless you're intending to go to sleep, nap or relax soon.

review: A great game with great levels. The end game is tough, really tough, and I had to try hard for a whole hour for some levels. DLCs are great too. The best part is when you play with someone else. It's a whole new gameplay and the levels became more nervous and faster. I recommend this game to anyone who love the first Overcooked and love cooking. However, the game doesn't have a great variety of food compare to the number of levels. But there are some interesting mechanisms.

Wish there was a mode to make it harder so it would become more of a challenge. For now it will sit in our library.

Fun times!We've played both games and it gives us a fun activity to do together. We even bought the DLC when on sale which are actually well worth it. I highly recommend this game as the textures have vastly improved since the first game and /hey have decidedly made a better investment in music this time round which has added real flavour to the experience. Solid 8.5/10

author: George.jl
review: Overcooked (1 and 2) are one of the most fun and frantic couch coop experiences in gaming.These games and especially the second installment manage to blend together ease-of-play with difficult-to-master stages, while staying fun and limiting frustration (not between players though!).An awesome, robust and simple design, that works flawlessly!Also, the soundtrack is pretty awesome, leading to some tunes getting stuck on your head for days.Although I don't like the strategy of Team17 with the "All You Can Eat" game, I must say that it's a must buy.It goes on sale pretty often, so grab it then, for about 15 hours of fun (more with DLCs)!A 10/10 for a coop experience. Simply one of the best.

author: TroubleTemptress
review: So there I was joyfully playing overcooked 2 when the credits suddenly rolled and my heart sank, 17 hours of game play and it was over and I was like wtf just happened even taking into account the elusive 4th stars which for the most part require super human agility to obtain. My disappointment was soon overcome as I had purchased the gourmet edition and the extra levels really make up for the quick main game. This is way easier than overcooked one and has some really fun recipes, the themes are fun and the quirks that make a level challenging. Its a go to game for casual short gaming with friends, the co-op mode here is awesome and really does work. The versus and arcade mode however are always pretty empty :(  There are many worse ways to waste some hours.

author: FrozenDogma
review: Fun Game, big improvement on the original. Good art and improved graphics. Smooth controls and throw feature adds an extra skill ceiling that is rewarding. Story is eh, but the game is about the cooking not the story. The cooking is fun and there are many dishes. The satisfaction comes from rapidly completing orders and getting a hot streak point bonus on turned in dishes. The game can be frustrating at times when the levels gimmick hasn't been fully understood and a plan hasn't been made. I would have appreciated more levels with dedicated stations for each player before ramping up the cooperation difficulty. Overall 9/10

author: lcoelho1997
review: BEST WITH FRIENDS!!!This is one of those games, where you need to play this co-op either with spilt/remote play or online multiplayer. Look, it is possible that you can beat this game on your own but unfortunately i don't have very fast hand reflexes when it comes to switching between the two identical characters.Communication and teamwork is key. Like Uno, this game can test/ruin friendships. This game also has a side dish of Rage Quitting. (I have dealt with it one too many times where that didn't have to be the case.)Let's talk about the game: -  Quality & gameplay is super smooth. - I'm someone who relies on a controller and Gamepad play-ability was nice compared to the first Overcooked game. - There was a variety of levels and characters to choose from in various modes and were decently priced.  - Also why does this game make me hungry? The food looks so good in this game!!!A couple of minor con's; The DLC levels, I wish there are incorporated in the story mode because they were very hard to find. Also, the plot for the story mode was pointless. Felt it need to have more context or not be there at all.This is a game where you will either like it or hate it. Overall, a very solid game. When I purchased this game, I didn't know that there was combined version of the first two games. The controls on the controller in the first game was difficult for me. I'm wondering with "Overcooked: All You Can Eat", if the gamepad controls would be consistent throughout? If a update could be made for this enquiry, the first game would be more enjoyable since I purchased the games individually.
